qTextArr: ['Most certainly her love has died,']
qText: Most certainly her love has died,
speaker: Fraulein Mosebach

qTextArr: ['Most certainly it has, Frieda, but that will not prevent me from being\nbored with the Wilcoxes if I return the call.']
qText:
Most certainly it has, Frieda, but that will not prevent me from being
bored with the Wilcoxes if I return the call.
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr: ['Oh, boo hoo! boo hoo hoo! Meg s\ngoing to return the call, and I can t.  Cos why?  Cos I m going to\nGerman-eye.']
qText:
Oh, boo hoo! boo hoo hoo! Meg s
going to return the call, and I can t.  Cos why?  Cos I m going to
German-eye.
speaker: Helen

qTextArr: ['If you are going to Germany, go and pack; if you aren t, go and call on\nthe Wilcoxes instead of me.']
qText:
If you are going to Germany, go and pack; if you aren t, go and call on
the Wilcoxes instead of me.
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr: ['But, Meg, Meg, I don t love the young gentleman; I don t love the\nyoung--O lud, who s that coming down the stairs? I vow  tis my brother.\nO crimini!']
qText:
But, Meg, Meg, I don t love the young gentleman; I don t love the
young--O lud, who s that coming down the stairs? I vow  tis my brother.
O crimini!
speaker: Helen

qTextArr: ['It is all right--she does not love the young\nman--he has not been worthy of her.']
qText:
It is all right--she does not love the young
man--he has not been worthy of her.
speaker: Fraulein Mosebach
refExp: Fraulein Mosebach followed her but lingered to say heavily over the banisters to Margaret

qTextArr: ['Yes, I know; thanks very much.']
qText: Yes, I know; thanks very much.
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr: ['I thought I did right to tell you.']
qText: I thought I did right to tell you.
speaker: Fraulein Mosebach

qTextArr: ['Ever so many thanks.']
qText: Ever so many thanks.
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr: ['What s that?']
qText: What s that?
speaker: Tibby

qTextArr: ['Oh, Mrs. Wilcox, I have made the baddest blunder. I am more, more\nashamed and sorry than I can say.']
qText:
Oh, Mrs. Wilcox, I have made the baddest blunder. I am more, more
ashamed and sorry than I can say.
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr: ['I knew he was going to India in November, but I forgot.']
qText: I knew he was going to India in November, but I forgot.
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr: ['He sailed on the 17th for Nigeria, in Africa.']
qText: He sailed on the 17th for Nigeria, in Africa.
speaker: Mrs. Wilcox

qTextArr: ['I knew--I know. I have been too absurd all through. I am very much\nashamed.']
qText:
I knew--I know. I have been too absurd all through. I am very much
ashamed.
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr: ['I am more sorry than I can say, and I hope that you will forgive me.']
qText: I am more sorry than I can say, and I hope that you will forgive me.
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr: ['It doesn t matter, Miss Schlegel. It is good of you to have come round\nso promptly.']
qText:
It doesn t matter, Miss Schlegel. It is good of you to have come round
so promptly.
speaker: Mrs. Wilcox

qTextArr: ['It does matter,', 'I have been rude to you; and my\nsister is not even at home, so there was not even that excuse.']
qText:
It does matter, I have been rude to you; and my
sister is not even at home, so there was not even that excuse.
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr: ['Indeed?']
qText: Indeed?
speaker: Mrs. Wilcox

qTextArr: ['She has just gone to Germany.']
qText: She has just gone to Germany.
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr: ['She gone as well,', 'Yes, certainly, it is quite\nsafe--safe, absolutely, now.']
qText:
She gone as well, Yes, certainly, it is quite
safe--safe, absolutely, now.
speaker: Mrs. Wilcox

qTextArr: ['You ve been worrying too!', 'How perfectly\nextraordinary! I can see that you have. You felt as I do; Helen mustn t\nmeet him again.']
qText:
You ve been worrying too! How perfectly
extraordinary! I can see that you have. You felt as I do; Helen mustn t
meet him again.
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr: ['I did think it best.']
qText: I did think it best.
speaker: Mrs. Wilcox

qTextArr: ['Now why?']
qText: Now why?
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr: ['That s a most difficult question,', 'I think you put it best in\nyour letter--it was an instinct, which may be wrong.']
qText:
That s a most difficult question, I think you put it best in
your letter--it was an instinct, which may be wrong.
speaker: Mrs. Wilcox

qTextArr: ['It wasn t that your son still--']
qText: It wasn t that your son still--
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr: ['Oh no; he often--my Paul is very young, you see.']
qText: Oh no; he often--my Paul is very young, you see.
speaker: Mrs. Wilcox

qTextArr: ['Then what was it?']
qText: Then what was it?
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr: ['An instinct which may be wrong.']
qText: An instinct which may be wrong.
speaker: Mrs. Wilcox

qTextArr: ['In other words, they belong to types that can fall in love, but\ncouldn t live together. That s dreadfully probable. I m afraid that in\nnine cases out of ten Nature pulls one way and human nature another.']
qText:
In other words, they belong to types that can fall in love, but
couldn t live together. That s dreadfully probable. I m afraid that in
nine cases out of ten Nature pulls one way and human nature another.
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr: ['These are indeed  other words,', 'I had nothing so\ncoherent in my head. I was merely alarmed when I knew that my boy cared\nfor your sister.']
qText:
These are indeed  other words, I had nothing so
coherent in my head. I was merely alarmed when I knew that my boy cared
for your sister.
speaker: Mrs. Wilcox

qTextArr: ['Ah, I have always been wanting to ask you. How DID you know? Helen\nwas so surprised when our aunt drove up, and you stepped forward and\narranged things. Did Paul tell you?']
qText:
Ah, I have always been wanting to ask you. How DID you know? Helen
was so surprised when our aunt drove up, and you stepped forward and
arranged things. Did Paul tell you?
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr: ['There is nothing to be gained by discussing that,']
qText: There is nothing to be gained by discussing that,
speaker: Mrs. Wilcox

qTextArr: ['Mrs. Wilcox, were you very angry with us last June? I wrote you a\nletter and you didn t answer it.']
qText:
Mrs. Wilcox, were you very angry with us last June? I wrote you a
letter and you didn t answer it.
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr: ['I was certainly against taking Mrs. Matheson s flat. I knew it was\nopposite your house.']
qText:
I was certainly against taking Mrs. Matheson s flat. I knew it was
opposite your house.
speaker: Mrs. Wilcox

qTextArr: ['But it s all right now?']
qText: But it s all right now?
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr: ['I think so.']
qText: I think so.
speaker: Mrs. Wilcox

qTextArr: ['You only think? You aren t sure? I do love these little muddles tidied\nup?']
qText:
You only think? You aren t sure? I do love these little muddles tidied
up?
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr: ['Oh yes, I m sure,', 'I always sound uncertain over things. It is my way of\nspeaking.']
qText:
Oh yes, I m sure, I always sound uncertain over things. It is my way of
speaking.
speaker: Mrs. Wilcox

qTextArr: ['That s all right, and I m sure, too.']
qText: That s all right, and I m sure, too.
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr: ['I must say good-bye now--you will be getting up.']
qText: I must say good-bye now--you will be getting up.
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr: ['No--please stop a little longer--I am taking a day in bed. Now and then\nI do.']
qText:
No--please stop a little longer--I am taking a day in bed. Now and then
I do.
speaker: Mrs. Wilcox

qTextArr: ['I thought of you as one of the early risers.']
qText: I thought of you as one of the early risers.
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr: ['At Howards End--yes; there is nothing to get up for in London.']
qText: At Howards End--yes; there is nothing to get up for in London.
speaker: Mrs. Wilcox

qTextArr: ['Nothing to get up for?', 'When there are\nall the autumn exhibitions, and Ysaye playing in the afternoon! Not to\nmention people.']
qText:
Nothing to get up for? When there are
all the autumn exhibitions, and Ysaye playing in the afternoon! Not to
mention people.
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr: ['The truth is, I am a little tired. First came the wedding, and then\nPaul went off, and, instead of resting yesterday, I paid a round of\ncalls.']
qText:
The truth is, I am a little tired. First came the wedding, and then
Paul went off, and, instead of resting yesterday, I paid a round of
calls.
speaker: Mrs. Wilcox

qTextArr: ['A wedding?']
qText: A wedding?
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr: ['Yes; Charles, my elder son, is married.']
qText: Yes; Charles, my elder son, is married.
speaker: Mrs. Wilcox

qTextArr: ['Indeed!']
qText: Indeed!
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr:
['We took the flat chiefly on that account, and also that Paul could get
his African outfit. The flat belongs to a cousin of my husband s, and
she most kindly offered it to us. So before the day came we were able to
make the acquaintance of Dolly s people, which we had not yet done.']
qText:
We took the flat chiefly on that account, and also that Paul could get
his African outfit. The flat belongs to a cousin of my husband s, and
she most kindly offered it to us. So before the day came we were able to
make the acquaintance of Dolly s people, which we had not yet done.
speaker: Mrs. Wilcox
menEnts: [[['Paul', 'Charles Wilcox', 'Mrs. Wilcox', 'Evie', 'Mr. Wilcox'], ['Paul'], ['Paul'], ['Mr. Wilcox'], ['Paul', 'Charles Wilcox', 'Mrs. Wilcox', 'Evie', 'Mr. Wilcox'], ['Paul', 'Charles Wilcox', 'Mrs. Wilcox', 'Evie', 'Mr. Wilcox'], ['Dolly'], ['Paul', 'Charles Wilcox', 'Mrs. Wilcox', 'Evie', 'Mr. Wilcox']]]

qTextArr: ['Fussell. The father is in the Indian army--retired; the brother is in\nthe army. The mother is dead.']
qText:
Fussell. The father is in the Indian army--retired; the brother is in
the army. The mother is dead.
speaker: Mrs. Wilcox

qTextArr:
['Charles and Albert Fussell have known one another some time. They
belong to the same club, and are both devoted to golf. Dolly plays
golf too, though I believe not so well; and they first met in a mixed
foursome. We all like her, and are very much pleased. They were married
on the 11th, a few days before Paul sailed. Charles was very anxious to
have his brother as best man, so he made a great point of having it on
the 11th. The Fussells would have preferred it after Christmas, but they
were very nice about it. There is Dolly s photograph--in that double
frame.']
qText:
Charles and Albert Fussell have known one another some time. They
belong to the same club, and are both devoted to golf. Dolly plays
golf too, though I believe not so well; and they first met in a mixed
foursome. We all like her, and are very much pleased. They were married
on the 11th, a few days before Paul sailed. Charles was very anxious to
have his brother as best man, so he made a great point of having it on
the 11th. The Fussells would have preferred it after Christmas, but they
were very nice about it. There is Dolly s photograph--in that double
frame.
speaker: Mrs. Wilcox
menEnts: [[['Charles Wilcox'], ['Dolly'], ['Charles Wilcox', 'Dolly'], ['Paul', 'Mrs. Wilcox', 'Evie', 'Mr. Wilcox'], ['Dolly'], ['Charles Wilcox', 'Dolly'], ['Paul'], ['Charles Wilcox'], ['Paul'], ['Charles Wilcox'], ['Dolly']]]

qTextArr: ['Are you quite certain that I m not interrupting, Mrs. Wilcox?']
qText: Are you quite certain that I m not interrupting, Mrs. Wilcox?
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr: ['Yes, quite.']
qText: Yes, quite.
speaker: Mrs. Wilcox

qTextArr: ['Then I will stay. I m enjoying this.']
qText: Then I will stay. I m enjoying this.
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr: ['They have gone to Naples for their honeymoon.']
qText: They have gone to Naples for their honeymoon.
speaker: Mrs. Wilcox

qTextArr: ['Lucky people!']
qText: Lucky people!
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr: ['I can hardly imagine Charles in Italy.']
qText: I can hardly imagine Charles in Italy.
speaker: Mrs. Wilcox

qTextArr: ['Doesn t he care for travelling?']
qText: Doesn t he care for travelling?
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr:
['He likes travel, but he does see through foreigners so. What he enjoys
most is a motor tour in England, and I think that would have carried the
day if the weather had not been so abominable. His father gave him a car
for a wedding present, which for the present is being stored at Howards
End.']
qText:
He likes travel, but he does see through foreigners so. What he enjoys
most is a motor tour in England, and I think that would have carried the
day if the weather had not been so abominable. His father gave him a car
for a wedding present, which for the present is being stored at Howards
End.
speaker: Mrs. Wilcox

qTextArr: ['I suppose you have a garage there?']
qText: I suppose you have a garage there?
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr: ['Yes. My husband built a little one only last month, to the west of the\nhouse, not far from the wych-elm, in what used to be the paddock for the\npony.']
qText:
Yes. My husband built a little one only last month, to the west of the
house, not far from the wych-elm, in what used to be the paddock for the
pony.
speaker: Mrs. Wilcox

qTextArr: ['Where s the pony gone?']
qText: Where s the pony gone?
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr: ['The pony? Oh, dead, ever so long ago.']
qText: The pony? Oh, dead, ever so long ago.
speaker: Mrs. Wilcox

qTextArr: ['The wych-elm I remember. Helen spoke of it as a very splendid tree.']
qText: The wych-elm I remember. Helen spoke of it as a very splendid tree.
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr: ['It is the finest wych-elm in Hertfordshire. Did your sister tell you\nabout the teeth?']
qText:
It is the finest wych-elm in Hertfordshire. Did your sister tell you
about the teeth?
speaker: Mrs. Wilcox

qText: No.
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr:
['Oh, it might interest you. There are pigs  teeth stuck into the trunk,
about four feet from the ground. The country people put them in long
ago, and they think that if they chew a piece of the bark, it will cure
the toothache. The teeth are almost grown over now, and no one comes to
the tree.']
qText:
Oh, it might interest you. There are pigs  teeth stuck into the trunk,
about four feet from the ground. The country people put them in long
ago, and they think that if they chew a piece of the bark, it will cure
the toothache. The teeth are almost grown over now, and no one comes to
the tree.
speaker: Mrs. Wilcox

qTextArr: ['I should. I love folklore and all festering superstitions.']
qText: I should. I love folklore and all festering superstitions.
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr: ['Do you think that the tree really did cure toothache, if one believed\nin it?']
qText:
Do you think that the tree really did cure toothache, if one believed
in it?
speaker: Mrs. Wilcox

qTextArr: ['Of course it did. It would cure anything--once.']
qText: Of course it did. It would cure anything--once.
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr: ['Certainly I remember cases--you see I lived at Howards End long, long\nbefore Mr. Wilcox knew it. I was born there.']
qText:
Certainly I remember cases--you see I lived at Howards End long, long
before Mr. Wilcox knew it. I was born there.
speaker: Mrs. Wilcox

qTextArr: ['Good-bye, Miss Schlegel, good-bye. Thank you for coming. You have\ncheered me up.']
qText:
Good-bye, Miss Schlegel, good-bye. Thank you for coming. You have
cheered me up.
speaker: Mrs. Wilcox

qTextArr: ['I m so glad!']
qText: I m so glad!
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr: ['I--I wonder whether you ever think about yourself?']
qText: I--I wonder whether you ever think about yourself?
speaker: Mrs. Wilcox

qTextArr: ['I think of nothing else,']
qText: I think of nothing else,
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr: ['I wonder. I wondered at Heidelberg.']
qText: I wonder. I wondered at Heidelberg.
speaker: Mrs. Wilcox

qTextArr: ['I M sure!']
qText: I M sure!
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr: ['I almost think--']
qText: I almost think--
speaker: Mrs. Wilcox

qText: Yes?
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr: ['I almost think you forget you re a girl.']
qText: I almost think you forget you re a girl.
speaker: Mrs. Wilcox

qTextArr: ['I m twenty-nine,', 'That s not so wildly girlish.']
qText: I m twenty-nine, That s not so wildly girlish.
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr: ['What makes you say that? Do you mean that I have been gauche and rude?']
qText: What makes you say that? Do you mean that I have been gauche and rude?
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr: ['I only meant that I am fifty-one, and that to\nme both of you--Read it all in some book or other; I cannot put things\nclearly.']
qText:
I only meant that I am fifty-one, and that to
me both of you--Read it all in some book or other; I cannot put things
clearly.
speaker: Mrs. Wilcox

qTextArr: ['Oh, I ve got it--inexperience. I m no better than Helen, you mean, and\nyet I presume to advise her.']
qText:
Oh, I ve got it--inexperience. I m no better than Helen, you mean, and
yet I presume to advise her.
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr: ['Yes. You have got it. Inexperience is the word.']
qText: Yes. You have got it. Inexperience is the word.
speaker: Mrs. Wilcox

qTextArr: ['Inexperience,']
qText: Inexperience,
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr:
['Of course, I have everything to learn--absolutely everything--just
as much as Helen. Life s very difficult and full of surprises. At all
events, I ve got as far as that. To be humble and kind, to go
straight ahead, to love people rather than pity them, to remember the
submerged--well, one can t do all these things at once, worse luck,
because they re so contradictory. It s then that proportion comes in--to
live by proportion. Don t BEGIN with proportion. Only prigs do that.
Let proportion come in as a last resource, when the better things have
failed, and a deadlock--Gracious me, I ve started preaching!']
qText:
Of course, I have everything to learn--absolutely everything--just
as much as Helen. Life s very difficult and full of surprises. At all
events, I ve got as far as that. To be humble and kind, to go
straight ahead, to love people rather than pity them, to remember the
submerged--well, one can t do all these things at once, worse luck,
because they re so contradictory. It s then that proportion comes in--to
live by proportion. Don t BEGIN with proportion. Only prigs do that.
Let proportion come in as a last resource, when the better things have
failed, and a deadlock--Gracious me, I ve started preaching!
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr: ['Indeed, you put the difficulties of life splendidly,', 'It is just what I should\nhave liked to say about them myself.']
qText:
Indeed, you put the difficulties of life splendidly, It is just what I should
have liked to say about them myself.
speaker: Mrs. Wilcox

qTextArr: ['I hope that your sister is safe in Germany by now.']
qText: I hope that your sister is safe in Germany by now.
speaker: Mrs. Wilcox
addressee: ['A Young Man Low Down In The Education Office', 'Margaret']

qTextArr: ['Yes, thank you; I heard on Tuesday.']
qText: Yes, thank you; I heard on Tuesday.
speaker: Margaret
addressee: ['Mrs. Wilcox', 'A Young Man Low Down In The Education Office']

qTextArr: ['Only on Tuesday, for they live right away at Stettin. Did you ever know\nany one living at Stettin?']
qText:
Only on Tuesday, for they live right away at Stettin. Did you ever know
any one living at Stettin?
speaker: Margaret
addressee: ['Mrs. Wilcox', 'A Young Man Low Down In The Education Office']

qTextArr: ['Never,']
qText: Never,
speaker: Mrs. Wilcox
addressee: ['A Young Man Low Down In The Education Office', 'Margaret']

qTextArr:
['People at Stettin drop things into boats out of overhanging warehouses.
At least, our cousins do, but aren t particularly rich. The town isn t
interesting, except for a clock that rolls its eyes, and the view of the
Oder, which truly is something special. Oh, Mrs. Wilcox, you would
love the Oder! The river, or rather rivers--there seem to be dozens
of them--are intense blue, and the plain they run through an intensest
green.']
qText:
People at Stettin drop things into boats out of overhanging warehouses.
At least, our cousins do, but aren t particularly rich. The town isn t
interesting, except for a clock that rolls its eyes, and the view of the
Oder, which truly is something special. Oh, Mrs. Wilcox, you would
love the Oder! The river, or rather rivers--there seem to be dozens
of them--are intense blue, and the plain they run through an intensest
green.
speaker: Margaret
addressee: ['Mrs. Wilcox', 'A Young Man Low Down In The Education Office']

qTextArr: ['Indeed! That sounds like a most beautiful view, Miss Schlegel.']
qText: Indeed! That sounds like a most beautiful view, Miss Schlegel.
speaker: Mrs. Wilcox
addressee: ['A Young Man Low Down In The Education Office', 'Margaret']

qTextArr:
['So I say, but Helen, who will muddle things, says no, it s like music.
The course of the Oder is to be like music. It s obliged to remind her
of a symphonic poem. The part by the landing-stage is in B minor, if I
remember rightly, but lower down things get extremely mixed. There is a
slodgy theme in several keys at once, meaning mud-banks, and another for
the navigable canal, and the exit into the Baltic is in C sharp major,
pianissimo.']
qText:
So I say, but Helen, who will muddle things, says no, it s like music.
The course of the Oder is to be like music. It s obliged to remind her
of a symphonic poem. The part by the landing-stage is in B minor, if I
remember rightly, but lower down things get extremely mixed. There is a
slodgy theme in several keys at once, meaning mud-banks, and another for
the navigable canal, and the exit into the Baltic is in C sharp major,
pianissimo.
speaker: Margaret
addressee: ['Mrs. Wilcox', 'A Young Man Low Down In The Education Office']

qTextArr: ['What do the overhanging warehouses make of that?']
qText: What do the overhanging warehouses make of that?
speaker: A Young Man Low Down In The Education Office

qTextArr:
['They make a great deal of it,', 'I think it s affectation to compare the Oder to
music, and so do you, but the overhanging warehouses of Stettin take
beauty seriously, which we don t, and the average Englishman doesn t,
and despises all who do. Now don t say  Germans have no taste,  or I
shall scream. They haven t. But--but--such a tremendous but!--they take
poetry seriously. They do take poetry seriously.']
qText:
They make a great deal of it, I think it s affectation to compare the Oder to
music, and so do you, but the overhanging warehouses of Stettin take
beauty seriously, which we don t, and the average Englishman doesn t,
and despises all who do. Now don t say  Germans have no taste,  or I
shall scream. They haven t. But--but--such a tremendous but!--they take
poetry seriously. They do take poetry seriously.
speaker: Margaret
addressee: ['Mrs. Wilcox', 'A Young Man Low Down In The Education Office']

qTextArr: ['Is anything gained by that?']
qText: Is anything gained by that?
speaker: A Young Man Low Down In The Education Office

qTextArr:
['Yes, yes. The German is always on the lookout for beauty. He may miss
it through stupidity, or misinterpret it, but he is always asking
beauty to enter his life, and I believe that in the end it will come. At
Heidelberg I met a fat veterinary surgeon whose voice broke with sobs as
he repeated some mawkish poetry. So easy for me to laugh--I, who never
repeat poetry, good or bad, and cannot remember one fragment of verse
to thrill myself with. My blood boils--well, I m half German, so put
it down to patriotism--when I listen to the tasteful contempt of the
average islander for things Teutonic, whether they re Bocklin or my
veterinary surgeon.  Oh, Bocklin,  they say;  he strains after beauty,
he peoples Nature with gods too consciously.  Of course Bocklin strains,
because he wants something--beauty and all the other intangible gifts
that are floating about the world. So his landscapes don t come off, and
Leader s do.']
qText:
Yes, yes. The German is always on the lookout for beauty. He may miss
it through stupidity, or misinterpret it, but he is always asking
beauty to enter his life, and I believe that in the end it will come. At
Heidelberg I met a fat veterinary surgeon whose voice broke with sobs as
he repeated some mawkish poetry. So easy for me to laugh--I, who never
repeat poetry, good or bad, and cannot remember one fragment of verse
to thrill myself with. My blood boils--well, I m half German, so put
it down to patriotism--when I listen to the tasteful contempt of the
average islander for things Teutonic, whether they re Bocklin or my
veterinary surgeon.  Oh, Bocklin,  they say;  he strains after beauty,
he peoples Nature with gods too consciously.  Of course Bocklin strains,
because he wants something--beauty and all the other intangible gifts
that are floating about the world. So his landscapes don t come off, and
Leader s do.
speaker: Margaret
addressee: ['Mrs. Wilcox', 'A Young Man Low Down In The Education Office']

qTextArr: ['I am not sure that I agree. Do you?']
qText: I am not sure that I agree. Do you?
speaker: A Young Man Low Down In The Education Office

qTextArr: ['I think Miss Schlegel puts everything splendidly;']
qText: I think Miss Schlegel puts everything splendidly;
speaker: Mrs. Wilcox
addressee: ['A Young Man Low Down In The Education Office', 'Margaret']

qTextArr: ['Oh, Mrs. Wilcox, say something nicer than that. It s such a snub to be\ntold you put things splendidly.']
qText:
Oh, Mrs. Wilcox, say something nicer than that. It s such a snub to be
told you put things splendidly.
speaker: Margaret
addressee: ['Mrs. Wilcox', 'A Young Man Low Down In The Education Office']

qTextArr: ['I do not mean it as a snub. Your last speech interested me so much.\nGenerally people do not seem quite to like Germany. I have long wanted\nto hear what is said on the other side.']
qText:
I do not mean it as a snub. Your last speech interested me so much.
Generally people do not seem quite to like Germany. I have long wanted
to hear what is said on the other side.
speaker: Mrs. Wilcox
addressee: ['A Young Man Low Down In The Education Office', 'Margaret']

qTextArr: ['The other side? Then you do disagree. Oh, good! Give us your side.']
qText: The other side? Then you do disagree. Oh, good! Give us your side.
speaker: Margaret
addressee: ['Mrs. Wilcox', 'A Young Man Low Down In The Education Office']
menEnts: [[['Mrs. Wilcox'], ['A Young Man Low Down In The Education Office', 'Margaret'], ['Mrs. Wilcox']]]

qTextArr: ['I have no side. But my husband']
qText: I have no side. But my husband
speaker: Mrs. Wilcox
addressee: ['A Young Man Low Down In The Education Office', 'Margaret']

qTextArr: ['has very little faith in the Continent, and our children\nhave all taken after him.']
qText:
has very little faith in the Continent, and our children
have all taken after him.
speaker: Mrs. Wilcox
addressee: ['A Young Man Low Down In The Education Office', 'Margaret']

qTextArr: ['On what grounds? Do they feel that the Continent is in bad form?']
qText: On what grounds? Do they feel that the Continent is in bad form?
speaker: Margaret
addressee: ['Mrs. Wilcox', 'A Young Man Low Down In The Education Office']

qTextArr:
['You will admit, though, that the Continent--it seems silly to speak of
 the Continent,  but really it is all more like itself than any part of
it is like England. England is unique. Do have another jelly first. I
was going to say that the Continent, for good or for evil, is interested
in ideas. Its Literature and Art have what one might call the kink of
the unseen about them, and this persists even through decadence and
affectation. There is more liberty of action in England, but for liberty
of thought go to bureaucratic Prussia. People will there discuss with
humility vital questions that we here think ourselves too good to touch
with tongs.']
qText:
You will admit, though, that the Continent--it seems silly to speak of
 the Continent,  but really it is all more like itself than any part of
it is like England. England is unique. Do have another jelly first. I
was going to say that the Continent, for good or for evil, is interested
in ideas. Its Literature and Art have what one might call the kink of
the unseen about them, and this persists even through decadence and
affectation. There is more liberty of action in England, but for liberty
of thought go to bureaucratic Prussia. People will there discuss with
humility vital questions that we here think ourselves too good to touch
with tongs.
speaker: Margaret
addressee: ['A Girl Opposite', 'Mrs. Wilcox', 'A Young Man Low Down In The Education Office']

qTextArr: ['I do not want to go to Prussia,', 'not even to see\nthat interesting view that you were describing. And for discussing with\nhumility I am too old. We never discuss anything at Howards End.']
qText:
I do not want to go to Prussia, not even to see
that interesting view that you were describing. And for discussing with
humility I am too old. We never discuss anything at Howards End.
speaker: Mrs. Wilcox
addressee: ['A Girl Opposite', 'A Young Man Low Down In The Education Office', 'Margaret']

qTextArr: ['Then you ought to!', 'Discussion keeps a house alive. It\ncannot stand by bricks and mortar alone.']
qText:
Then you ought to! Discussion keeps a house alive. It
cannot stand by bricks and mortar alone.
speaker: Margaret
addressee: ['A Girl Opposite', 'Mrs. Wilcox', 'A Young Man Low Down In The Education Office']

qTextArr: ['It cannot stand without them,', 'It cannot stand without\nthem, and I sometimes think--But I cannot expect your generation to\nagree, for even my daughter disagrees with me here.']
qText:
It cannot stand without them, It cannot stand without
them, and I sometimes think--But I cannot expect your generation to
agree, for even my daughter disagrees with me here.
speaker: Mrs. Wilcox
addressee: ['A Girl Opposite', 'A Young Man Low Down In The Education Office', 'Margaret']
menEnts: [[], [['Margaret', 'A Young Man Low Down In The Education Office', 'A Girl Opposite'], ['Evie']]]

qTextArr: ['Never mind us or her. Do say!']
qText: Never mind us or her. Do say!
speaker: Margaret
addressee: ['A Girl Opposite', 'Mrs. Wilcox', 'A Young Man Low Down In The Education Office']
menEnts: [[['A Young Man Low Down In The Education Office', 'Margaret'], ['Evie']]]

qTextArr: ['I sometimes think that it is wiser to leave action and discussion to\nmen.']
qText:
I sometimes think that it is wiser to leave action and discussion to
men.
speaker: Mrs. Wilcox
addressee: ['A Girl Opposite', 'A Young Man Low Down In The Education Office', 'Margaret']

qTextArr: ['One admits that the arguments against the suffrage ARE extraordinarily\nstrong,']
qText:
One admits that the arguments against the suffrage ARE extraordinarily
strong,
speaker: A Girl Opposite
addressee: ['A Young Man Low Down In The Education Office', 'Mrs. Wilcox', 'Margaret']

qTextArr: ['Are they? I never follow any arguments. I am only too thankful not to\nhave a vote myself.']
qText:
Are they? I never follow any arguments. I am only too thankful not to
have a vote myself.
speaker: Mrs. Wilcox
addressee: ['A Girl Opposite', 'A Young Man Low Down In The Education Office', 'Margaret']

qTextArr:
['We didn t mean the vote, though, did we?', 'Aren t
we differing on something much wider, Mrs. Wilcox? Whether women are to
remain what they have been since the dawn of history; or whether, since
men have moved forward so far, they too may move forward a little now. I
say they may. I would even admit a biological change.']
qText:
We didn t mean the vote, though, did we? Aren t
we differing on something much wider, Mrs. Wilcox? Whether women are to
remain what they have been since the dawn of history; or whether, since
men have moved forward so far, they too may move forward a little now. I
say they may. I would even admit a biological change.
speaker: Margaret
addressee: ['A Girl Opposite', 'Mrs. Wilcox', 'A Young Man Low Down In The Education Office']

qTextArr: ['I don t know, I don t know.']
qText: I don t know, I don t know.
speaker: Mrs. Wilcox
addressee: ['A Girl Opposite', 'A Young Man Low Down In The Education Office', 'Margaret']

qTextArr: ['I must be getting back to my overhanging warehouse,', 'They ve turned disgracefully strict.']
qText: I must be getting back to my overhanging warehouse, They ve turned disgracefully strict.
speaker: A Young Man Low Down In The Education Office

qTextArr: ['Oh, but come upstairs for a little. Miss Quested plays. Do you like\nMacDowell? Do you mind his only having two noises? If you must really\ngo, I ll see you out. Won t you even have coffee?']
qText:
Oh, but come upstairs for a little. Miss Quested plays. Do you like
MacDowell? Do you mind his only having two noises? If you must really
go, I ll see you out. Won t you even have coffee?
speaker: Margaret
addressee: ['A Girl Opposite', 'Mrs. Wilcox', 'A Young Man Low Down In The Education Office']

qTextArr: ['What an interesting life you\nall lead in London!']
qText:
What an interesting life you
all lead in London!
speaker: Mrs. Wilcox

qTextArr:
['No, we don t,', 'We lead the
lives of gibbering monkeys. Mrs. Wilcox--really--We have something quiet
and stable at the bottom. We really have. All my friends have. Don t
pretend you enjoyed lunch, for you loathed it, but forgive me by coming
again, alone, or by asking me to you.']
qText:
No, we don t, We lead the
lives of gibbering monkeys. Mrs. Wilcox--really--We have something quiet
and stable at the bottom. We really have. All my friends have. Don t
pretend you enjoyed lunch, for you loathed it, but forgive me by coming
again, alone, or by asking me to you.
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr:
['I am used to young people,', 'I hear a great deal of
chatter at home, for we, like you, entertain a great deal. With us it
is more sport and politics, but--I enjoyed my lunch very much, Miss
Schlegel, dear, and am not pretending, and only wish I could have joined
in more. For one thing, I m not particularly well just to-day. For
another, you younger people move so quickly that it dazes me. Charles
is the same, Dolly the same. But we are all in the same boat, old and
young. I never forget that.']
qText:
I am used to young people, I hear a great deal of
chatter at home, for we, like you, entertain a great deal. With us it
is more sport and politics, but--I enjoyed my lunch very much, Miss
Schlegel, dear, and am not pretending, and only wish I could have joined
in more. For one thing, I m not particularly well just to-day. For
another, you younger people move so quickly that it dazes me. Charles
is the same, Dolly the same. But we are all in the same boat, old and
young. I never forget that.
speaker: Mrs. Wilcox
menEnts: [[], [['Paul', 'Charles Wilcox', 'Mrs. Wilcox', 'Evie', 'Mr. Wilcox'], ['Margaret'], ['Paul', 'Charles Wilcox', 'Mrs. Wilcox', 'Evie', 'Mr. Wilcox'], ['Margaret'], ['Margaret'], ['Charles Wilcox'], ['Dolly'], ['Margaret', 'Mrs. Wilcox', 'Charles Wilcox', 'Dolly']]]

qTextArr: ['First of all,', 'we must make a list and tick off the\npeople s names. My aunt always does, and this fog may thicken up any\nmoment. Have you any ideas?']
qText:
First of all, we must make a list and tick off the
people s names. My aunt always does, and this fog may thicken up any
moment. Have you any ideas?
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr:
['I thought we would go to Harrods or the Haymarket Stores,', 'Everything is sure to be there. I am not a
good shopper. The din is so confusing, and your aunt is quite right--one
ought to make a list. Take my notebook, then, and write your own name at
the top of the page.']
qText:
I thought we would go to Harrods or the Haymarket Stores, Everything is sure to be there. I am not a
good shopper. The din is so confusing, and your aunt is quite right--one
ought to make a list. Take my notebook, then, and write your own name at
the top of the page.
speaker: Mrs. Wilcox

qTextArr: ['Oh, hooray!', 'How very kind of you to start\nwith me!']
qText:
Oh, hooray! How very kind of you to start
with me!
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr: ['I don t really want a Yuletide\ngift, though. In fact, I d rather not.']
qText:
I don t really want a Yuletide
gift, though. In fact, I d rather not.
speaker: Margaret

qText: Why?
speaker: Mrs. Wilcox

qTextArr: ['Because I ve odd ideas about Christmas. Because I have all that money\ncan buy. I want more people, but no more things.']
qText:
Because I ve odd ideas about Christmas. Because I have all that money
can buy. I want more people, but no more things.
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr:
['I should like to give you something worth your acquaintance, Miss
Schlegel, in memory of your kindness to me during my lonely fortnight.
It has so happened that I have been left alone, and you have stopped me
from brooding. I am too apt to brood.']
qText:
I should like to give you something worth your acquaintance, Miss
Schlegel, in memory of your kindness to me during my lonely fortnight.
It has so happened that I have been left alone, and you have stopped me
from brooding. I am too apt to brood.
speaker: Mrs. Wilcox

qTextArr: ['If that is so,', 'if I have happened to be of use to you,\nwhich I didn t know, you cannot pay me back with anything tangible.']
qText:
If that is so, if I have happened to be of use to you,
which I didn t know, you cannot pay me back with anything tangible.
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr: ['I suppose not, but one would like to. Perhaps I shall think of\nsomething as we go about.']
qText:
I suppose not, but one would like to. Perhaps I shall think of
something as we go about.
speaker: Mrs. Wilcox

qTextArr: ['We always give the\nservants money.']
qText:
We always give the
servants money.
speaker: Mrs. Wilcox

qTextArr: ['Yes, do you, yes, much easier,']
qText: Yes, do you, yes, much easier,
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr: ['No, I do like Christmas on the whole,', 'In its clumsy\nway, it does approach Peace and Goodwill. But oh, it is clumsier every\nyear.']
qText:
No, I do like Christmas on the whole, In its clumsy
way, it does approach Peace and Goodwill. But oh, it is clumsier every
year.
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr: ['Is it? I am only used to country Christmases.']
qText: Is it? I am only used to country Christmases.
speaker: Mrs. Wilcox

qTextArr:
['We are usually in London, and play the game with vigour--carols at
the Abbey, clumsy midday meal, clumsy dinner for the maids, followed by
Christmas-tree and dancing of poor children, with songs from Helen.
The drawing-room does very well for that. We put the tree in the
powder-closet, and draw a curtain when the candles are lighted, and with
the looking-glass behind it looks quite pretty. I wish we might have
a powder-closet in our next house. Of course, the tree has to be very
small, and the presents don t hang on it. No; the presents reside in a
sort of rocky landscape made of crumpled brown paper.']
qText:
We are usually in London, and play the game with vigour--carols at
the Abbey, clumsy midday meal, clumsy dinner for the maids, followed by
Christmas-tree and dancing of poor children, with songs from Helen.
The drawing-room does very well for that. We put the tree in the
powder-closet, and draw a curtain when the candles are lighted, and with
the looking-glass behind it looks quite pretty. I wish we might have
a powder-closet in our next house. Of course, the tree has to be very
small, and the presents don t hang on it. No; the presents reside in a
sort of rocky landscape made of crumpled brown paper.
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr: ['You spoke of your  next house,  Miss Schlegel. Then are you leaving\nWickham Place?']
qText:
You spoke of your  next house,  Miss Schlegel. Then are you leaving
Wickham Place?
speaker: Mrs. Wilcox

qTextArr: ['Yes, in two or three years, when the lease expires. We must.']
qText: Yes, in two or three years, when the lease expires. We must.
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr: ['Have you been there long?']
qText: Have you been there long?
speaker: Mrs. Wilcox

qTextArr: ['All our lives.']
qText: All our lives.
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr: ['You will be very sorry to leave it.']
qText: You will be very sorry to leave it.
speaker: Mrs. Wilcox

qTextArr: ['I suppose so. We scarcely realise it yet. My father--']
qText: I suppose so. We scarcely realise it yet. My father--
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr: ['If possible, something distinctive,']
qText: If possible, something distinctive,
speaker: Mrs. Wilcox

qTextArr: ['My husband and our daughter are\nmotoring.']
qText:
My husband and our daughter are
motoring.
speaker: A Friend Of Mrs. Wilcox

qTextArr: ['Bertha, too? Oh, fancy, what a coincidence!']
qText: Bertha, too? Oh, fancy, what a coincidence!
speaker: Mrs. Wilcox

qTextArr: ['Do you know, I ll wait. On\nsecond thoughts, I ll wait. There s plenty of time still, isn t there,\nand I shall be able to get Evie s opinion.']
qText:
Do you know, I ll wait. On
second thoughts, I ll wait. There s plenty of time still, isn t there,
and I shall be able to get Evie s opinion.
speaker: Mrs. Wilcox

qTextArr: ['But couldn t you get it renewed?']
qText: But couldn t you get it renewed?
speaker: Mrs. Wilcox

qTextArr: ['I beg your pardon?']
qText: I beg your pardon?
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr: ['The lease, I mean.']
qText: The lease, I mean.
speaker: Mrs. Wilcox

qTextArr: ['Oh, the lease! Have you been thinking of that all the time? How very\nkind of you!']
qText:
Oh, the lease! Have you been thinking of that all the time? How very
kind of you!
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr: ['Surely something could be done.']
qText: Surely something could be done.
speaker: Mrs. Wilcox

qTextArr: ['No; values have risen too enormously. They mean to pull down Wickham\nPlace, and build flats like yours.']
qText:
No; values have risen too enormously. They mean to pull down Wickham
Place, and build flats like yours.
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr: ['But how horrible!']
qText: But how horrible!
speaker: Mrs. Wilcox

qTextArr: ['Landlords are horrible.']
qText: Landlords are horrible.
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr:
['It is monstrous, Miss Schlegel; it isn t
right. I had no idea that this was hanging over you. I do pity you from
the bottom of my heart. To be parted from your house, your father s
house--it oughtn t to be allowed. It is worse than dying. I would rather
die than--Oh, poor girls! Can what they call civilisation be right, if
people mayn t die in the room where they were born? My dear, I am so
sorry.']
qText:
It is monstrous, Miss Schlegel; it isn t
right. I had no idea that this was hanging over you. I do pity you from
the bottom of my heart. To be parted from your house, your father s
house--it oughtn t to be allowed. It is worse than dying. I would rather
die than--Oh, poor girls! Can what they call civilisation be right, if
people mayn t die in the room where they were born? My dear, I am so
sorry.
speaker: Mrs. Wilcox

qTextArr: ['Howards End was nearly pulled down once. It would have killed me.']
qText: Howards End was nearly pulled down once. It would have killed me.
speaker: Mrs. Wilcox

qTextArr: ['I--Howards End must be a very different house to ours. We are fond of\nours, but there is nothing distinctive about it. As you saw, it is an\nordinary London house. We shall easily find another.']
qText:
I--Howards End must be a very different house to ours. We are fond of
ours, but there is nothing distinctive about it. As you saw, it is an
ordinary London house. We shall easily find another.
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr: ['So you think.']
qText: So you think.
speaker: Mrs. Wilcox

qTextArr:
['Again my lack of experience, I suppose!', 'I can t say anything when you take up that line, Mrs.
Wilcox. I wish I could see myself as you see me--foreshortened into a
backfisch. Quite the ingenue. Very charming--wonderfully well read for
my age, but incapable--']
qText:
Again my lack of experience, I suppose! I can t say anything when you take up that line, Mrs.
Wilcox. I wish I could see myself as you see me--foreshortened into a
backfisch. Quite the ingenue. Very charming--wonderfully well read for
my age, but incapable--
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr:
['Come down with me to Howards End
now,', 'I want you to see it. You
have never seen it. I want to hear what you say about it, for you do put
things so wonderfully.']
qText:
Come down with me to Howards End
now, I want you to see it. You
have never seen it. I want to hear what you say about it, for you do put
things so wonderfully.
speaker: Mrs. Wilcox

qTextArr: ['Later on I should love it,', 'but it s hardly\nthe weather for such an expedition, and we ought to start when we re\nfresh. Isn t the house shut up, too?']
qText:
Later on I should love it, but it s hardly
the weather for such an expedition, and we ought to start when we re
fresh. Isn t the house shut up, too?
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr: ['Might I come some other day?']
qText: Might I come some other day?
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr: ['Back to Wickham Place,\nplease!']
qText:
Back to Wickham Place,
please!
speaker: Mrs. Wilcox
refExp: was her order to the coachman

qTextArr: ['A thousand thanks, Miss Schlegel, for all your help.']
qText: A thousand thanks, Miss Schlegel, for all your help.
speaker: Mrs. Wilcox

qTextArr: ['Not at all.']
qText: Not at all.
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr: ['It is such a comfort to get the presents off my mind--the\nChristmas-cards especially. I do admire your choice.']
qText:
It is such a comfort to get the presents off my mind--the
Christmas-cards especially. I do admire your choice.
speaker: Mrs. Wilcox

qTextArr:
['My husband and Evie will be back the day after to-morrow. That is why
I dragged you out shopping to-day. I stayed in town chiefly to shop,
but got through nothing, and now he writes that they must cut their
tour short, the weather is so bad, and the police-traps have been so
bad--nearly as bad as in Surrey. Ours is such a careful chauffeur, and
my husband feels it particularly hard that they should be treated like
road-hogs.']
qText:
My husband and Evie will be back the day after to-morrow. That is why
I dragged you out shopping to-day. I stayed in town chiefly to shop,
but got through nothing, and now he writes that they must cut their
tour short, the weather is so bad, and the police-traps have been so
bad--nearly as bad as in Surrey. Ours is such a careful chauffeur, and
my husband feels it particularly hard that they should be treated like
road-hogs.
speaker: Mrs. Wilcox

qText: Why?
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr: ['Well, naturally he--he isn t a road-hog.']
qText: Well, naturally he--he isn t a road-hog.
speaker: Mrs. Wilcox

qTextArr: ['He was exceeding the speed-limit, I conclude. He must expect to suffer\nwith the lower animals.']
qText:
He was exceeding the speed-limit, I conclude. He must expect to suffer
with the lower animals.
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr: ['I will come if I still may,']
qText: I will come if I still may,
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr: ['You are coming to sleep, dear, too. It is in the morning that my house\nis most beautiful. You are coming to stop. I cannot show you my meadow\nproperly except at sunrise. These fogs']
qText:
You are coming to sleep, dear, too. It is in the morning that my house
is most beautiful. You are coming to stop. I cannot show you my meadow
properly except at sunrise. These fogs
speaker: Mrs. Wilcox

qTextArr: ['never spread far. I dare say they are sitting in the sun in\nHertfordshire, and you will never repent joining them.']
qText:
never spread far. I dare say they are sitting in the sun in
Hertfordshire, and you will never repent joining them.
speaker: Mrs. Wilcox

qTextArr: ['I shall never repent joining you.']
qText: I shall never repent joining you.
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr: ['It is the same.']
qText: It is the same.
speaker: Mrs. Wilcox

qTextArr: ['Mother! mother!']
qText: Mother! mother!
speaker: Evie

qTextArr: ['Evie!', 'Evie, my pet--']
qText: Evie! Evie, my pet--
speaker: Mrs. Wilcox

qTextArr: ['Father! I say! look who s here.']
qText: Father! I say! look who s here.
speaker: Evie

qTextArr: ['Evie, dearest girl, why aren t you in Yorkshire?']
qText: Evie, dearest girl, why aren t you in Yorkshire?
speaker: Mrs. Wilcox

qTextArr: ['No--motor smash--changed plans--father s coming.']
qText: No--motor smash--changed plans--father s coming.
speaker: Evie

qTextArr: ['Why, Ruth!', 'what in the name of all\nthat s wonderful are you doing here, Ruth?']
qText:
Why, Ruth! what in the name of all
that s wonderful are you doing here, Ruth?
speaker: Mr. Wilcox

qTextArr: ['Oh, Henry dear!--here s a lovely surprise--but let me introduce--but I\nthink you know Miss Schlegel.']
qText:
Oh, Henry dear!--here s a lovely surprise--but let me introduce--but I
think you know Miss Schlegel.
speaker: Mrs. Wilcox

qTextArr: ['Oh yes,', 'But how s yourself,\nRuth?']
qText:
Oh yes, But how s yourself,
Ruth?
speaker: Mr. Wilcox

qTextArr: ['Fit as a fiddle,']
qText: Fit as a fiddle,
speaker: Mrs. Wilcox

qTextArr: ['So are we, and so was our car, which ran A1 as far as Ripon, but there\na wretched horse and cart which a fool of a driver--']
qText:
So are we, and so was our car, which ran A1 as far as Ripon, but there
a wretched horse and cart which a fool of a driver--
speaker: Mr. Wilcox

qTextArr: ['Miss Schlegel, our little outing must be for another day.']
qText: Miss Schlegel, our little outing must be for another day.
speaker: Mrs. Wilcox

qTextArr: ['I was saying that this fool of a driver, as the policeman himself\nadmits.']
qText:
I was saying that this fool of a driver, as the policeman himself
admits.
speaker: Mr. Wilcox

qTextArr: ['Another day, Mrs. Wilcox. Of course.']
qText: Another day, Mrs. Wilcox. Of course.
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr: ['--But as we ve insured against third party risks, it won t so much\nmatter--']
qText:
--But as we ve insured against third party risks, it won t so much
matter--
speaker: Mr. Wilcox

qTextArr: ['--Cart and car being practically at right angles--']
qText: --Cart and car being practically at right angles--
speaker: Evie

qTextArr: ['Henry, why\ndo people who have enough money try to get more money?']
qText:
Henry, why
do people who have enough money try to get more money?
speaker: Mrs. Wilcox

qTextArr: ['I am sure that if the mothers of various nations could meet,\nthere would be no more wars,']
qText:
I am sure that if the mothers of various nations could meet,
there would be no more wars,
speaker: Mrs. Wilcox

qTextArr: ['a more inward light,', 'not so much for myself as for\nbaby']
qText:
a more inward light, not so much for myself as for
baby
speaker: Mrs. Wilcox

qTextArr: ['Why didn t you tell me you knew of it?']
qText: Why didn t you tell me you knew of it?
speaker: Mr. Wilcox

qTextArr: ['I didn t want to, Henry--I might have been\nwrong--and every one hates illnesses.']
qText:
I didn t want to, Henry--I might have been
wrong--and every one hates illnesses.
speaker: Mrs. Wilcox

qTextArr: ['The post s come, father,']
qText: The post s come, father,
speaker: Evie

qTextArr: ['Thanks. Put it down.']
qText: Thanks. Put it down.
speaker: Mr. Wilcox

qTextArr: ['Has the breakfast been all right?']
qText: Has the breakfast been all right?
speaker: Evie

qTextArr: ['Yes, thanks.']
qText: Yes, thanks.
speaker: Mr. Wilcox

qTextArr: ['Charles says do you want the Times?']
qText: Charles says do you want the Times?
speaker: Evie

qTextArr: ['No, I ll read it later.']
qText: No, I ll read it later.
speaker: Mr. Wilcox

qTextArr: ['Ring if you want anything, father, won t you?']
qText: Ring if you want anything, father, won t you?
speaker: Evie

qTextArr: ['I ve all I want.']
qText: I ve all I want.
speaker: Mr. Wilcox

qTextArr: ['Father s eaten nothing,']
qText: Father s eaten nothing,
speaker: Evie

qTextArr: ['Look here father, you must eat, you know;']
qText: Look here father, you must eat, you know;
speaker: Charles Wilcox
refExp: he ran quickly upstairs opened the door and said

qTextArr: ['He s\ngoing to read his letters first, I think,', 'I dare\nsay he will go on with his breakfast afterwards.']
qText:
He s
going to read his letters first, I think, I dare
say he will go on with his breakfast afterwards.
speaker: Charles Wilcox

qTextArr: ['They had no business to be pollarding those elms\nyesterday,']
qText:
They had no business to be pollarding those elms
yesterday,
speaker: Charles Wilcox

qText:

refExp: She seized it and at once exclaimed

qTextArr:
['We know that it is not legally binding, Dolly,', 'We are aware of that. Legally, I
should be justified in tearing it up and throwing it into the fire. Of
course, my dear, we consider you as one of the family, but it will be
better if you do not interfere with what you do not understand.']
qText:
We know that it is not legally binding, Dolly, We are aware of that. Legally, I
should be justified in tearing it up and throwing it into the fire. Of
course, my dear, we consider you as one of the family, but it will be
better if you do not interfere with what you do not understand.
speaker: Mr. Wilcox

Ah, well! I shouldn t have

['The whole thing is unlike her,', 'If Miss Schlegel had

qText:
The whole thing is unlike her, If Miss Schlegel had
been poor, if she had wanted a house, I could understand it a little.
But she has a house of her own. Why should she want another? She

qText: That time may prove,

Presumably she knows--mother will have told her. She got twice or three

qText: What a horrid woman!

Why, she

qText:
I wish she would, I could
then deal with her.

qText:
So could I, I could deal
with her, if she comes, but she won t come. You re all a bit hard on
Miss Schlegel.
speaker: Mr. Wilcox

qTextArr: ['That Paul business was pretty scandalous, though.']
qText: That Paul business was pretty scandalous, though.
speaker: Charles Wilcox

qTextArr:
['I want no more of the Paul business, Charles, as I said at the time,
and besides, it is quite apart from this business. Margaret Schlegel has
been officious and tiresome during this terrible week, and we have
all suffered under her, but upon my soul she s honest. She s NOT in
collusion with the matron. I m absolutely certain of it. Nor was she
with the doctor, I m equally certain of that. She did not hide anything
from us, for up to that very afternoon she was as ignorant as we are.
She, like ourselves, was a dupe--']
qText:
I want no more of the Paul business, Charles, as I said at the time,
and besides, it is quite apart from this business. Margaret Schlegel has
been officious and tiresome during this terrible week, and we have
all suffered under her, but upon my soul she s honest. She s NOT in
collusion with the matron. I m absolutely certain of it. Nor was she
with the doctor, I m equally certain of that. She did not hide anything
from us, for up to that very afternoon she was as ignorant as we are.
She, like ourselves, was a dupe--
speaker: Mr. Wilcox
menEnts: [[['Paul'], ['Charles Wilcox'], ['Margaret'], ['Charles Wilcox', 'Evie', 'Mr. Wilcox', 'Dolly'], ['Margaret'], ['Margaret'], ['Margaret'], ['Margaret'], ['Charles Wilcox', 'Evie', 'Mr. Wilcox', 'Dolly'], ['Margaret'], ['Charles Wilcox', 'Evie', 'Mr. Wilcox', 'Dolly'], ['Margaret']]]

qTextArr:
['You see,
Charles, in her terrible pain your mother put us all in false positions.
Paul would not have left England, you would not have gone to Italy, nor
Evie and I into Yorkshire, if only we had known. Well, Miss Schlegel s
position has been equally false. Take all in all, she has not come out
of it badly.']
qText:
You see,
Charles, in her terrible pain your mother put us all in false positions.
Paul would not have left England, you would not have gone to Italy, nor
Evie and I into Yorkshire, if only we had known. Well, Miss Schlegel s
position has been equally false. Take all in all, she has not come out
of it badly.
speaker: Mr. Wilcox
menEnts: [[['Charles Wilcox'], ['Charles Wilcox'], ['Mrs. Wilcox'], ['Mrs. Wilcox'], ['Charles Wilcox', 'Evie', 'Mr. Wilcox', 'Dolly'], ['Paul'], ['Charles Wilcox'], ['Evie'], ['Charles Wilcox', 'Evie', 'Mr. Wilcox', 'Dolly'], ['Margaret'], ['Margaret']]]

qTextArr: ['But those chrysanthemums--']
qText: But those chrysanthemums--

qTextArr: ['Or coming down to the funeral at all--']
qText: Or coming down to the funeral at all--
speaker: Dolly

qTextArr:
['Why shouldn t she come down? She had the right to, and she stood far
back among the Hilton women. The flowers--certainly we should not have
sent such flowers, but they may have seemed the right thing to her,
Evie, and for all you know they may be the custom in Germany.']
qText:
Why shouldn t she come down? She had the right to, and she stood far
back among the Hilton women. The flowers--certainly we should not have
sent such flowers, but they may have seemed the right thing to her,
Evie, and for all you know they may be the custom in Germany.
speaker: Mr. Wilcox

qTextArr: ['Oh, I forget she isn t really English,', 'That would explain\na lot.']
qText:
Oh, I forget she isn t really English, That would explain
a lot.
speaker: Evie

qTextArr:
['She s a cosmopolitan,', 'I admit I m
rather down on cosmopolitans. My fault, doubtless. I cannot stand them,
and a German cosmopolitan is the limit. I think that s about all, isn t
it? I want to run down and see Chalkeley. A bicycle will do. And, by the
way, I wish you d speak to Crane some time. I m certain he s had my new
car out.']
qText:
She s a cosmopolitan, I admit I m
rather down on cosmopolitans. My fault, doubtless. I cannot stand them,
and a German cosmopolitan is the limit. I think that s about all, isn t
it? I want to run down and see Chalkeley. A bicycle will do. And, by the
way, I wish you d speak to Crane some time. I m certain he s had my new
car out.
speaker: Charles Wilcox

qTextArr: ['Has he done it any harm?']
qText: Has he done it any harm?
speaker: Mr. Wilcox

qText: No.
speaker: Charles Wilcox

qTextArr: ['In that case I shall let it pass. It s not worth while having a row.']
qText: In that case I shall let it pass. It s not worth while having a row.

qTextArr: ['loved superstition.']
qText: loved superstition.

qText: Oh, how lovely! That s the place for me!

qTextArr: ['I have a message, dear Helen,']
qText: I have a message, dear Helen,
speaker: Fraulein Mosebach

qTextArr:
['And there will even be some one for Tibby,', 'There now, Tibby, think of that; Frieda is saving up a little
girl for you, in pig-tails and white worsted stockings but the feet
of the stockings are pink as if the little girl had trodden in
strawberries. I ve talked too much. My head aches. Now you talk.']
qText:
And there will even be some one for Tibby, There now, Tibby, think of that; Frieda is saving up a little
girl for you, in pig-tails and white worsted stockings but the feet
of the stockings are pink as if the little girl had trodden in
strawberries. I ve talked too much. My head aches. Now you talk.

qTextArr: ['Helen, I told you about poor Mrs. Wilcox; that sad business?']
qText: Helen, I told you about poor Mrs. Wilcox; that sad business?
speaker: Margaret

qText: Yes.
speaker: Helen

qTextArr:
['I have had a correspondence with her son. He was winding up the estate,
and wrote to ask me whether his mother had wanted me to have anything.
I thought it good of him, considering I knew her so little. I said that
she had once spoken of giving me a Christmas present, but we both forgot
about it afterwards.']
qText:
I have had a correspondence with her son. He was winding up the estate,
and wrote to ask me whether his mother had wanted me to have anything.
I thought it good of him, considering I knew her so little. I said that
she had once spoken of giving me a Christmas present, but we both forgot
about it afterwards.
speaker: Margaret
menEnts: [[['Charles Wilcox'], ['Charles Wilcox'], ['Mrs. Wilcox'], ['Charles Wilcox'], ['Mrs. Wilcox'], ['Mrs. Wilcox', 'Margaret']]]

qTextArr: ['I hope Charles took the hint.']
qText: I hope Charles took the hint.
speaker: Helen

qTextArr:
['Yes--that is to say, her husband wrote later on, and thanked me for
being a little kind to her, and actually gave me her silver vinaigrette.
Don t you think that is extraordinarily generous? It has made me
like him very much. He hopes that this will not be the end of our
acquaintance, but that you and I will go and stop with Evie some time in
the future. I like Mr. Wilcox. He is taking up his work--rubber--it is
a big business. I gather he is launching out rather. Charles is in it,
too. Charles is married--a pretty little creature, but she doesn t seem
wise. They took on the flat, but now they have gone off to a house of
their own.']
qText:
Yes--that is to say, her husband wrote later on, and thanked me for
being a little kind to her, and actually gave me her silver vinaigrette.
Don t you think that is extraordinarily generous? It has made me
like him very much. He hopes that this will not be the end of our
acquaintance, but that you and I will go and stop with Evie some time in
the future. I like Mr. Wilcox. He is taking up his work--rubber--it is
a big business. I gather he is launching out rather. Charles is in it,
too. Charles is married--a pretty little creature, but she doesn t seem
wise. They took on the flat, but now they have gone off to a house of
their own.
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr: ['I was thinking of Mr. Vyse. He never strikes me as particularly happy.']
qText: I was thinking of Mr. Vyse. He never strikes me as particularly happy.

qText: Ye--es.
speaker: Tibby

qTextArr: ['But Mr. Vyse is rather a wretched, weedy man, don t you think? Then\nthere s Guy. That was a pitiful business. Besides']
qText:
But Mr. Vyse is rather a wretched, weedy man, don t you think? Then
there s Guy. That was a pitiful business. Besides
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr: ['every one is the better for some regular work.']
qText: every one is the better for some regular work.
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr:
['I shall stick to it,', 'I am not saying it
to educate you; it is what I really think. I believe that in the last
century men have developed the desire for work, and they must not starve
it. It s a new desire. It goes with a great deal that s bad, but in
itself it s good, and I hope that for women, too,  not to work  will
soon become as shocking as  not to be married  was a hundred years ago.']
qText:
I shall stick to it, I am not saying it
to educate you; it is what I really think. I believe that in the last
century men have developed the desire for work, and they must not starve
it. It s a new desire. It goes with a great deal that s bad, but in
itself it s good, and I hope that for women, too,  not to work  will
soon become as shocking as  not to be married  was a hundred years ago.
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr: ['I have no experience of this profound desire to which you allude,']
qText: I have no experience of this profound desire to which you allude,
speaker: Tibby

qTextArr: ['Then we ll leave the subject till you do. I m not going to rattle you\nround. Take your time. Only do think over the lives of the men you like\nmost, and see how they ve arranged them.']
qText:
Then we ll leave the subject till you do. I m not going to rattle you
round. Take your time. Only do think over the lives of the men you like
most, and see how they ve arranged them.
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr: ['I like Guy and Mr. Vyse most,']
qText: I like Guy and Mr. Vyse most,
speaker: Tibby

qTextArr: ['And don t think I m not serious because I don t use the traditional\narguments--making money, a sphere awaiting you, and so on--all of which\nare, for various reasons, cant.']
qText:
And don t think I m not serious because I don t use the traditional
arguments--making money, a sphere awaiting you, and so on--all of which
are, for various reasons, cant.
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr: ['I m only your sister.\nI haven t any authority over you, and I don t want to have any. Just\nto put before you what I think the Truth. You see']
qText:
I m only your sister.
I haven t any authority over you, and I don t want to have any. Just
to put before you what I think the Truth. You see
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr: ['in a few years we shall be\nthe same age practically, and I shall want you to help me. Men are so\nmuch nicer than women.']
qText:
in a few years we shall be
the same age practically, and I shall want you to help me. Men are so
much nicer than women.
speaker: Margaret

qText: Labouring under such a delusion, why do you not marry?

qText: I sometimes jolly well think I would if I got the chance.
speaker: Margaret

qText: Has nobody arst you?
