qTextArr: ['Tell me about them.']
qText: Tell me about them.
speaker: Tibby

qText: No.
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr: ['Tell me about your ninnies, then.']
qText: Tell me about your ninnies, then.
speaker: Tibby

qTextArr:
['They were men who had nothing better to do,', 'So take warning; you must
work, or else you must pretend to work, which is what I do. Work, work,
work if you d save your soul and your body. It is honestly a necessity,
dear boy. Look at the Wilcoxes, look at Mr. Pembroke. With all their
defects of temper and understanding, such men give me more pleasure than
many who are better equipped, and I think it is because they have worked
regularly and honestly.']
qText:
They were men who had nothing better to do, So take warning; you must
work, or else you must pretend to work, which is what I do. Work, work,
work if you d save your soul and your body. It is honestly a necessity,
dear boy. Look at the Wilcoxes, look at Mr. Pembroke. With all their
defects of temper and understanding, such men give me more pleasure than
many who are better equipped, and I think it is because they have worked
regularly and honestly.
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr: ['Spare me the Wilcoxes,']
qText: Spare me the Wilcoxes,
speaker: Tibby

qTextArr: ['I shall not. They are the right sort.']
qText: I shall not. They are the right sort.
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr: ['Oh, goodness me, Meg--!']
qText: Oh, goodness me, Meg--!
speaker: Tibby

qTextArr: ['Well, they re as near the right sort as you can imagine.']
qText: Well, they re as near the right sort as you can imagine.
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr: ['No, no--oh, no!']
qText: No, no--oh, no!
speaker: Tibby

qTextArr: ['I was thinking of the younger son, whom I once classed as a ninny,\nbut who came back so ill from Nigeria. He s gone out there again, Evie\nWilcox tells me--out to his duty.']
qText:
I was thinking of the younger son, whom I once classed as a ninny,
but who came back so ill from Nigeria. He s gone out there again, Evie
Wilcox tells me--out to his duty.
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr:
['He doesn t want the money, it is work he wants, though it is beastly
work--dull country, dishonest natives, an eternal fidget over fresh
water and food... A nation that can produce men of that sort may well be
proud. No wonder England has become an Empire.']
qText:
He doesn t want the money, it is work he wants, though it is beastly
work--dull country, dishonest natives, an eternal fidget over fresh
water and food... A nation that can produce men of that sort may well be
proud. No wonder England has become an Empire.
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr: ['EMPIRE!']
qText: EMPIRE!
speaker: Tibby

qTextArr:
['I can t bother over results,', 'They are
too difficult for me. I can only look at the men. An Empire bores me,
so far, but I can appreciate the heroism that builds it up. London
bores me, but what thousands of splendid people are labouring to make
London--']
qText:
I can t bother over results, They are
too difficult for me. I can only look at the men. An Empire bores me,
so far, but I can appreciate the heroism that builds it up. London
bores me, but what thousands of splendid people are labouring to make
London--
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr: ['What it is,']
qText: What it is,
speaker: Tibby

qTextArr: ['What it is, worse luck. I want activity without civilisation. How\nparadoxical! Yet I expect that is what we shall find in heaven.']
qText:
What it is, worse luck. I want activity without civilisation. How
paradoxical! Yet I expect that is what we shall find in heaven.
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr: ['And I,', 'want civilisation without activity, which, I\nexpect, is what we shall find in the other place.']
qText:
And I, want civilisation without activity, which, I
expect, is what we shall find in the other place.
speaker: Tibby

qTextArr: ['You needn t go as far as the other place, Tibbikins, if you want that.\nYou can find it at Oxford.']
qText:
You needn t go as far as the other place, Tibbikins, if you want that.
You can find it at Oxford.
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr: ['Stupid--']
qText: Stupid--
speaker: Tibby

qTextArr:
['If I m stupid, get me back to the house-hunting. I ll even live in
Oxford if you like--North Oxford. I ll live anywhere except Bournemouth,
Torquay, and Cheltenham. Oh yes, or Ilfracombe and Swanage and Tunbridge
Wells and Surbiton and Bedford. There on no account.']
qText:
If I m stupid, get me back to the house-hunting. I ll even live in
Oxford if you like--North Oxford. I ll live anywhere except Bournemouth,
Torquay, and Cheltenham. Oh yes, or Ilfracombe and Swanage and Tunbridge
Wells and Surbiton and Bedford. There on no account.
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr: ['London, then.']
qText: London, then.
speaker: Tibby

qTextArr:
['I agree, but Helen rather wants to get away from London. However,
there s no reason we shouldn t have a house in the country and also a
flat in town, provided we all stick together and contribute. Though of
course--Oh, how one does maunder on and to think, to think of the people
who are really poor. How do they live? Not to move about the world would
kill me.']
qText:
I agree, but Helen rather wants to get away from London. However,
there s no reason we shouldn t have a house in the country and also a
flat in town, provided we all stick together and contribute. Though of
course--Oh, how one does maunder on and to think, to think of the people
who are really poor. How do they live? Not to move about the world would
kill me.
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr: ['Oh, my dears, what do you think? You ll never guess. A woman s been\nhere asking me for her husband. Her WHAT?']
qText:
Oh, my dears, what do you think? You ll never guess. A woman s been
here asking me for her husband. Her WHAT?
speaker: Helen

qTextArr: ['Yes, for her husband, and it really is so.']
qText: Yes, for her husband, and it really is so.
speaker: Helen

qTextArr: ['Not anything to do with Bracknell?']
qText: Not anything to do with Bracknell?
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr: ['I offered Bracknell, and he was rejected. So was Tibby. (Cheer up,\nTibby!) It s no one we know. I said,']
qText:
I offered Bracknell, and he was rejected. So was Tibby. (Cheer up,
Tibby!) It s no one we know. I said,
speaker: Helen

qTextArr: ['Oh, and she so magnificently dressed\nand tinkling like a chandelier.']
qText:
Oh, and she so magnificently dressed
and tinkling like a chandelier.
speaker: Helen

qTextArr: ['Now, Helen, what did really happen?']
qText: Now, Helen, what did really happen?
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr: ['What I say. I was, as it were, orating my speech. Annie opens the door\nlike a fool, and shows a female straight in on me, with my mouth open.\nThen we began--very civilly.']
qText:
What I say. I was, as it were, orating my speech. Annie opens the door
like a fool, and shows a female straight in on me, with my mouth open.
Then we began--very civilly.
speaker: Helen

qTextArr: ['No--how unjust one is. She said  whom,  not  what. \nShe got it perfectly. So I said,']
qText:
No--how unjust one is. She said  whom,  not  what. 
She got it perfectly. So I said,
speaker: Helen

qTextArr: ['and she said,']
qText: and she said,
speaker: Helen

qTextArr: ['and there we were.']
qText: and there we were.
speaker: Helen

qText: Lan?
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr: ['Lan or Len. We were not nice about our vowels. Lanoline.']
qText: Lan or Len. We were not nice about our vowels. Lanoline.
speaker: Helen

qTextArr: ['But what an extraordinary--']
qText: But what an extraordinary--
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr: ['I said,  My good Mrs. Lanoline, we have some grave misunderstanding\nhere. Beautiful as I am, my modesty is even more remarkable than my\nbeauty, and never, never has Mr. Lanoline rested his eyes on mine.']
qText:
I said,  My good Mrs. Lanoline, we have some grave misunderstanding
here. Beautiful as I am, my modesty is even more remarkable than my
beauty, and never, never has Mr. Lanoline rested his eyes on mine.
speaker: Helen

qTextArr: ['I hope you were pleased,']
qText: I hope you were pleased,
speaker: Tibby

qTextArr:
['Of course,', 'A perfectly delightful experience.
Oh, Mrs. Lanoline s a dear--she asked for a husband as if he were
an umbrella. She mislaid him Saturday afternoon--and for a long time
suffered no inconvenience. But all night, and all this morning her
apprehensions grew. Breakfast didn t seem the same--no, no more did
lunch, and so she strolled up to 2 Wickham Place as being the most
likely place for the missing article.']
qText:
Of course, A perfectly delightful experience.
Oh, Mrs. Lanoline s a dear--she asked for a husband as if he were
an umbrella. She mislaid him Saturday afternoon--and for a long time
suffered no inconvenience. But all night, and all this morning her
apprehensions grew. Breakfast didn t seem the same--no, no more did
lunch, and so she strolled up to 2 Wickham Place as being the most
likely place for the missing article.
speaker: Helen

qTextArr: ['But how on earth--']
qText: But how on earth--
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr: ['Don t begin how on earthing.']
qText: Don t begin how on earthing.
speaker: Helen

qTextArr:
['she kept repeating,
not uncivilly, but with extreme gloom. In vain I asked her what she did
know. Some knew what others knew, and others didn t, and then others
again had better be careful. Oh dear, she was incompetent! She had
a face like a silkworm, and the dining-room reeks of orris-root. We
chatted pleasantly a little about husbands, and I wondered where hers
was too, and advised her to go to the police. She thanked me. We agreed
that Mr. Lanoline s a notty, notty man, and hasn t no business to go
on the lardy-da. But I think she suspected me up to the last. Bags I
writing to Aunt Juley about this. Now, Meg, remember--bags I.']
qText:
she kept repeating,
not uncivilly, but with extreme gloom. In vain I asked her what she did
know. Some knew what others knew, and others didn t, and then others
again had better be careful. Oh dear, she was incompetent! She had
a face like a silkworm, and the dining-room reeks of orris-root. We
chatted pleasantly a little about husbands, and I wondered where hers
was too, and advised her to go to the police. She thanked me. We agreed
that Mr. Lanoline s a notty, notty man, and hasn t no business to go
on the lardy-da. But I think she suspected me up to the last. Bags I
writing to Aunt Juley about this. Now, Meg, remember--bags I.
speaker: Helen
menEnts: [[['Mrs. Bast'], ['Mrs. Bast'], ['Mrs. Bast'], ['Mrs. Bast'], ['Mrs. Bast'], ['Helen', 'Mrs. Bast'], ['Mrs. Bast'], ['Mrs. Bast'], ['Mrs. Bast'], ['Helen', 'Mrs. Bast'], ['Leonard'], ['Mrs. Bast'], ['Aunt Juley'], ['Margaret']]]

qTextArr: ['Bag it by all means,', 'I m\nnot sure that this is so funny, Helen. It means some horrible volcano\nsmoking somewhere, doesn t it?']
qText:
Bag it by all means, I m
not sure that this is so funny, Helen. It means some horrible volcano
smoking somewhere, doesn t it?
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr: ['I don t think so--she doesn t really mind. The admirable creature isn t\ncapable of tragedy.']
qText:
I don t think so--she doesn t really mind. The admirable creature isn t
capable of tragedy.
speaker: Helen

qTextArr: ['Her husband may be, though,']
qText: Her husband may be, though,
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr: ['Oh no, not likely. No one capable of tragedy could have married Mrs.\nLanoline.']
qText:
Oh no, not likely. No one capable of tragedy could have married Mrs.
Lanoline.
speaker: Helen

qTextArr: ['Was she pretty?']
qText: Was she pretty?
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr: ['Her figure may have been good once.']
qText: Her figure may have been good once.
speaker: Helen

qTextArr: ['Tibby and I have again been wondering where we ll live next September,']
qText: Tibby and I have again been wondering where we ll live next September,
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr: ['Tibby had better first wonder what he ll do,']
qText: Tibby had better first wonder what he ll do,
speaker: Helen

qTextArr: ['Cheers, children!', 'It s Mrs. Lanoline.']
qText: Cheers, children! It s Mrs. Lanoline.
speaker: Helen

qTextArr: ['You wouldn t remember giving me this, Miss Schlegel?']
qText: You wouldn t remember giving me this, Miss Schlegel?
speaker: Leonard

qTextArr: ['No; I can t say I do.']
qText: No; I can t say I do.
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr: ['Well, that was how it happened, you see.']
qText: Well, that was how it happened, you see.
speaker: Leonard

qTextArr: ['Where did we meet, Mr. Bast? For the minute I don t remember.']
qText: Where did we meet, Mr. Bast? For the minute I don t remember.
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr: ['It was a concert at the Queen s Hall. I think you will recollect,', 'when I tell you that it included a performance of\nthe Fifth Symphony of Beethoven.']
qText:
It was a concert at the Queen s Hall. I think you will recollect, when I tell you that it included a performance of
the Fifth Symphony of Beethoven.
speaker: Leonard

qTextArr: ['We hear the Fifth practically every time it s done, so I m not sure--do\nyou remember, Helen?']
qText:
We hear the Fifth practically every time it s done, so I m not sure--do
you remember, Helen?
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr: ['Was it the time the sandy cat walked round the balustrade?']
qText: Was it the time the sandy cat walked round the balustrade?
speaker: Helen

qTextArr: ['Then I don t remember. That s the only Beethoven I ever remember\nspecially.']
qText:
Then I don t remember. That s the only Beethoven I ever remember
specially.
speaker: Helen

qTextArr: ['And you, if I may say so, took away my umbrella, inadvertently of\ncourse.']
qText:
And you, if I may say so, took away my umbrella, inadvertently of
course.
speaker: Leonard

qTextArr: ['Likely enough,', 'for I steal umbrellas even oftener than\nI hear Beethoven. Did you get it back?']
qText:
Likely enough, for I steal umbrellas even oftener than
I hear Beethoven. Did you get it back?
speaker: Helen

qTextArr: ['Yes, thank you, Miss Schlegel.']
qText: Yes, thank you, Miss Schlegel.
speaker: Leonard

qTextArr: ['The mistake arose out of my card, did it?']
qText: The mistake arose out of my card, did it?
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr: ['Yes, the mistake arose--it was a mistake.']
qText: Yes, the mistake arose--it was a mistake.
speaker: Leonard

qTextArr: ['The lady who called here yesterday thought that you were calling too,\nand that she could find you?']
qText:
The lady who called here yesterday thought that you were calling too,
and that she could find you?
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr: ['That s so, calling too--a mistake.']
qText: That s so, calling too--a mistake.
speaker: Leonard

qTextArr: ['Then why--?']
qText: Then why--?
speaker: Helen

qTextArr:
['I said to my wife,', 'I said to Mrs. Bast,', 'and Mrs. Bast said to me,', 'While I was gone, however, she wanted me on important business, and
thought I had come here, owing to the card, and so came after me, and I
beg to tender my apologies, and hers as well, for any inconvenience we
may have inadvertently caused you.']
qText:
I said to my wife, I said to Mrs. Bast, and Mrs. Bast said to me, While I was gone, however, she wanted me on important business, and
thought I had come here, owing to the card, and so came after me, and I
beg to tender my apologies, and hers as well, for any inconvenience we
may have inadvertently caused you.
speaker: Leonard

qTextArr: ['No inconvenience,', 'but I still don t understand.']
qText: No inconvenience, but I still don t understand.
speaker: Helen

qTextArr: ['I still\ndon t understand. When did you say you paid this call?']
qText:
I still
don t understand. When did you say you paid this call?
speaker: Helen

qTextArr: ['Call? What call?']
qText: Call? What call?
speaker: Leonard

qTextArr: ['This afternoon call.']
qText: This afternoon call.
speaker: Helen

qTextArr: ['In the afternoon, of course!']
qText: In the afternoon, of course!
speaker: Leonard

qTextArr: ['Saturday\nafternoon or Sunday afternoon?']
qText:
Saturday
afternoon or Sunday afternoon?
speaker: Tibby

qTextArr: ['S--Saturday.']
qText: S--Saturday.
speaker: Leonard

qTextArr: ['Really!', 'and you were still calling on Sunday, when your\nwife came here. A long visit.']
qText:
Really! and you were still calling on Sunday, when your
wife came here. A long visit.
speaker: Helen

qTextArr: ['I don t call that fair,', 'I know what you mean, and it isn t so.']
qText: I don t call that fair, I know what you mean, and it isn t so.
speaker: Leonard

qTextArr: ['Oh, don t let us mind,']
qText: Oh, don t let us mind,
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr: ['It was something else,', 'I was somewhere else to what you think, so there!']
qText: It was something else, I was somewhere else to what you think, so there!
speaker: Leonard

qTextArr: ['It was good of you to come and explain,', 'The rest is\nnaturally no concern of ours.']
qText:
It was good of you to come and explain, The rest is
naturally no concern of ours.
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr: ['Yes, but I want--I wanted--have you ever read The Ordeal of Richard\nFeverel?']
qText:
Yes, but I want--I wanted--have you ever read The Ordeal of Richard
Feverel?
speaker: Leonard

qTextArr: ['It s a beautiful book. I wanted to get back to the earth, don t you\nsee, like Richard does in the end. Or have you ever read Stevenson s\nPrince Otto?']
qText:
It s a beautiful book. I wanted to get back to the earth, don t you
see, like Richard does in the end. Or have you ever read Stevenson s
Prince Otto?
speaker: Leonard

qTextArr: ['That s another beautiful book. You get back to the earth in that. I\nwanted--']
qText:
That s another beautiful book. You get back to the earth in that. I
wanted--
speaker: Leonard

qTextArr: ['I walked all the Saturday night,', 'I walked.']
qText: I walked all the Saturday night, I walked.
speaker: Leonard

qTextArr: ['No doubt it s another beautiful book, but I d rather hear\nabout your road.']
qText:
No doubt it s another beautiful book, but I d rather hear
about your road.
speaker: Helen

qTextArr: ['Oh, I walked.']
qText: Oh, I walked.
speaker: Leonard

qTextArr: ['How far?']
qText: How far?
speaker: Helen

qTextArr: ['I don t know, nor for how long. It got too dark to see my watch.']
qText: I don t know, nor for how long. It got too dark to see my watch.
speaker: Leonard

qTextArr: ['Were you walking alone, may I ask?']
qText: Were you walking alone, may I ask?
speaker: Helen

qTextArr:
['Yes,', 'but we d been talking it over at
the office. There s been a lot of talk at the office lately about these
things. The fellows there said one steers by the Pole Star, and I looked
it up in the celestial atlas, but once out of doors everything gets so
mixed.']
qText:
Yes, but we d been talking it over at
the office. There s been a lot of talk at the office lately about these
things. The fellows there said one steers by the Pole Star, and I looked
it up in the celestial atlas, but once out of doors everything gets so
mixed.
speaker: Leonard

qTextArr: ['Don t talk to me about the Pole Star,', 'I know its little ways. It goes round and round,\nand you go round after it.']
qText:
Don t talk to me about the Pole Star, I know its little ways. It goes round and round,
and you go round after it.
speaker: Helen

qTextArr: ['Well, I lost it entirely. First of all the street lamps, then the\ntrees, and towards morning it got cloudy.']
qText:
Well, I lost it entirely. First of all the street lamps, then the
trees, and towards morning it got cloudy.
speaker: Leonard

qTextArr: ['Where did you start from?', 'Do tell us more.']
qText: Where did you start from? Do tell us more.
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr:
['I took the Underground to Wimbledon. As I came out of the office I said
to myself,  I must have a walk once in a way. If I don t take this walk
now, I shall never take it.  I had a bit of dinner at Wimbledon, and
then--']
qText:
I took the Underground to Wimbledon. As I came out of the office I said
to myself,  I must have a walk once in a way. If I don t take this walk
now, I shall never take it.  I had a bit of dinner at Wimbledon, and
then--
speaker: Leonard

qTextArr: ['But not good country there, is it?']
qText: But not good country there, is it?
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr: ['It was gas-lamps for hours. Still, I had all the night, and being out\nwas the great thing. I did get into woods, too, presently.']
qText:
It was gas-lamps for hours. Still, I had all the night, and being out
was the great thing. I did get into woods, too, presently.
speaker: Leonard

qTextArr: ['Yes, go on,']
qText: Yes, go on,
speaker: Helen

qTextArr: ['You ve no idea how difficult uneven ground is when it s dark.']
qText: You ve no idea how difficult uneven ground is when it s dark.
speaker: Leonard

qTextArr: ['Did you actually go off the roads?']
qText: Did you actually go off the roads?
speaker: Helen

qTextArr: ['Oh yes. I always meant to go off the roads, but the worst of it is that\nit s more difficult to find one s way.']
qText:
Oh yes. I always meant to go off the roads, but the worst of it is that
it s more difficult to find one s way.
speaker: Leonard

qTextArr: ['Mr. Bast, you re a born adventurer,', 'No professional\nathlete would have attempted what you ve done. It s a wonder your walk\ndidn t end in a broken neck. Whatever did your wife say?']
qText:
Mr. Bast, you re a born adventurer, No professional
athlete would have attempted what you ve done. It s a wonder your walk
didn t end in a broken neck. Whatever did your wife say?
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr: ['Professional athletes never move without lanterns and compasses,', 'Besides, they can t walk. It tires them. Go on.']
qText: Professional athletes never move without lanterns and compasses, Besides, they can t walk. It tires them. Go on.
speaker: Helen

qTextArr: ['I felt like R. L. S. You probably remember how in Virginibus.']
qText: I felt like R. L. S. You probably remember how in Virginibus.
speaker: Leonard

qTextArr: ['Yes, but the wood. This  ere wood. How did you get out of it?']
qText: Yes, but the wood. This  ere wood. How did you get out of it?
speaker: Helen

qTextArr:
['I managed one wood, and found a road the other side which went a good
bit uphill. I rather fancy it was those North Downs, for the road went
off into grass, and I got into another wood. That was awful, with gorse
bushes. I did wish I d never come, but suddenly it got light--just while
I seemed going under one tree. Then I found a road down to a station,
and took the first train I could back to London.']
qText:
I managed one wood, and found a road the other side which went a good
bit uphill. I rather fancy it was those North Downs, for the road went
off into grass, and I got into another wood. That was awful, with gorse
bushes. I did wish I d never come, but suddenly it got light--just while
I seemed going under one tree. Then I found a road down to a station,
and took the first train I could back to London.
speaker: Leonard

qTextArr: ['But was the dawn wonderful?']
qText: But was the dawn wonderful?
speaker: Helen

qText: No.
speaker: Leonard

qTextArr: ['The dawn was only grey, it was nothing to mention.']
qText: The dawn was only grey, it was nothing to mention.
speaker: Leonard

qTextArr: ['Just a grey evening turned upside down. I know.']
qText: Just a grey evening turned upside down. I know.
speaker: Helen

qTextArr:
['--and I was too tired to lift up my head to look at it, and so cold
too. I m glad I did it, and yet at the time it bored me more than I can
say. And besides--you can believe me or not as you choose--I was very
hungry. That dinner at Wimbledon--I meant it to last me all night
like other dinners. I never thought that walking would make such a
difference. Why, when you re walking you want, as it were, a breakfast
and luncheon and tea during the night as well, and I d nothing but a
packet of Woodbines. Lord, I did feel bad! Looking back, it wasn t what
you may call enjoyment. It was more a case of sticking to it. I did
stick. I--I was determined. Oh, hang it all! what s the good--I mean,
the good of living in a room for ever? There one goes on day after day,
same old game, same up and down to town, until you forget there is any
other game. You ought to see once in a way what s going on outside, if
it s only nothing particular after all.']
qText:
--and I was too tired to lift up my head to look at it, and so cold
too. I m glad I did it, and yet at the time it bored me more than I can
say. And besides--you can believe me or not as you choose--I was very
hungry. That dinner at Wimbledon--I meant it to last me all night
like other dinners. I never thought that walking would make such a
difference. Why, when you re walking you want, as it were, a breakfast
and luncheon and tea during the night as well, and I d nothing but a
packet of Woodbines. Lord, I did feel bad! Looking back, it wasn t what
you may call enjoyment. It was more a case of sticking to it. I did
stick. I--I was determined. Oh, hang it all! what s the good--I mean,
the good of living in a room for ever? There one goes on day after day,
same old game, same up and down to town, until you forget there is any
other game. You ought to see once in a way what s going on outside, if
it s only nothing particular after all.
speaker: Leonard

qTextArr: ['I should just think you ought,']
qText: I should just think you ought,
speaker: Helen

qTextArr: ['Curious it should all come about from reading something of Richard\nJefferies.']
qText:
Curious it should all come about from reading something of Richard
Jefferies.
speaker: Leonard

qTextArr: ['Excuse me, Mr. Bast, but you re wrong there. It didn t. It came from\nsomething far greater.']
qText:
Excuse me, Mr. Bast, but you re wrong there. It didn t. It came from
something far greater.
speaker: Helen

qTextArr: ['Then you don t think I was foolish?']
qText: Then you don t think I was foolish?
speaker: Leonard

qTextArr: ['Heavens, no!']
qText: Heavens, no!
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr: ['Heaven help us if we do!']
qText: Heaven help us if we do!
speaker: Helen

qTextArr: ['I m very glad you say that. Now, my wife would never understand--not if\nI explained for days.']
qText:
I m very glad you say that. Now, my wife would never understand--not if
I explained for days.
speaker: Leonard

qTextArr: ['No, it wasn t foolish!', 'You ve pushed\nback the boundaries; I think it splendid of you.']
qText:
No, it wasn t foolish! You ve pushed
back the boundaries; I think it splendid of you.
speaker: Helen

qTextArr: ['You ve not been content to dream as we have--']
qText: You ve not been content to dream as we have--
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr: ['Though we have walked, too--']
qText: Though we have walked, too--
speaker: Helen

qTextArr: ['I must show you a picture upstairs--']
qText: I must show you a picture upstairs--
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr: ['Oh, bother, not to say dash--I had forgotten we were dining out; but\ndo, do, come round again and have a talk.']
qText:
Oh, bother, not to say dash--I had forgotten we were dining out; but
do, do, come round again and have a talk.
speaker: Helen

qTextArr: ['Yes, you must--do,']
qText: Yes, you must--do,
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr: ['No, I shall not. It s better\nlike this.']
qText:
No, I shall not. It s better
like this.
speaker: Leonard

qTextArr: ['Why better?']
qText: Why better?
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr:
['No, it is better not to risk a second interview. I shall always look
back on this talk with you as one of the finest things in my life.
Really. I mean this. We can never repeat. It has done me real good, and
there we had better leave it.']
qText:
No, it is better not to risk a second interview. I shall always look
back on this talk with you as one of the finest things in my life.
Really. I mean this. We can never repeat. It has done me real good, and
there we had better leave it.
speaker: Leonard

qTextArr: ['That s rather a sad view of life, surely.']
qText: That s rather a sad view of life, surely.
speaker: Helen

qTextArr: ['Things so often get spoiled.']
qText: Things so often get spoiled.
speaker: Leonard

qTextArr: ['I know,', 'but people don t.']
qText: I know, but people don t.
speaker: Helen

qTextArr: ['Go, then; perhaps you know\nbest; but never forget you re better than Jefferies.']
qText:
Go, then; perhaps you know
best; but never forget you re better than Jefferies.
speaker: Helen

qTextArr: ['What s\nthat card, eh?']
qText:
What s
that card, eh?
speaker: Jacky
refExp: Jacky found it and then began

qTextArr: ['Yes, don t you wish you knew what that card was?']
qText: Yes, don t you wish you knew what that card was?
speaker: Leonard

qTextArr: ['Len,\nwho s Miss Schlegel?']
qText:
Len,
who s Miss Schlegel?
speaker: Jacky

qTextArr: ['Well, at all events, she\ndoesn t know about that card. Yah! done her there!']
qText:
Well, at all events, she
doesn t know about that card. Yah! done her there!
speaker: Leonard

qTextArr: ['Well?', 'I know\nwhere you ve been, but you don t know where I ve been.']
qText:
Well? I know
where you ve been, but you don t know where I ve been.
speaker: Leonard

qTextArr: ['Len, I do think you might explain,']
qText: Len, I do think you might explain,
speaker: Jacky

qTextArr:
['Order, order, Miss Schlegel!', 'You are
here, I understand, to advise me in the interests of the Society for the
Preservation of Places of Historic Interest or Natural Beauty. I cannot
have you speaking out of your role. It makes my poor head go round, and
I think you forget that I am very ill.']
qText:
Order, order, Miss Schlegel! You are
here, I understand, to advise me in the interests of the Society for the
Preservation of Places of Historic Interest or Natural Beauty. I cannot
have you speaking out of your role. It makes my poor head go round, and
I think you forget that I am very ill.
speaker: The Reader Of The Paper
refExp: said the reader of the paper

qTextArr: ['Your head won t go round if only you ll listen to my argument,', 'Why not give him the money itself? You re supposed to have\nabout thirty thousand a year.']
qText:
Your head won t go round if only you ll listen to my argument, Why not give him the money itself? You re supposed to have
about thirty thousand a year.
speaker: Margaret
addressee: ['The Reader Of The Paper', 'An Earnest Girl', 'Helen']
menEnts: [[['The Reader Of The Paper'], ['The Reader Of The Paper']], [['The Reader Of The Paper']]]

qTextArr: ['Have I? I thought I had a million.']
qText: Have I? I thought I had a million.
speaker: The Reader Of The Paper

qTextArr: ['Wasn t a million your capital? Dear me! we ought to have settled that.\nStill, it doesn t matter. Whatever you ve got, I order you to give as\nmany poor men as you can three hundred a year each.']
qText:
Wasn t a million your capital? Dear me! we ought to have settled that.
Still, it doesn t matter. Whatever you ve got, I order you to give as
many poor men as you can three hundred a year each.
speaker: Margaret
addressee: ['The Reader Of The Paper', 'An Earnest Girl', 'Helen']
menEnts: [[['The Reader Of The Paper'], ['The Reader Of The Paper'], ['The Reader Of The Paper'], ['The Reader Of The Paper']]]

qTextArr: ['But that would be pauperising them,']
qText: But that would be pauperising them,
speaker: An Earnest Girl

qTextArr:
['Not if you gave them so much. A big windfall would not pauperise a man.
It is these little driblets, distributed among too many, that do the
harm. Money s educational. It s far more educational than the things
it buys.', 'In a sense,', 'Well, isn t the most civilized thing going, the man
who has learnt to wear his income properly?']
qText:
Not if you gave them so much. A big windfall would not pauperise a man.
It is these little driblets, distributed among too many, that do the
harm. Money s educational. It s far more educational than the things
it buys. In a sense, Well, isn t the most civilized thing going, the man
who has learnt to wear his income properly?
speaker: Margaret
addressee: ['The Reader Of The Paper', 'An Earnest Girl', 'Helen']

qTextArr:
['Give them a chance. Give them money. Don t dole them out poetry-books
and railway-tickets like babies. Give them the wherewithal to buy these
things. When your Socialism comes it may be different, and we may think
in terms of commodities instead of cash. Till it comes give people
cash, for it is the warp of civilisation, whatever the woof may be. The
imagination ought to play upon money and realise it vividly, for it s
the--the second most important thing in the world. It is so slurred over
and hushed up, there is so little clear thinking--oh, political economy,
of course, but so few of us think clearly about our own private incomes,
and admit that independent thoughts are in nine cases out of ten the
result of independent means. Money: give Mr. Bast money, and don t
bother about his ideals. He ll pick up those for himself.']
qText:
Give them a chance. Give them money. Don t dole them out poetry-books
and railway-tickets like babies. Give them the wherewithal to buy these
things. When your Socialism comes it may be different, and we may think
in terms of commodities instead of cash. Till it comes give people
cash, for it is the warp of civilisation, whatever the woof may be. The
imagination ought to play upon money and realise it vividly, for it s
the--the second most important thing in the world. It is so slurred over
and hushed up, there is so little clear thinking--oh, political economy,
of course, but so few of us think clearly about our own private incomes,
and admit that independent thoughts are in nine cases out of ten the
result of independent means. Money: give Mr. Bast money, and don t
bother about his ideals. He ll pick up those for himself.
speaker: Margaret
addressee: ['The Reader Of The Paper', 'An Earnest Girl', 'Helen']
menEnts: [[['An Earnest Girl'], ['An Earnest Girl', 'Margaret', 'Helen', 'The Reader Of The Paper'], ['An Earnest Girl', 'Margaret', 'Helen', 'The Reader Of The Paper'], ['Leonard'], ['Leonard'], ['Leonard']]]

qTextArr: ['Nothing, but he would not gain his soul until\nhe had gained a little of the world.']
qText:
Nothing, but he would not gain his soul until
he had gained a little of the world.
speaker: Margaret
addressee: ['The Reader Of The Paper', 'An Earnest Girl', 'Helen']

qTextArr: ['personal\nsupervision and mutual help,']
qText:
personal
supervision and mutual help,

qTextArr: ['Cold?']
qText: Cold?
speaker: Margaret

qText: No.
speaker: Helen

qTextArr: ['Tired?']
qText: Tired?
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr: ['Doesn t matter.']
qText: Doesn t matter.
speaker: Helen

qTextArr: ['I say, Helen--']
qText: I say, Helen--
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr: ['Well?']
qText: Well?
speaker: Helen

qTextArr: ['Are we really going to follow up Mr. Bast?']
qText: Are we really going to follow up Mr. Bast?
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr: ['I don t know.']
qText: I don t know.
speaker: Helen

qTextArr: ['I think we won t.']
qText: I think we won t.
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr: ['As you like.']
qText: As you like.
speaker: Helen

qTextArr:
['It s no good, I think, unless you really mean to know people. The
discussion brought that home to me. We got on well enough with him in a
spirit of excitement, but think of rational intercourse. We mustn t play
at friendship. No, it s no good.']
qText:
It s no good, I think, unless you really mean to know people. The
discussion brought that home to me. We got on well enough with him in a
spirit of excitement, but think of rational intercourse. We mustn t play
at friendship. No, it s no good.
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr: ['There s Mrs. Lanoline, too,', 'So dull.']
qText: There s Mrs. Lanoline, too, So dull.
speaker: Helen

qTextArr: ['Just so, and possibly worse than dull.']
qText: Just so, and possibly worse than dull.
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr: ['I should like to know how he got hold of your card.']
qText: I should like to know how he got hold of your card.
speaker: Helen

qTextArr: ['But he said--something about a concert and an umbrella.']
qText: But he said--something about a concert and an umbrella.
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr: ['Then did the card see the wife--']
qText: Then did the card see the wife--
speaker: Helen

qTextArr: ['Helen, come to bed.']
qText: Helen, come to bed.
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr: ['No, just a little longer, it is so beautiful. Tell me; oh yes; did you\nsay money is the warp of the world?']
qText:
No, just a little longer, it is so beautiful. Tell me; oh yes; did you
say money is the warp of the world?
speaker: Helen

qText: Yes.
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr: ['Then what s the woof?']
qText: Then what s the woof?
speaker: Helen

qTextArr: ['Very much what one chooses,', 'It s something that isn t\nmoney--one can t say more.']
qText:
Very much what one chooses, It s something that isn t
money--one can t say more.
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr: ['Walking at night?']
qText: Walking at night?
speaker: Helen

qTextArr: ['Probably.']
qText: Probably.
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr: ['For Tibby, Oxford?']
qText: For Tibby, Oxford?
speaker: Helen

qTextArr: ['It seems so.']
qText: It seems so.
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr: ['For you?']
qText: For you?
speaker: Helen

qTextArr: ['Now that we have to leave Wickham Place, I begin to think it s that.\nFor Mrs. Wilcox it was certainly Howards End.']
qText:
Now that we have to leave Wickham Place, I begin to think it s that.
For Mrs. Wilcox it was certainly Howards End.
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr: ['It is sad to suppose that places may ever be more important than\npeople,']
qText:
It is sad to suppose that places may ever be more important than
people,
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr: ['Why, Meg? They re so much nicer generally. I d rather think of that\nforester s house in Pomerania than of the fat Herr Forstmeister who\nlived in it.']
qText:
Why, Meg? They re so much nicer generally. I d rather think of that
forester s house in Pomerania than of the fat Herr Forstmeister who
lived in it.
speaker: Helen

qTextArr:
['I believe we shall come to care about people less and less, Helen. The
more people one knows the easier it becomes to replace them. It s one
of the curses of London. I quite expect to end my life caring most for a
place.']
qText:
I believe we shall come to care about people less and less, Helen. The
more people one knows the easier it becomes to replace them. It s one
of the curses of London. I quite expect to end my life caring most for a
place.
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr: ['How do you do?', 'I thought I recognised your voices. Whatever\nare you both doing down here?']
qText:
How do you do? I thought I recognised your voices. Whatever
are you both doing down here?
speaker: Henry

qTextArr: ['What an age it is since I ve seen you, Mr. Wilcox. I met Evie in the\nTube, though, lately. I hope you have good news of your son.']
qText:
What an age it is since I ve seen you, Mr. Wilcox. I met Evie in the
Tube, though, lately. I hope you have good news of your son.
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr: ['Paul?', 'Oh, Paul s all right. We had a line from Madeira. He ll\nbe at work again by now.']
qText:
Paul? Oh, Paul s all right. We had a line from Madeira. He ll
be at work again by now.
speaker: Henry

qText: Ugh--
speaker: Helen

qTextArr: ['I beg your pardon?']
qText: I beg your pardon?
speaker: Henry

qTextArr: ['Isn t the climate of Nigeria too horrible?']
qText: Isn t the climate of Nigeria too horrible?
speaker: Helen

qTextArr:
['Some one s got to go,', 'England will never keep her
trade overseas unless she is prepared to make sacrifices. Unless we get
firm in West Africa, Ger--untold complications may follow. Now tell me
all your news.']
qText:
Some one s got to go, England will never keep her
trade overseas unless she is prepared to make sacrifices. Unless we get
firm in West Africa, Ger--untold complications may follow. Now tell me
all your news.
speaker: Henry

qTextArr:
['Oh, we ve had a splendid evening,', 'We belong to a kind of club that reads papers,
Margaret and I--all women, but there is a discussion after. This evening
it was on how one ought to leave one s money--whether to one s family,
or to the poor, and if so how--oh, most interesting.']
qText:
Oh, we ve had a splendid evening, We belong to a kind of club that reads papers,
Margaret and I--all women, but there is a discussion after. This evening
it was on how one ought to leave one s money--whether to one s family,
or to the poor, and if so how--oh, most interesting.
speaker: Helen

qTextArr: ['Sounds a most original entertainment!', 'I wish Evie would go to that sort of thing. But she\nhasn t the time. She s taken to breeding Aberdeen terriers--jolly little\ndogs.']
qText:
Sounds a most original entertainment! I wish Evie would go to that sort of thing. But she
hasn t the time. She s taken to breeding Aberdeen terriers--jolly little
dogs.
speaker: Henry

qTextArr: ['I expect we d better be doing the same, really.']
qText: I expect we d better be doing the same, really.
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr: ['We pretend we re improving ourselves, you see,', 'We suppose it a good thing to\nwaste an evening once a fortnight over a debate, but, as my sister says,\nit may be better to breed dogs.']
qText:
We pretend we re improving ourselves, you see, We suppose it a good thing to
waste an evening once a fortnight over a debate, but, as my sister says,
it may be better to breed dogs.
speaker: Helen

qTextArr: ['Not at all. I don t agree with your sister. There s nothing like a\ndebate to teach one quickness. I often wish I had gone in for them when\nI was a youngster. It would have helped me no end.']
qText:
Not at all. I don t agree with your sister. There s nothing like a
debate to teach one quickness. I often wish I had gone in for them when
I was a youngster. It would have helped me no end.
speaker: Henry

qTextArr: ['Quickness--?']
qText: Quickness--?
speaker: Helen

qTextArr: ['Yes. Quickness in argument. Time after time I ve missed scoring a point\nbecause the other man has had the gift of the gab and I haven t. Oh, I\nbelieve in these discussions.']
qText:
Yes. Quickness in argument. Time after time I ve missed scoring a point
because the other man has had the gift of the gab and I haven t. Oh, I
believe in these discussions.
speaker: Henry

qTextArr: ['Oh yes, it doesn t much matter what subject you take,']
qText: Oh yes, it doesn t much matter what subject you take,
speaker: Henry

qTextArr: ['But this is going to be far better than the\ndebate itself.']
qText:
But this is going to be far better than the
debate itself.
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr: ['No, I won t go\non,', 'I ll just put our special case to Mr. Wilcox.']
qText:
No, I won t go
on, I ll just put our special case to Mr. Wilcox.
speaker: Helen

qTextArr: ['About Mr. Bast? Yes, do. He ll be more lenient to a special case.']
qText: About Mr. Bast? Yes, do. He ll be more lenient to a special case.
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr: ['But, Mr. Wilcox, do first light another cigarette. It s this. We ve\njust come across a young fellow, who s evidently very poor, and who\nseems interest--']
qText:
But, Mr. Wilcox, do first light another cigarette. It s this. We ve
just come across a young fellow, who s evidently very poor, and who
seems interest--
speaker: Helen

qTextArr: ['What s his profession?']
qText: What s his profession?
speaker: Henry

qTextArr: ['Clerk.']
qText: Clerk.
speaker: Helen

qTextArr: ['What in?']
qText: What in?
speaker: Henry

qTextArr: ['Do you remember, Margaret?']
qText: Do you remember, Margaret?
speaker: Helen

qTextArr: ['Porphyrion Fire Insurance Company.']
qText: Porphyrion Fire Insurance Company.
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr:
['Oh yes; the nice people who gave Aunt Juley a new hearth rug. He seems
interesting, in some ways very, and one wishes one could help him. He is
married to a wife whom he doesn t seem to care for much. He likes books,
and what one may roughly call adventure, and if he had a chance--But he
is so poor. He lives a life where all the money is apt to go on nonsense
and clothes. One is so afraid that circumstances will be too strong
for him and that he will sink. Well, he got mixed up in our debate. He
wasn t the subject of it, but it seemed to bear on his point. Suppose
a millionaire died, and desired to leave money to help such a man. How
should he be helped? Should he be given three hundred pounds a year
direct, which was Margaret s plan? Most of them thought this would
pauperise him. Should he and those like him be given free libraries?
I said  No!  He doesn t want more books to read, but to read books
rightly. My suggestion was he should be given something every year
towards a summer holiday, but then there is his wife, and they said she
would have to go too. Nothing seemed quite right! Now what do you think?
Imagine that you were a millionaire, and wanted to help the poor. What
would you do?']
qText:
Oh yes; the nice people who gave Aunt Juley a new hearth rug. He seems
interesting, in some ways very, and one wishes one could help him. He is
married to a wife whom he doesn t seem to care for much. He likes books,
and what one may roughly call adventure, and if he had a chance--But he
is so poor. He lives a life where all the money is apt to go on nonsense
and clothes. One is so afraid that circumstances will be too strong
for him and that he will sink. Well, he got mixed up in our debate. He
wasn t the subject of it, but it seemed to bear on his point. Suppose
a millionaire died, and desired to leave money to help such a man. How
should he be helped? Should he be given three hundred pounds a year
direct, which was Margaret s plan? Most of them thought this would
pauperise him. Should he and those like him be given free libraries?
I said  No!  He doesn t want more books to read, but to read books
rightly. My suggestion was he should be given something every year
towards a summer holiday, but then there is his wife, and they said she
would have to go too. Nothing seemed quite right! Now what do you think?
Imagine that you were a millionaire, and wanted to help the poor. What
would you do?
speaker: Helen

qTextArr:
['My dear Miss Schlegel, I will not rush
in where your sex has been unable to tread. I will not add another plan
to the numerous excellent ones that have been already suggested. My only
contribution is this: let your young friend clear out of the Porphyrion
Fire Insurance Company with all possible speed.']
qText:
My dear Miss Schlegel, I will not rush
in where your sex has been unable to tread. I will not add another plan
to the numerous excellent ones that have been already suggested. My only
contribution is this: let your young friend clear out of the Porphyrion
Fire Insurance Company with all possible speed.
speaker: Henry

qText: Why?
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr: ['This is between friends. It ll be in the\nReceiver s hands before Christmas. It ll smash,']
qText:
This is between friends. It ll be in the
Receiver s hands before Christmas. It ll smash,
speaker: Henry

qTextArr: ['Dear me, Helen, listen to that. And he ll have to get another place!']
qText: Dear me, Helen, listen to that. And he ll have to get another place!
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr: ['WILL have? Let him leave the ship before it sinks. Let him get one\nnow.']
qText:
WILL have? Let him leave the ship before it sinks. Let him get one
now.
speaker: Henry

qTextArr: ['Rather than wait, to make sure?']
qText: Rather than wait, to make sure?
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr: ['Decidedly.']
qText: Decidedly.
speaker: Henry

qTextArr: ['Why s that?']
qText: Why s that?
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr:
['Naturally the man
who s in a situation when he applies stands a better chance, is in a
stronger position, that the man who isn t. It looks as if he s worth
something. I know by myself--(this is letting you into the State
secrets)--it affects an employer greatly. Human nature, I m afraid.']
qText:
Naturally the man
who s in a situation when he applies stands a better chance, is in a
stronger position, that the man who isn t. It looks as if he s worth
something. I know by myself--(this is letting you into the State
secrets)--it affects an employer greatly. Human nature, I m afraid.
speaker: Henry

qTextArr: ['I hadn t thought of that,']
qText: I hadn t thought of that,
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr: ['Our\nhuman nature appears to be the other way round. We employ people because\nthey re unemployed. The boot man, for instance.']
qText:
Our
human nature appears to be the other way round. We employ people because
they re unemployed. The boot man, for instance.
speaker: Helen

qTextArr: ['And how does he clean the boots?']
qText: And how does he clean the boots?
speaker: Henry

qTextArr: ['Not well,']
qText: Not well,
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr: ['There you are!']
qText: There you are!
speaker: Henry

qTextArr: ['Then do you really advise us to tell this youth--?']
qText: Then do you really advise us to tell this youth--?
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr:
['I advise nothing,', 'I oughtn t to have
spoken--but I happen to know, being more or less behind the scenes. The
Porphyrion s a bad, bad concern--Now, don t say I said so. It s outside
the Tariff Ring.']
qText:
I advise nothing, I oughtn t to have
spoken--but I happen to know, being more or less behind the scenes. The
Porphyrion s a bad, bad concern--Now, don t say I said so. It s outside
the Tariff Ring.
speaker: Henry

qTextArr: ['Certainly I won t say. In fact, I don t know what that means.']
qText: Certainly I won t say. In fact, I don t know what that means.
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr: ['I thought an insurance company never smashed,', 'Don t the others always run in and save them?']
qText: I thought an insurance company never smashed, Don t the others always run in and save them?
speaker: Helen

qTextArr:
['You re thinking of reinsurance,', 'It is exactly
there that the Porphyrion is weak. It has tried to undercut, has been
badly hit by a long series of small fires, and it hasn t been able to
reinsure. I m afraid that public companies don t save one another for
love.']
qText:
You re thinking of reinsurance, It is exactly
there that the Porphyrion is weak. It has tried to undercut, has been
badly hit by a long series of small fires, and it hasn t been able to
reinsure. I m afraid that public companies don t save one another for
love.
speaker: Henry

qTextArr: ['Human nature,  I suppose,']
qText: Human nature,  I suppose,
speaker: Helen

qTextArr: ['Yes, extremely,']
qText: Yes, extremely,
speaker: Henry

qTextArr: ['And how s Howards End looking?']
qText: And how s Howards End looking?
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr: ['It s let.']
qText: It s let.
speaker: Henry

qTextArr: ['Really. And you wandering homeless in longhaired Chelsea? How strange\nare the ways of Fate!']
qText:
Really. And you wandering homeless in longhaired Chelsea? How strange
are the ways of Fate!
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr: ['No; it s let unfurnished. We ve moved.']
qText: No; it s let unfurnished. We ve moved.
speaker: Henry

qTextArr: ['Why, I thought of you both as anchored there for ever. Evie never told\nme.']
qText:
Why, I thought of you both as anchored there for ever. Evie never told
me.
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr:
['I dare say when you met Evie the thing wasn t settled. We only moved
a week ago. Paul has rather a feeling for the old place, and we held on
for him to have his holiday there; but, really, it is impossibly small.
Endless drawbacks. I forget whether you ve been up to it?']
qText:
I dare say when you met Evie the thing wasn t settled. We only moved
a week ago. Paul has rather a feeling for the old place, and we held on
for him to have his holiday there; but, really, it is impossibly small.
Endless drawbacks. I forget whether you ve been up to it?
speaker: Henry

qTextArr: ['As far as the house, never.']
qText: As far as the house, never.
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr:
['Well, Howards End is one of those converted farms. They don t really
do, spend what you will on them. We messed away with a garage all among
the wych-elm roots, and last year we enclosed a bit of the meadow and
attempted a rockery. Evie got rather keen on Alpine plants. But it
didn t do--no, it didn t do. You remember, your sister will remember,
the farm with those abominable guinea-fowls, and the hedge that the old
woman never would cut properly, so that it all went thin at the
bottom. And, inside the house, the beams--and the staircase through a
door--picturesque enough, but not a place to live in.']
qText:
Well, Howards End is one of those converted farms. They don t really
do, spend what you will on them. We messed away with a garage all among
the wych-elm roots, and last year we enclosed a bit of the meadow and
attempted a rockery. Evie got rather keen on Alpine plants. But it
didn t do--no, it didn t do. You remember, your sister will remember,
the farm with those abominable guinea-fowls, and the hedge that the old
woman never would cut properly, so that it all went thin at the
bottom. And, inside the house, the beams--and the staircase through a
door--picturesque enough, but not a place to live in.
speaker: Henry

qTextArr:
['Full tide. And the position wasn t right
either. The neighbourhood s getting suburban. Either be in London or out
of it, I say; so we ve taken a house in Ducie Street, close to Sloane
Street, and a place right down in Shropshire--Oniton Grange. Ever heard
of Oniton? Do come and see us--right away from everywhere, up towards
Wales.']
qText:
Full tide. And the position wasn t right
either. The neighbourhood s getting suburban. Either be in London or out
of it, I say; so we ve taken a house in Ducie Street, close to Sloane
Street, and a place right down in Shropshire--Oniton Grange. Ever heard
of Oniton? Do come and see us--right away from everywhere, up towards
Wales.
speaker: Henry

qTextArr: ['What a change!', 'I can t imagine Howards End or Hilton\nwithout you.']
qText:
What a change! I can t imagine Howards End or Hilton
without you.
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr: ['Hilton isn t without us,', 'Charles is there still.']
qText: Hilton isn t without us, Charles is there still.
speaker: Henry

qTextArr:
['Still?', 'But I
thought he was still at Epsom. They were furnishing that Christmas--one
Christmas. How everything alters! I used to admire Mrs. Charles from our
windows very often. Wasn t it Epsom?']
qText:
Still? But I
thought he was still at Epsom. They were furnishing that Christmas--one
Christmas. How everything alters! I used to admire Mrs. Charles from our
windows very often. Wasn t it Epsom?
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr: ['Yes, but they moved eighteen months ago. Charles, the good chap']
qText: Yes, but they moved eighteen months ago. Charles, the good chap
speaker: Henry

qTextArr:
['thought I should be lonely. I didn t want him to move,
but he would, and took a house at the other end of Hilton, down by
the Six Hills. He had a motor, too. There they all are, a very jolly
party--he and she and the two grandchildren.']
qText:
thought I should be lonely. I didn t want him to move,
but he would, and took a house at the other end of Hilton, down by
the Six Hills. He had a motor, too. There they all are, a very jolly
party--he and she and the two grandchildren.
speaker: Henry

qTextArr:
['I manage other people s affairs so much better than they manage them
themselves,', 'When you moved out of
Howards End, I should have moved Mr. Charles Wilcox into it. I should
have kept so remarkable a place in the family.']
qText:
I manage other people s affairs so much better than they manage them
themselves, When you moved out of
Howards End, I should have moved Mr. Charles Wilcox into it. I should

speaker: Margaret

qTextArr: ['So it is,', 'I haven t sold it, and don t mean to.']
qText: So it is, I haven t sold it, and don t mean to.
speaker: Henry

qTextArr: ['No; but none of you are there.']
qText: No; but none of you are there.
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr:
['Oh, we ve got a splendid tenant--Hamar Bryce, an invalid. If
Charles ever wanted it--but he won t. Dolly is so dependent on modern
conveniences. No, we have all decided against Howards End. We like it in
a way, but now we feel that it is neither one thing nor the other. One
must have one thing or the other.']
qText:

qTextArr:
['What a prosperous vulgarian Mr. Wilcox has
grown! I have very little use for him in these days. However, he did
tell us about the Porphyrion. Let us write to Mr. Bast as soon as ever
we get home, and tell him to clear out of it at once.']
qText:
What a prosperous vulgarian Mr. Wilcox has
grown! I have very little use for him in these days. However, he did
tell us about the Porphyrion. Let us write to Mr. Bast as soon as ever
we get home, and tell him to clear out of it at once.
speaker: Helen

qText: Do; yes, that s worth doing. Let us.

qText: Sugar?

qText:
Cake? The big cake or the little deadlies? I m afraid

qText: It depends on what you call big.

qText:
I mean by big, a solid, well-established concern, that offers a

qTextArr: ['I couldn t say--some would tell you one thing and others another,', 'For my own part', 'I only\nbelieve half I hear. Not that even; it s safer. Those clever ones come\nto the worse grief, I ve often noticed. Ah, you can t be too careful.']
qText:
I couldn t say--some would tell you one thing and others another, For my own part I only
believe half I hear. Not that even; it s safer. Those clever ones come
to the worse grief, I ve often noticed. Ah, you can t be too careful.
speaker: Leonard

qTextArr: ['I quite agree, and that s why I was curious to know; is it a solid,\nwell-established concern?']
qText:
I quite agree, and that s why I was curious to know; is it a solid,

speaker: Helen

qText: You can tell your friend, that he s quite wrong.

qText: You, you--you--

qText: You saw the sunrise.

You tried to get away from the fogs that are stifling us all--away past

qText: So do I.

qTextArr:
['You were that last Sunday--you are this
to-day. Mr. Bast! I and my sister have talked you over. We wanted to
help you; we also supposed you might help us. We did not have you here
out of charity--which bores us--but because we hoped there would be a
connection between last Sunday and other days. What is the good of your
stars and trees, your sunrise and the wind, if they do not enter into
our daily lives? They have never entered into mine, but into yours,
we thought--Haven t we all to struggle against life s daily greyness,
against pettiness, against mechanical cheerfulness, against suspicion?
I struggle by remembering my friends; others I have known by remembering
some place--some beloved place or tree--we thought you one of these.']
qText:
You were that last Sunday--you are this
to-day. Mr. Bast! I and my sister have talked you over. We wanted to
help you; we also supposed you might help us. We did not have you here
out of charity--which bores us--but because we hoped there would be a
connection between last Sunday and other days. What is the good of your
stars and trees, your sunrise and the wind, if they do not enter into
our daily lives? They have never entered into mine, but into yours,
we thought--Haven t we all to struggle against life s daily greyness,
against pettiness, against mechanical cheerfulness, against suspicion?
I struggle by remembering my friends; others I have known by remembering
some place--some beloved place or tree--we thought you one of these.
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr: ['Of course, if there s been any misunderstanding,', 'all\nI can do is to go. But I beg to state--', 'You were picking my\nbrain for official information--I can prove it--I--']
qText:
Of course, if there s been any misunderstanding, all
I can do is to go. But I beg to state-- You were picking my
brain for official information--I can prove it--I--
speaker: Leonard

qTextArr: ['Can I help you now?', 'May I have\none quiet word with him in the hall?']
qText:

qText:

qText: But really-- Ought she to?

qText:

qTextArr:
['You behave much too well to people, and then they impose on you. I know
the world and that type of man, and as soon as I entered the room I saw
you had not been treating him properly. You must keep that type at a
distance. Otherwise they forget themselves. Sad, but true. They aren t
our sort, and one must face the fact.']
qText:
You behave much too well to people, and then they impose on you. I know
the world and that type of man, and as soon as I entered the room I saw
you had not been treating him properly. You must keep that type at a
distance. Otherwise they forget themselves. Sad, but true. They aren t
our sort, and one must face the fact.
speaker: Henry

qText: Ye--es.

qTextArr:
['I do. Firstly, because he cares for physical adventure, just as you
do. Yes, you go motoring and shooting; he would like to go camping out.
Secondly, he cares for something special IN adventure. It is quickest to
call that special something poetry--']
qText:
I do. Firstly, because he cares for physical adventure, just as you
do. Yes, you go motoring and shooting; he would like to go camping out.
Secondly, he cares for something special IN adventure. It is quickest to
call that special something poetry--
speaker: Margaret

qText: Oh, he s one of that writer sort.

qTextArr:

wash out his brain and go to the real thing. We want to show him how
he may get upsides with life. As I said, either friends or the country,
some']
qText:
No--oh no! I mean he may be, but it would be loathsome stuff. His brain
is filled with the husks of books, culture--horrible; we want him to
wash out his brain and go to the real thing. We want to show him how
he may get upsides with life. As I said, either friends or the country,
some
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr: ['either some very dear person or some very dear\nplace seems necessary to relieve life s daily grey, and to show that it\nis grey. If possible, one should have both.']
qText:
either some very dear person or some very dear
place seems necessary to relieve life s daily grey, and to show that it

qTextArr: ['Your mistake is this, and it is a very common mistake. This young\nbounder has a life of his own. What right have you to conclude it is an\nunsuccessful life, or, as you call it,  grey ?']
qText:
Your mistake is this, and it is a very common mistake. This young
bounder has a life of his own. What right have you to conclude it is an
unsuccessful life, or, as you call it,  grey ?

qText: Because--

qTextArr: ['One minute. You know nothing about him. He probably has his own\njoys and interests--wife, children, snug little home. That s where we\npractical fellows']
qText:

qTextArr:
['are more tolerant than you intellectuals.
We live and let live, and assume that things are jogging on fairly well
elsewhere, and that the ordinary plain man may be trusted to look after
his own affairs. I quite grant--I look at the faces of the clerks in my
own office, and observe them to be dull, but I don t know what s going
on beneath. So, by the way, with London. I have heard you rail against
London, Miss Schlegel, and it seems a funny thing to say but I was very
angry with you. What do you know about London? You only see civilisation
from the outside. I don t say in your case, but in too many cases that
attitude leads to morbidity, discontent, and Socialism.']
qText:
are more tolerant than you intellectuals.
We live and let live, and assume that things are jogging on fairly well
elsewhere, and that the ordinary plain man may be trusted to look after
his own affairs. I quite grant--I look at the faces of the clerks in my
own office, and observe them to be dull, but I don t know what s going
on beneath. So, by the way, with London. I have heard you rail against
London, Miss Schlegel, and it seems a funny thing to say but I was very
angry with you. What do you know about London? You only see civilisation
from the outside. I don t say in your case, but in too many cases that
attitude leads to morbidity, discontent, and Socialism.
speaker: Henry

qTextArr: ['His wife is an old bore,', 'He never came home last\nSaturday night because he wanted to be alone, and she thought he was\nwith us.']
qText:
His wife is an old bore, He never came home last
Saturday night because he wanted to be alone, and she thought he was
with us.
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr: ['With YOU?']
qText: With YOU?
speaker: Henry

qText: Yes.
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr: ['He hasn t got the cosy home that you assumed. He\nneeds outside interests.']
qText:
He hasn t got the cosy home that you assumed. He
needs outside interests.
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr: ['Naughty young man!']
qText: Naughty young man!
speaker: Evie

qTextArr: ['Naughty?', 'When\nyou re married Miss Wilcox, won t you want outside interests?']
qText:
Naughty? When
you re married Miss Wilcox, won t you want outside interests?
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr: ['He has apparently got them,']
qText: He has apparently got them,
speaker: Henry

qTextArr: ['Yes, indeed, father.']
qText: Yes, indeed, father.
speaker: Evie

qTextArr: ['He was tramping in Surrey, if you mean that,']
qText: He was tramping in Surrey, if you mean that,
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr: ['Oh, I dare say!']
qText: Oh, I dare say!
speaker: Evie

qTextArr: ['Miss Wilcox, he was!']
qText: Miss Wilcox, he was!
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr: ['He said so, and about such a thing he wouldn t lie.']
qText: He said so, and about such a thing he wouldn t lie.
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr: ['That s where I differ from you. Men lie about their positions and\nprospects, but not about a thing of that sort.']
qText:
That s where I differ from you. Men lie about their positions and
prospects, but not about a thing of that sort.
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr: ['Miss Schlegel, excuse me, but I know the type.']
qText: Miss Schlegel, excuse me, but I know the type.
speaker: Henry

qTextArr:
['I said before--he isn t a type. He cares about adventures rightly. He s
certain that our smug existence isn t all. He s vulgar and hysterical
and bookish, but don t think that sums him up. There s manhood in him as
well. Yes, that s what I m trying to say. He s a real man.']
qText:
I said before--he isn t a type. He cares about adventures rightly. He s
certain that our smug existence isn t all. He s vulgar and hysterical
and bookish, but don t think that sums him up. There s manhood in him as
well. Yes, that s what I m trying to say. He s a real man.
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr: ['Miss Schlegel, you re a pair of dear creatures, but you really MUST be\ncareful in this uncharitable world. What does your brother say?']
qText:
Miss Schlegel, you re a pair of dear creatures, but you really MUST be
careful in this uncharitable world. What does your brother say?
speaker: Henry

qTextArr: ['I forget.']
qText: I forget.
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr: ['Surely he has some opinion?']
qText: Surely he has some opinion?
speaker: Henry

qTextArr: ['He laughs, if I remember correctly.']
qText: He laughs, if I remember correctly.
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr: ['He s very clever, isn t he?']
qText: He s very clever, isn t he?
speaker: Evie

qTextArr: ['Yes, pretty well--but I wonder what Helen s doing.']
qText: Yes, pretty well--but I wonder what Helen s doing.
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr: ['She is very young to undertake this sort of thing,']
qText: She is very young to undertake this sort of thing,
speaker: Henry

qTextArr: ['Helen!']
qText: Helen!
speaker: Margaret

qText: Yes!
speaker: Helen

qTextArr: ['You in there?']
qText: You in there?
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr: ['Yes--he s gone some time.']
qText: Yes--he s gone some time.
speaker: Helen

qTextArr: ['Why, you re all alone,']
qText: Why, you re all alone,
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr: ['Yes--it s all right, Meg. Poor, poor creature--']
qText: Yes--it s all right, Meg. Poor, poor creature--
speaker: Helen

qTextArr: ['Come back to the Wilcoxes and tell me later--Mr. W much concerned, and\nslightly titillated.']
qText:
Come back to the Wilcoxes and tell me later--Mr. W much concerned, and
slightly titillated.
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr: ['Oh, I ve no patience with him. I hate him. Poor dear Mr. Bast! he\nwanted to talk literature, and we would talk business. Such a muddle of\na man, and yet so worth pulling through. I like him extraordinarily.']
qText:
Oh, I ve no patience with him. I hate him. Poor dear Mr. Bast! he
wanted to talk literature, and we would talk business. Such a muddle of
a man, and yet so worth pulling through. I like him extraordinarily.
speaker: Helen

qTextArr: ['Well done,', 'but come into the drawing-room\nnow, and don t talk about him to the Wilcoxes. Make light of the whole\nthing.']
qText:
Well done, but come into the drawing-room
now, and don t talk about him to the Wilcoxes. Make light of the whole
thing.
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr: ['He s gone with my blessing,', 'and now for puppies.']
qText: He s gone with my blessing, and now for puppies.
speaker: Helen

qTextArr:
['I am really concerned at the way those girls go on. They are as clever
as you make  em, but unpractical--God bless me! One of these days
they ll go too far. Girls like that oughtn t to live alone in London.
Until they marry, they ought to have some one to look after them. We
must look in more often--we re better than no one. You like them, don t
you, Evie?']
qText:
I am really concerned at the way those girls go on. They are as clever
as you make  em, but unpractical--God bless me! One of these days
they ll go too far. Girls like that oughtn t to live alone in London.
Until they marry, they ought to have some one to look after them. We
must look in more often--we re better than no one. You like them, don t
you, Evie?
speaker: Henry
refExp: Mr Wilcox said to his daughter

qTextArr: ['Helen s right enough, but I can t stand the toothy one.\nAnd I shouldn t have called either of them girls.']
qText:
Helen s right enough, but I can t stand the toothy one.
And I shouldn t have called either of them girls.
speaker: Evie

qTextArr: ['simply must,']
qText: simply must,
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr:
['I thought I d get round if I could,', 'Evie told me of her
little plan, so I just slipped in and secured a table. Always secure
a table first. Evie, don t pretend you want to sit by your old father,
because you don t. Miss Schlegel, come in my side, out of pity. My
goodness, but you look tired! Been worrying round after your young
clerks?']
qText:
I thought I d get round if I could, Evie told me of her
little plan, so I just slipped in and secured a table. Always secure
a table first. Evie, don t pretend you want to sit by your old father,
because you don t. Miss Schlegel, come in my side, out of pity. My
goodness, but you look tired! Been worrying round after your young
clerks?
speaker: Henry

qTextArr: ['No, after houses,', 'I m\nhungry, not tired; I want to eat heaps.']
qText:
No, after houses, I m
hungry, not tired; I want to eat heaps.
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr: ['That s good. What ll you have?']
qText: That s good. What ll you have?
speaker: Henry

qTextArr: ['Fish pie,']
qText: Fish pie,
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr: ['Fish pie! Fancy coming for fish pie to Simpson s. It s not a bit the\nthing to go for here.']
qText:
Fish pie! Fancy coming for fish pie to Simpson s. It s not a bit the
thing to go for here.
speaker: Henry

qTextArr: ['Go for something for me, then,']
qText: Go for something for me, then,
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr: ['Saddle of mutton,', 'and cider to\ndrink. That s the type of thing. I like this place, for a joke, once in\na way. It is so thoroughly Old English. Don t you agree?']
qText:
Saddle of mutton, and cider to
drink. That s the type of thing. I like this place, for a joke, once in
a way. It is so thoroughly Old English. Don t you agree?
speaker: Henry

qText: Yes,
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr: ['It s a golden rule to tip the carver. Tip everywhere s my motto.']
qText: It s a golden rule to tip the carver. Tip everywhere s my motto.
speaker: Henry

qTextArr: ['Perhaps it does make life more human.']
qText: Perhaps it does make life more human.
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr: ['Then the fellows know one again. Especially in the East, if you tip,\nthey remember you from year s end to year s end.']
qText:
Then the fellows know one again. Especially in the East, if you tip,
they remember you from year s end to year s end.
speaker: Henry

qTextArr: ['Have you been in the East?']
qText: Have you been in the East?
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr:
['Oh, Greece and the Levant. I used to go out for sport and business to
Cyprus; some military society of a sort there. A few piastres, properly
distributed, help to keep one s memory green. But you, of course, think
this shockingly cynical. How s your discussion society getting on? Any
new Utopias lately?']
qText:
Oh, Greece and the Levant. I used to go out for sport and business to
Cyprus; some military society of a sort there. A few piastres, properly
distributed, help to keep one s memory green. But you, of course, think
this shockingly cynical. How s your discussion society getting on? Any
new Utopias lately?
speaker: Henry

qTextArr: ['No, I m house-hunting, Mr. Wilcox, as I ve already told you once. Do\nyou know of any houses?']
qText:
No, I m house-hunting, Mr. Wilcox, as I ve already told you once. Do
you know of any houses?
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr: ['Afraid I don t.']
qText: Afraid I don t.
speaker: Henry

qTextArr: ['Well, what s the point of being practical if you can t find two\ndistressed females a house? We merely want a small house with large\nrooms, and plenty of them.']
qText:
Well, what s the point of being practical if you can t find two
distressed females a house? We merely want a small house with large
rooms, and plenty of them.
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr: ['Evie, I like that! Miss Schlegel expects me to turn house-agent for\nher!']
qText:
Evie, I like that! Miss Schlegel expects me to turn house-agent for
her!
speaker: Henry

qTextArr: ['What s that, father?']
qText: What s that, father?
speaker: Evie

qTextArr: ['I want a new home in September, and some one must find it. I can t.']
qText: I want a new home in September, and some one must find it. I can t.
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr: ['Percy, do you know of anything?']
qText: Percy, do you know of anything?
speaker: Evie

qTextArr: ['I can t say I do,']
qText: I can t say I do,
speaker: Mr. Cahill

qTextArr: ['How like you! You re never any good.']
qText: How like you! You re never any good.
speaker: Evie

qTextArr: ['Never any good. Just listen to her! Never any good. Oh, come!']
qText: Never any good. Just listen to her! Never any good. Oh, come!
speaker: Mr. Cahill

qTextArr: ['Well, you aren t. Miss Schlegel, is he?']
qText: Well, you aren t. Miss Schlegel, is he?
speaker: Evie

qTextArr: ['Next time,', 'you\nshall come to lunch with me at Mr. Eustace Miles s.']
qText:
Next time, you
shall come to lunch with me at Mr. Eustace Miles s.
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr: ['With pleasure.']
qText: With pleasure.
speaker: Henry

qTextArr: ['No, you d hate it,', 'It s all proteids and body buildings, and people come up to\nyou and beg your pardon, but you have such a beautiful aura.']
qText:
No, you d hate it, It s all proteids and body buildings, and people come up to
you and beg your pardon, but you have such a beautiful aura.
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr: ['A what?']
qText: A what?
speaker: Henry

qTextArr: ['Never heard of an aura? Oh, happy, happy man! I scrub at mine for\nhours. Nor of an astral plane?']
qText:
Never heard of an aura? Oh, happy, happy man! I scrub at mine for
hours. Nor of an astral plane?
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr: ['Just so. Luckily it was Helen s aura, not mine, and she had to\nchaperone it and do the politenesses. I just sat with my handkerchief in\nmy mouth till the man went.']
qText:
Just so. Luckily it was Helen s aura, not mine, and she had to
chaperone it and do the politenesses. I just sat with my handkerchief in
my mouth till the man went.
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr: ['Funny experiences seem to come to you two girls. No one s ever asked me\nabout my--what d ye call it? Perhaps I ve not got one.']
qText:
Funny experiences seem to come to you two girls. No one s ever asked me
about my--what d ye call it? Perhaps I ve not got one.
speaker: Henry

qTextArr: ['You re bound to have one, but it may be such a terrible colour that no\none dares mention it.']
qText:
You re bound to have one, but it may be such a terrible colour that no
one dares mention it.
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr: ['Tell me, though, Miss Schlegel, do you really believe in the\nsupernatural and all that?']
qText:
Tell me, though, Miss Schlegel, do you really believe in the
supernatural and all that?
speaker: Henry

qTextArr: ['Too difficult a question.']
qText: Too difficult a question.
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr: ['Why s that? Gruyere or Stilton?']
qText: Why s that? Gruyere or Stilton?
speaker: Henry

qTextArr: ['Gruyere, please.']
qText: Gruyere, please.
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr: ['Better have Stilton.']
qText: Better have Stilton.
speaker: Henry

qTextArr: ['Stilton. Because, though I don t believe in auras, and think\nTheosophy s only a halfway-house--']
qText:
Stilton. Because, though I don t believe in auras, and think
Theosophy s only a halfway-house--
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr: ['--Yet there may be something in it all the same,']
qText: --Yet there may be something in it all the same,
speaker: Henry

qTextArr: ['Not even that. It may be halfway in the wrong direction. I can t\nexplain. I don t believe in all these fads, and yet I don t like saying\nthat I don t believe in them.']
qText:
Not even that. It may be halfway in the wrong direction. I can t
explain. I don t believe in all these fads, and yet I don t like saying
that I don t believe in them.
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr: ['So you wouldn t give me your word that\nyou DON T hold with astral bodies and all the rest of it?']
qText:
So you wouldn t give me your word that
you DON T hold with astral bodies and all the rest of it?
speaker: Henry

qTextArr: ['I could,', 'Indeed, I will. When I talked about scrubbing my aura, I was\nonly trying to be funny. But why do you want this settled?']
qText:
I could, Indeed, I will. When I talked about scrubbing my aura, I was
only trying to be funny. But why do you want this settled?
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr: ['I don t know.']
qText: I don t know.
speaker: Henry

qTextArr: ['Now, Mr. Wilcox, you do know.']
qText: Now, Mr. Wilcox, you do know.
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr: ['How s your house?']
qText: How s your house?
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr: ['Much the same as when you honoured it last week.']
qText: Much the same as when you honoured it last week.
speaker: Henry

qTextArr: ['I don t mean Ducie Street. Howards End, of course.']
qText: I don t mean Ducie Street. Howards End, of course.
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr: ['Why  of course ?']
qText: Why  of course ?
speaker: Henry

qTextArr: ['Can t you turn out your tenant and let it to us? We re nearly demented.']
qText: Can t you turn out your tenant and let it to us? We re nearly demented.
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr:
['Let me think. I wish I could help you. But I thought you wanted to be
in town. One bit of advice: fix your district, then fix your price, and
then don t budge. That s how I got both Ducie Street and Oniton. I said
to myself,  I mean to be exactly here,  and I was, and Oniton s a place
in a thousand.']
qText:
Let me think. I wish I could help you. But I thought you wanted to be
in town. One bit of advice: fix your district, then fix your price, and
then don t budge. That s how I got both Ducie Street and Oniton. I said
to myself,  I mean to be exactly here,  and I was, and Oniton s a place
in a thousand.
speaker: Henry

qTextArr:
['But I do budge. Gentlemen seem to mesmerise houses--cow them with an
eye, and up they come, trembling. Ladies can t. It s the houses that are
mesmerising me. I ve no control over the saucy things. Houses are alive.
No?']
qText:
