But I do budge. Gentlemen seem to mesmerise houses--cow them with an
eye, and up they come, trembling. Ladies can t. It s the houses that are
mesmerising me. I ve no control over the saucy things. Houses are alive.
No?
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr: ['I m out of my depth,', 'Didn t you talk rather like\nthat to your office boy?']
qText:
I m out of my depth, Didn t you talk rather like
that to your office boy?
speaker: Henry

qTextArr: ['Did I?--I mean I did, more or less. I talk the same way to every\none--or try to.']
qText:
Did I?--I mean I did, more or less. I talk the same way to every
one--or try to.
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr: ['Yes, I know. And how much of it do you suppose he understood?']
qText: Yes, I know. And how much of it do you suppose he understood?
speaker: Henry

qTextArr:
['That s his lookout. I don t believe in suiting my conversation to my
company. One can doubtless hit upon some medium of exchange that seems
to do well enough, but it s no more like the real thing than money
is like food. There s no nourishment in it. You pass it to the lower
classes, and they pass it back to you, and this you call  social
intercourse  or  mutual endeavour,  when it s mutual priggishness if
it s anything. Our friends at Chelsea don t see this. They say one ought
to be at all costs intelligible, and sacrifice--']
qText:
That s his lookout. I don t believe in suiting my conversation to my
company. One can doubtless hit upon some medium of exchange that seems
to do well enough, but it s no more like the real thing than money
is like food. There s no nourishment in it. You pass it to the lower
classes, and they pass it back to you, and this you call  social
intercourse  or  mutual endeavour,  when it s mutual priggishness if
it s anything. Our friends at Chelsea don t see this. They say one ought
to be at all costs intelligible, and sacrifice--
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr: ['Lower classes,', 'Well, you do admit that there are rich and poor.\nThat s something.']
qText:
Lower classes, Well, you do admit that there are rich and poor.
That s something.
speaker: Henry

qTextArr: ['You do admit that, if wealth was divided up equally, in a few years\nthere would be rich and poor again just the same. The hard-working man\nwould come to the top, the wastrel sink to the bottom.']
qText:
You do admit that, if wealth was divided up equally, in a few years
there would be rich and poor again just the same. The hard-working man
would come to the top, the wastrel sink to the bottom.
speaker: Henry

qTextArr: ['Every one admits that.']
qText: Every one admits that.
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr: ['Your Socialists don t.']
qText: Your Socialists don t.
speaker: Henry

qTextArr:
['My Socialists do. Yours mayn t; but I strongly suspect yours of being
not Socialists, but ninepins, which you have constructed for your own
amusement. I can t imagine any living creature who would bowl over quite
so easily.']
qText:
My Socialists do. Yours mayn t; but I strongly suspect yours of being
not Socialists, but ninepins, which you have constructed for your own
amusement. I can t imagine any living creature who would bowl over quite
so easily.
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr: ['I don t care. You ve made two damaging admissions, and I m\nheartily with you in both.']
qText:
I don t care. You ve made two damaging admissions, and I m
heartily with you in both.
speaker: Henry

qTextArr: ['You needn t go though--']
qText: You needn t go though--
speaker: Aunt Juley

qTextArr:
['I needn t, but hadn t I better? It s really getting rather serious. We
let chance after chance slip, and the end of it is we shall be bundled
out bag and baggage into the street. We don t know what we WANT, that s
the mischief with us--']
qText:
I needn t, but hadn t I better? It s really getting rather serious. We
let chance after chance slip, and the end of it is we shall be bundled
out bag and baggage into the street. We don t know what we WANT, that s
the mischief with us--
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr: ['No, we have no real ties,']
qText: No, we have no real ties,
speaker: Helen

qTextArr:
['Shan t I go up to town to-day, take the house if it s the least
possible, and then come down by the afternoon train to-morrow, and start
enjoying myself. I shall be no fun to myself or to others until this
business is off my mind.']
qText:
Shan t I go up to town to-day, take the house if it s the least
possible, and then come down by the afternoon train to-morrow, and start
enjoying myself. I shall be no fun to myself or to others until this
business is off my mind.
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr: ['But you won t do anything rash, Margaret?']
qText: But you won t do anything rash, Margaret?
speaker: Aunt Juley

qTextArr: ['There s nothing rash to do.']
qText: There s nothing rash to do.
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr: ['Who ARE the Wilcoxes?']
qText: Who ARE the Wilcoxes?
speaker: Tibby

qTextArr: ['I don t MANAGE the Wilcoxes; I don t see where they come\nIN.']
qText:
I don t MANAGE the Wilcoxes; I don t see where they come
IN.
speaker: Aunt Juley

qTextArr:
['No more do I,', 'It s funny that we just don t lose sight
of them. Out of all our hotel acquaintances, Mr. Wilcox is the only one
who has stuck. It is now over three years, and we have drifted away from
far more interesting people in that time.']
qText:
No more do I, It s funny that we just don t lose sight
of them. Out of all our hotel acquaintances, Mr. Wilcox is the only one
who has stuck. It is now over three years, and we have drifted away from
far more interesting people in that time.
speaker: Helen

qTextArr: ['Interesting people don t get one houses.']
qText: Interesting people don t get one houses.
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr: ['Meg, if you start in your honest-English vein, I shall throw the\ntreacle at you.']
qText:
Meg, if you start in your honest-English vein, I shall throw the
treacle at you.
speaker: Helen

qTextArr: ['It s a better vein than the cosmopolitan,', 'Now, children, which is it to be? You know the Ducie Street house.\nShall I say yes or shall I say no? Tibby love--which? I m specially\nanxious to pin you both.']
qText:
It s a better vein than the cosmopolitan, Now, children, which is it to be? You know the Ducie Street house.
Shall I say yes or shall I say no? Tibby love--which? I m specially
anxious to pin you both.
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr: ['It depends on nothing of the sort. Say  yes.']
qText: It depends on nothing of the sort. Say  yes.
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr: ['I think,', 'that our\nrace is degenerating. We cannot settle even this little thing; what will\nit be like when we have to settle a big one?']
qText:
I think, that our
race is degenerating. We cannot settle even this little thing; what will
it be like when we have to settle a big one?
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr: ['It will be as easy as eating,']
qText: It will be as easy as eating,
speaker: Helen

qTextArr:
['I was thinking of father. How could he settle to leave Germany as he
did, when he had fought for it as a young man, and all his feelings
and friends were Prussian? How could he break loose with Patriotism and
begin aiming at something else? It would have killed me. When he was
nearly forty he could change countries and ideals--and we, at our age,
can t change houses. It s humiliating.']
qText:
I was thinking of father. How could he settle to leave Germany as he
did, when he had fought for it as a young man, and all his feelings
and friends were Prussian? How could he break loose with Patriotism and
begin aiming at something else? It would have killed me. When he was
nearly forty he could change countries and ideals--and we, at our age,
can t change houses. It s humiliating.
speaker: Margaret
menEnts: [[['Ernst'], ['Uncle Ernst'], ['Uncle Ernst'], ['Uncle Ernst'], ['Uncle Ernst'], ['Uncle Ernst'], ['Uncle Ernst'], ['Uncle Ernst'], ['Margaret', 'Tibby', 'Helen']]]

qTextArr: ['Your father may have been able to change countries,', 'and that may or may not be a good thing. But he could\nchange houses no better than you can, in fact, much worse. Never shall I\nforget what poor Emily suffered in the move from Manchester.']
qText:
Your father may have been able to change countries, and that may or may not be a good thing. But he could
change houses no better than you can, in fact, much worse. Never shall I
forget what poor Emily suffered in the move from Manchester.
speaker: Aunt Juley

qTextArr: ['I knew it,', 'I told you so. It is the little things one\nbungles at. The big, real ones are nothing when they come.']
qText:
I knew it, I told you so. It is the little things one
bungles at. The big, real ones are nothing when they come.
speaker: Helen

qTextArr:
['Bungle, my dear! You are too little to recollect--in fact, you weren t
there. But the furniture was actually in the vans and on the move
before the lease for Wickham Place was signed, and Emily took train with
baby--who was Margaret then--and the smaller luggage for London, without
so much as knowing where her new home would be. Getting away from that
house may be hard, but it is nothing to the misery that we all went
through getting you into it.']
qText:
Bungle, my dear! You are too little to recollect--in fact, you weren t
there. But the furniture was actually in the vans and on the move
before the lease for Wickham Place was signed, and Emily took train with
baby--who was Margaret then--and the smaller luggage for London, without
so much as knowing where her new home would be. Getting away from that
house may be hard, but it is nothing to the misery that we all went
through getting you into it.
speaker: Aunt Juley

qTextArr: ['And that s the man who beat the Austrians, and the Danes, and the\nFrench, and who beat the Germans that were inside himself. And we re\nlike him.']
qText:
And that s the man who beat the Austrians, and the Danes, and the
French, and who beat the Germans that were inside himself. And we re
like him.
speaker: Helen
refExp: Helen with her mouth full cried

qTextArr: ['Speak for yourself,', 'Remember that I am cosmopolitan,\nplease.']
qText:
Speak for yourself, Remember that I am cosmopolitan,
please.
speaker: Tibby

qTextArr: ['Helen may be right.']
qText: Helen may be right.
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr: ['Of course she s right,']
qText: Of course she s right,
speaker: Helen

qTextArr: ['This is awfully kind of you,', 'but I m afraid it s not going\nto do. The house has not been built that suits the Schlegel family.']
qText:
This is awfully kind of you, but I m afraid it s not going
to do. The house has not been built that suits the Schlegel family.
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr: ['What! Have you come up determined not to deal?']
qText: What! Have you come up determined not to deal?
speaker: Henry

qTextArr: ['Not exactly.']
qText: Not exactly.
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr: ['Not exactly? In that case let s be starting.']
qText: Not exactly? In that case let s be starting.
speaker: Henry

qTextArr: ['Presumably it s very beautiful,', 'How do you like it, Crane?']
qText: Presumably it s very beautiful, How do you like it, Crane?
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr: ['Come, let s be starting,', 'How on earth did you know\nthat my chauffeur was called Crane?']
qText:
Come, let s be starting, How on earth did you know
that my chauffeur was called Crane?
speaker: Henry

qTextArr: ['Why, I know Crane; I ve been for a drive with Evie once. I know that\nyou ve got a parlourmaid called Milton. I know all sorts of things.']
qText:
Why, I know Crane; I ve been for a drive with Evie once. I know that
you ve got a parlourmaid called Milton. I know all sorts of things.
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr:
['Evie!', 'You won t see her. She s gone out
with Cahill. It s no fun, I can tell you, being left so much alone. I ve
got my work all day--indeed, a great deal too much of it--but when I
come home in the evening, I tell you, I can t stand the house.']
qText:
Evie! You won t see her. She s gone out
with Cahill. It s no fun, I can tell you, being left so much alone. I ve
got my work all day--indeed, a great deal too much of it--but when I
come home in the evening, I tell you, I can t stand the house.
speaker: Henry

qTextArr: ['In my absurd way, I m lonely too,', 'It s\nheart-breaking to leave one s old home. I scarcely remember anything\nbefore Wickham Place, and Helen and Tibby were born there. Helen says--']
qText:
In my absurd way, I m lonely too, It s
heart-breaking to leave one s old home. I scarcely remember anything
before Wickham Place, and Helen and Tibby were born there. Helen says--
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr: ['You, too, feel lonely?']
qText: You, too, feel lonely?
speaker: Henry

qTextArr: ['Horribly. Hullo, Parliament s back!']
qText: Horribly. Hullo, Parliament s back!
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr: ['Yes, they are talking again,', 'But you were going to say--']
qText: Yes, they are talking again, But you were going to say--
speaker: Henry

qTextArr:
['Only some rubbish about furniture. Helen says it alone endures while
men and houses perish, and that in the end the world will be a desert of
chairs and sofas--just imagine it!--rolling through infinity with no one
to sit upon them.']
qText:
Only some rubbish about furniture. Helen says it alone endures while
men and houses perish, and that in the end the world will be a desert of
chairs and sofas--just imagine it!--rolling through infinity with no one
to sit upon them.
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr: ['Your sister always likes her little joke.']
qText: Your sister always likes her little joke.
speaker: Henry

qTextArr: ['She says  Yes,  my brother says `No,  to Ducie Street. It s no fun\nhelping us, Mr. Wilcox, I assure you.']
qText:
She says  Yes,  my brother says `No,  to Ducie Street. It s no fun
helping us, Mr. Wilcox, I assure you.
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr: ['You are not as unpractical as you pretend. I shall never believe it.']
qText: You are not as unpractical as you pretend. I shall never believe it.
speaker: Henry

qTextArr: ['At all events you responded to my telegram promptly,']
qText: At all events you responded to my telegram promptly,
speaker: Henry

qTextArr: ['Oh, even I know a good thing when I see it.']
qText: Oh, even I know a good thing when I see it.
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr: ['I m glad you don t despise the goods of this world.']
qText: I m glad you don t despise the goods of this world.
speaker: Henry

qTextArr: ['Heavens, no! Only idiots and prigs do that.']
qText: Heavens, no! Only idiots and prigs do that.
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr:
['I am glad, very glad,', 'There is so much cant talked in
would-be intellectual circles. I am glad you don t share it. Self-denial
is all very well as a means of strengthening the character. But I can t
stand those people who run down comforts. They have usually some axe to
grind. Can you?']
qText:
I am glad, very glad, There is so much cant talked in
would-be intellectual circles. I am glad you don t share it. Self-denial
is all very well as a means of strengthening the character. But I can t
stand those people who run down comforts. They have usually some axe to
grind. Can you?
speaker: Henry

qTextArr: ['Comforts are of two kinds,', 'those we can share with others, like fire, weather, or music; and\nthose we can t--food, food, for instance. It depends.']
qText:
Comforts are of two kinds, those we can share with others, like fire, weather, or music; and
those we can t--food, food, for instance. It depends.
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr: ['I mean reasonable comforts, of course. I shouldn t like to think that\nyou--']
qText:
I mean reasonable comforts, of course. I shouldn t like to think that
you--
speaker: Henry

qTextArr: ['I want to go over the whole house,', 'As soon as I get back to Swanage, which will be to-morrow afternoon,\nI ll talk it over once more with Helen and Tibby, and wire you  yes  or\n no.']
qText:
I want to go over the whole house, As soon as I get back to Swanage, which will be to-morrow afternoon,
I ll talk it over once more with Helen and Tibby, and wire you  yes  or
 no.
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr: ['Right. The dining-room.']
qText: Right. The dining-room.
speaker: Henry

qTextArr: ['Now the entrance-hall.']
qText: Now the entrance-hall.
speaker: Henry

qTextArr: ['Here we fellows smoke.']
qText: Here we fellows smoke.
speaker: Henry

qTextArr: ['Oh, jolly!']
qText: Oh, jolly!
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr: ['You do like it?', 'It s all rubbish not making\noneself comfortable. Isn t it?']
qText:
You do like it? It s all rubbish not making
oneself comfortable. Isn t it?
speaker: Henry

qTextArr: ['Ye--es. Semi-rubbish. Are those Cruikshanks?']
qText: Ye--es. Semi-rubbish. Are those Cruikshanks?
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr: ['Gillrays. Shall we go on upstairs?']
qText: Gillrays. Shall we go on upstairs?
speaker: Henry

qTextArr: ['Does all this furniture come from Howards End?']
qText: Does all this furniture come from Howards End?
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr: ['The Howards End furniture has all gone to Oniton.']
qText: The Howards End furniture has all gone to Oniton.
speaker: Henry

qTextArr: ['Does--However, I m concerned with the house, not the furniture. How big\nis this smoking-room?']
qText:
Does--However, I m concerned with the house, not the furniture. How big
is this smoking-room?
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr: ['Thirty by fifteen. No, wait a minute. Fifteen and a half.']
qText: Thirty by fifteen. No, wait a minute. Fifteen and a half.
speaker: Henry

qTextArr: ['Ah, well. Mr. Wilcox, aren t you ever amused at the solemnity with\nwhich we middle classes approach the subject of houses?']
qText:
Ah, well. Mr. Wilcox, aren t you ever amused at the solemnity with
which we middle classes approach the subject of houses?
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr: ['Miss Schlegel']
qText: Miss Schlegel
speaker: Henry

qTextArr: ['I have had you up on false\npretences. I want to speak about a much more serious matter than a\nhouse.']
qText:
I have had you up on false
pretences. I want to speak about a much more serious matter than a
house.
speaker: Henry

qTextArr: ['Could you be induced to share my--is it probable--']
qText: Could you be induced to share my--is it probable--
speaker: Henry

qTextArr: ['Oh, Mr. Wilcox!', 'I see, I see. I will write to you afterwards if I may.']
qText: Oh, Mr. Wilcox! I see, I see. I will write to you afterwards if I may.
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr: ['Miss Schlegel--Margaret you don t understand.']
qText: Miss Schlegel--Margaret you don t understand.
speaker: Henry

qTextArr: ['Oh yes! Indeed, yes!']
qText: Oh yes! Indeed, yes!
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr: ['I am asking you to be my wife.']
qText: I am asking you to be my wife.
speaker: Henry

qTextArr: ['You aren t offended, Miss Schlegel?']
qText: You aren t offended, Miss Schlegel?
speaker: Henry

qTextArr: ['How could I be offended?']
qText: How could I be offended?
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr: ['Good-bye,', 'You will have a letter from me--I am going\nback to Swanage to-morrow.']
qText:
Good-bye, You will have a letter from me--I am going
back to Swanage to-morrow.
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr: ['Thank you.']
qText: Thank you.
speaker: Henry

qTextArr: ['Good-bye, and it s you I thank.']
qText: Good-bye, and it s you I thank.
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr: ['I may order the motor round, mayn t I?']
qText: I may order the motor round, mayn t I?
speaker: Henry

qTextArr: ['That would be most kind.']
qText: That would be most kind.
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr: ['I wish I had written. Ought I to have written?']
qText: I wish I had written. Ought I to have written?
speaker: Henry

qTextArr: ['Not at all.']
qText: Not at all.
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr: ['There s just one question--']
qText: There s just one question--
speaker: Henry

qTextArr: ['And your English lakes--Vindermere, Grasmere they, then, unhealthy?']
qText: And your English lakes--Vindermere, Grasmere they, then, unhealthy?
speaker: Frieda

qTextArr: ['No, Frau Liesecke; but that is because they are fresh water, and\ndifferent. Salt water ought to have tides, and go up and down a great\ndeal, or else it smells. Look, for instance, at an aquarium.']
qText:
No, Frau Liesecke; but that is because they are fresh water, and
different. Salt water ought to have tides, and go up and down a great
deal, or else it smells. Look, for instance, at an aquarium.
speaker: Aunt Juley

qTextArr: ['An aquarium! Oh, MEESIS Munt, you mean to tell me that fresh aquariums\nstink less than salt? Why, then Victor, my brother-in-law, collected\nmany tadpoles--']
qText:
An aquarium! Oh, MEESIS Munt, you mean to tell me that fresh aquariums
stink less than salt? Why, then Victor, my brother-in-law, collected
many tadpoles--
speaker: Frieda

qTextArr: ['You are not to say  stink,', 'at\nleast, you may say it, but you must pretend you are being funny while\nyou say it.']
qText:
You are not to say  stink, at
least, you may say it, but you must pretend you are being funny while
you say it.
speaker: Helen

qTextArr: ['Then  smell.  And the mud of your Pool down there--does it not smell,\nor may I say  stink,  ha, ha?']
qText:
Then  smell.  And the mud of your Pool down there--does it not smell,
or may I say  stink,  ha, ha?
speaker: Frieda

qTextArr: ['There always has been mud in Poole Harbour,', 'The rivers bring it down, and a most valuable\noyster-fishery depends upon it.']
qText:
There always has been mud in Poole Harbour, The rivers bring it down, and a most valuable
oyster-fishery depends upon it.
speaker: Aunt Juley

qTextArr: ['Yes, that is so,']
qText: Yes, that is so,
speaker: Frieda

qTextArr:
['Bournemouth is,', 'Bournemouth is, Poole was, and Swanage
is to be the most important town of all and biggest of the three.  Now,
Frau Liesecke, I have shown you Bournemouth, and I have shown you Poole,
so let us walk backward a little, and look down again at Swanage.']
qText:
Bournemouth is, Bournemouth is, Poole was, and Swanage
is to be the most important town of all and biggest of the three.  Now,
Frau Liesecke, I have shown you Bournemouth, and I have shown you Poole,
so let us walk backward a little, and look down again at Swanage.
speaker: Aunt Juley

qTextArr: ['Aunt Juley, wouldn t that be Meg s train?']
qText: Aunt Juley, wouldn t that be Meg s train?
speaker: Helen

qTextArr: ['Oh, dearest Margaret, I do hope she won t be overtired.']
qText: Oh, dearest Margaret, I do hope she won t be overtired.
speaker: Aunt Juley

qTextArr: ['Oh, I do wonder--I do wonder whether she s taken the house.']
qText: Oh, I do wonder--I do wonder whether she s taken the house.
speaker: Helen

qTextArr: ['I hope she hasn t been hasty.']
qText: I hope she hasn t been hasty.
speaker: Aunt Juley

qTextArr: ['So do I--oh, SO do I.']
qText: So do I--oh, SO do I.
speaker: Helen

qTextArr: ['Will it be as beautiful as Wickham Place?']
qText: Will it be as beautiful as Wickham Place?
speaker: Frieda

qTextArr:
['I should think it would. Trust Mr. Wilcox for doing himself proud. All
those Ducie Street houses are beautiful in their modern way, and I can t
think why he doesn t keep on with it. But it s really for Evie that he
went there, and now that Evie s going to be married--']
qText:
I should think it would. Trust Mr. Wilcox for doing himself proud. All
those Ducie Street houses are beautiful in their modern way, and I can t
think why he doesn t keep on with it. But it s really for Evie that he
went there, and now that Evie s going to be married--
speaker: Helen

qText: Ah!
speaker: Frieda

qTextArr: ['You ve never seen Miss Wilcox, Frieda. How absurdly matrimonial you\nare!']
qText:
You ve never seen Miss Wilcox, Frieda. How absurdly matrimonial you
are!
speaker: Helen

qTextArr: ['But sister to that Paul?']
qText: But sister to that Paul?
speaker: Frieda

qText: Yes.
speaker: Helen

qTextArr: ['And to that Charles,', 'Oh, Helen, Helen,\nwhat a time that was!']
qText:
And to that Charles, Oh, Helen, Helen,
what a time that was!
speaker: Aunt Juley

qTextArr: ['Meg and I haven t got such tender hearts. If there s a\nchance of a cheap house, we go for it.']
qText:
Meg and I haven t got such tender hearts. If there s a
chance of a cheap house, we go for it.
speaker: Helen

qTextArr:
['Now look, Frau Liesecke, at my niece s train. You see, it is coming
towards us--coming, coming; and, when it gets to Corfe, it will actually
go THROUGH the downs, on which we are standing, so that, if we walk
over, as I suggested, and look down on Swanage, we shall see it coming
on the other side. Shall we?']
qText:
Now look, Frau Liesecke, at my niece s train. You see, it is coming
towards us--coming, coming; and, when it gets to Corfe, it will actually
go THROUGH the downs, on which we are standing, so that, if we walk
over, as I suggested, and look down on Swanage, we shall see it coming
on the other side. Shall we?
speaker: Aunt Juley

qTextArr:
['You see,', 'the Wilcoxes collect houses
as your Victor collects tadpoles. They have, one, Ducie Street; two,
Howards End, where my great rumpus was; three, a country seat in
Shropshire; four, Charles has a house in Hilton; and five, another near
Epsom; and six, Evie will have a house when she marries, and probably a
pied-a-terre in the country--which makes seven. Oh yes, and Paul a
hut in Africa makes eight. I wish we could get Howards End. That was
something like a dear little house! Didn t you think so, Aunt Juley?']
qText:
You see, the Wilcoxes collect houses
as your Victor collects tadpoles. They have, one, Ducie Street; two,
Howards End, where my great rumpus was; three, a country seat in
Shropshire; four, Charles has a house in Hilton; and five, another near
Epsom; and six, Evie will have a house when she marries, and probably a
pied-a-terre in the country--which makes seven. Oh yes, and Paul a
hut in Africa makes eight. I wish we could get Howards End. That was
something like a dear little house! Didn t you think so, Aunt Juley?
speaker: Helen

qTextArr: ['I had too much to do, dear, to look at it,', 'I had everything to settle and explain, and Charles\nWilcox to keep in his place besides. It isn t likely I should remember\nmuch. I just remember having lunch in your bedroom.']
qText:
I had too much to do, dear, to look at it, I had everything to settle and explain, and Charles
Wilcox to keep in his place besides. It isn t likely I should remember
much. I just remember having lunch in your bedroom.
speaker: Aunt Juley

qTextArr:
['Yes, so do I. But, oh dear, dear, how dreadful it all seems! And in the
autumn there began that anti-Pauline movement--you, and Frieda, and
Meg, and Mrs. Wilcox, all obsessed with the idea that I might yet marry
Paul.']
qText:
Yes, so do I. But, oh dear, dear, how dreadful it all seems! And in the
autumn there began that anti-Pauline movement--you, and Frieda, and
Meg, and Mrs. Wilcox, all obsessed with the idea that I might yet marry
Paul.
speaker: Helen

qTextArr: ['You yet may,']
qText: You yet may,
speaker: Frieda

qTextArr: ['The Great Wilcox Peril will never return. If I m\ncertain of anything it s of that.']
qText:
The Great Wilcox Peril will never return. If I m
certain of anything it s of that.
speaker: Helen

qTextArr: ['One is certain of nothing but the truth of one s own emotions.']
qText: One is certain of nothing but the truth of one s own emotions.
speaker: Frieda

qTextArr: ['Look!', 'Stand where I stand, and you will see the\npony-cart coming. I see the pony-cart coming.']
qText:
Look! Stand where I stand, and you will see the
pony-cart coming. I see the pony-cart coming.
speaker: Aunt Juley

qTextArr: ['Have you got the house?']
qText: Have you got the house?
speaker: Helen

qTextArr: ['Oh, what a nuisance! So we re as we were?']
qText: Oh, what a nuisance! So we re as we were?
speaker: Helen

qTextArr: ['Not exactly.']
qText: Not exactly.
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr: ['Some mystery,', 'We are to be enlightened presently.']
qText: Some mystery, We are to be enlightened presently.
speaker: Tibby

qTextArr: ['It s just like a widower,', 'They ve cheek enough for anything, and invariably select one\nof their first wife s friends.']
qText:
It s just like a widower, They ve cheek enough for anything, and invariably select one
of their first wife s friends.
speaker: Helen

qTextArr: ['That type--']
qText: That type--
speaker: Helen

qTextArr: ['Meg, not anything wrong with\nyou?']
qText:
Meg, not anything wrong with
you?
speaker: Helen

qTextArr: ['Wait one minute,']
qText: Wait one minute,
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr: ['But you ve never conceivably--you ve never--']
qText: But you ve never conceivably--you ve never--
speaker: Helen

qTextArr: ['Tibby, hurry up through; I can t hold this gate indefinitely.\nAunt Juley! I say, Aunt Juley, make the tea, will you, and Frieda; we ve\ngot to talk houses, and will come on afterwards.']
qText:
Tibby, hurry up through; I can t hold this gate indefinitely.
Aunt Juley! I say, Aunt Juley, make the tea, will you, and Frieda; we ve
got to talk houses, and will come on afterwards.
speaker: Helen

qTextArr: ['Oh, really--']
qText: Oh, really--
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr: ['Don t,', 'don t, don t, Meg, don t!']
qText: Don t, don t, don t, Meg, don t!
speaker: Helen

qTextArr: ['Don t, don t do such a thing! I tell you not to--don t! I know--don t!']
qText: Don t, don t do such a thing! I tell you not to--don t! I know--don t!
speaker: Helen

qTextArr: ['What do you know?']
qText: What do you know?
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr: ['Panic and emptiness,', 'Don t!']
qText: Panic and emptiness, Don t!
speaker: Helen

qTextArr: ['Helen is a little selfish. I have never behaved\nlike this when there has seemed a chance of her marrying.']
qText:
Helen is a little selfish. I have never behaved
like this when there has seemed a chance of her marrying.
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr: ['But we would still see each other very--often, and you--']
qText: But we would still see each other very--often, and you--
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr: ['It s not a thing like that,']
qText: It s not a thing like that,
speaker: Helen

qTextArr: ['What s happened to you?']
qText: What s happened to you?
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr: ['But it s\nstupid!']
qText:
But it s
stupid!
speaker: Helen

qTextArr: ['I don t know what s happened to either of us,', 'We must both have gone mad.']
qText: I don t know what s happened to either of us, We must both have gone mad.
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr: ['Look here, sit down.']
qText: Look here, sit down.
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr: ['All right; I ll sit down if you ll sit down.']
qText: All right; I ll sit down if you ll sit down.
speaker: Helen

qTextArr: ['There.']
qText: There.
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr: ['Now, whatever, whatever is the matter?']
qText: Now, whatever, whatever is the matter?
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr: ['I do mean what I said. Don t; it wouldn t do.']
qText: I do mean what I said. Don t; it wouldn t do.
speaker: Helen

qTextArr: ['Oh, Helen, stop saying  don t ! It s ignorant. It s as if your head\nwasn t out of the slime.  Don t  is probably what Mrs. Bast says all the\nday to Mr. Bast.']
qText:
Oh, Helen, stop saying  don t ! It s ignorant. It s as if your head
wasn t out of the slime.  Don t  is probably what Mrs. Bast says all the
day to Mr. Bast.
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr: ['Well?']
qText: Well?
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr: ['Tell me about it first, and meanwhile perhaps I ll have got my head out\nof the slime.']
qText:
Tell me about it first, and meanwhile perhaps I ll have got my head out
of the slime.
speaker: Helen

qTextArr:
['That s better. Well, where shall I begin? When I arrived at
Waterloo--no, I ll go back before that, because I m anxious you should
know everything from the first. The  first  was about ten days ago. It
was the day Mr. Bast came to tea and lost his temper. I was defending
him, and Mr. Wilcox became jealous about me, however slightly. I thought
it was the involuntary thing, which men can t help any more than we can.
You know--at least, I know in my own case--when a man has said to me,
 So-and-so s a pretty girl,  I am seized with a momentary sourness
against So-and-so, and long to tweak her ear. It s a tiresome feeling,
but not an important one, and one easily manages it. But it wasn t only
this in Mr. Wilcox s case, I gather now.']
qText:
That s better. Well, where shall I begin? When I arrived at
Waterloo--no, I ll go back before that, because I m anxious you should
know everything from the first. The  first  was about ten days ago. It
was the day Mr. Bast came to tea and lost his temper. I was defending
him, and Mr. Wilcox became jealous about me, however slightly. I thought
it was the involuntary thing, which men can t help any more than we can.
You know--at least, I know in my own case--when a man has said to me,
 So-and-so s a pretty girl,  I am seized with a momentary sourness
against So-and-so, and long to tweak her ear. It s a tiresome feeling,
but not an important one, and one easily manages it. But it wasn t only
this in Mr. Wilcox s case, I gather now.
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr: ['Then you love him?']
qText: Then you love him?
speaker: Helen

qTextArr: ['It is wonderful knowing that a real man cares for\nyou,', 'The mere fact of that grows more tremendous. Remember,\nI ve known and liked him steadily for nearly three years.']
qText:
It is wonderful knowing that a real man cares for
you, The mere fact of that grows more tremendous. Remember,
I ve known and liked him steadily for nearly three years.
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr: ['But loved him?']
qText: But loved him?
speaker: Helen

qText: No.
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr: ['But you will?']
qText: But you will?
speaker: Helen

qTextArr: ['Yes,', 'of that I m pretty sure. Indeed, I began the\nmoment he spoke to me.']
qText:
Yes, of that I m pretty sure. Indeed, I began the
moment he spoke to me.
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr: ['And have settled to marry him?']
qText: And have settled to marry him?
speaker: Helen

qTextArr: ['I had, but am wanting a long talk about it now. What is it against him,\nHelen? You must try and say.']
qText:
I had, but am wanting a long talk about it now. What is it against him,
Helen? You must try and say.
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr: ['It is ever since Paul,']
qText: It is ever since Paul,
speaker: Helen

qTextArr: ['But what has Mr. Wilcox to do with Paul?']
qText: But what has Mr. Wilcox to do with Paul?
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr:
['But he was there, they were all there that morning when I came down
to breakfast, and saw that Paul was frightened--the man who loved me
frightened and all his paraphernalia fallen, so that I knew it was
impossible, because personal relations are the important thing for ever
and ever, and not this outer life of telegrams and anger.']
qText:
But he was there, they were all there that morning when I came down
to breakfast, and saw that Paul was frightened--the man who loved me
frightened and all his paraphernalia fallen, so that I knew it was
impossible, because personal relations are the important thing for ever
and ever, and not this outer life of telegrams and anger.
speaker: Helen

qTextArr:
['That s foolish. In the first place, I disagree about the outer life.
Well, we ve often argued that. The real point is that there is the
widest gulf between my love-making and yours. Yours was romance; mine
will be prose. I m not running it down--a very good kind of prose, but
well considered, well thought out. For instance, I know all Mr. Wilcox s
faults. He s afraid of emotion. He cares too much about success, too
little about the past. His sympathy lacks poetry, and so isn t sympathy
really. I d even say']
qText:
That s foolish. In the first place, I disagree about the outer life.
Well, we ve often argued that. The real point is that there is the
widest gulf between my love-making and yours. Yours was romance; mine
will be prose. I m not running it down--a very good kind of prose, but
well considered, well thought out. For instance, I know all Mr. Wilcox s
faults. He s afraid of emotion. He cares too much about success, too
little about the past. His sympathy lacks poetry, and so isn t sympathy
really. I d even say
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr: ['that,\nspiritually, he s not as honest as I am. Doesn t that satisfy you?']
qText:
that,
spiritually, he s not as honest as I am. Doesn t that satisfy you?
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr: ['No, it doesn t,', 'It makes me feel worse and worse. You\nmust be mad.']
qText:
No, it doesn t, It makes me feel worse and worse. You
must be mad.
speaker: Helen

qTextArr: ['I don t intend him, or any man or any woman, to be all my life--good\nheavens, no! There are heaps of things in me that he doesn t, and shall\nnever, understand.']
qText:
I don t intend him, or any man or any woman, to be all my life--good
heavens, no! There are heaps of things in me that he doesn t, and shall
never, understand.
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr:
['So with him,', 'There are heaps of things in him--more
especially things that he does that will always be hidden from me. He
has all those public qualities which you so despise and which enable all
this--', 'If Wilcoxes hadn t worked and died in England for thousands of years,
you and I couldn t sit here without having our throats cut. There would
be no trains, no ships to carry us literary people about in, no fields
even. Just savagery. No--perhaps not even that. Without their spirit
life might never have moved out of protoplasm. More and more do I refuse
to draw my income and sneer at those who guarantee it. There are times
when it seems to me--']
qText:
So with him, There are heaps of things in him--more
especially things that he does that will always be hidden from me. He
has all those public qualities which you so despise and which enable all
this-- If Wilcoxes hadn t worked and died in England for thousands of years,
you and I couldn t sit here without having our throats cut. There would
be no trains, no ships to carry us literary people about in, no fields
even. Just savagery. No--perhaps not even that. Without their spirit
life might never have moved out of protoplasm. More and more do I refuse
to draw my income and sneer at those who guarantee it. There are times
when it seems to me--
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr: ['And to me, and to all women. So one kissed Paul.']
qText: And to me, and to all women. So one kissed Paul.
speaker: Helen

qTextArr: ['That s brutal,', 'Mine is an absolutely different case.\nI ve thought things out.']
qText:
That s brutal, Mine is an absolutely different case.
I ve thought things out.
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr: ['It makes no difference thinking things out. They come to the same.']
qText: It makes no difference thinking things out. They come to the same.
speaker: Helen

qTextArr: ['Rubbish!']
qText: Rubbish!
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr: ['One would lose something,']
qText: One would lose something,
speaker: Helen

qTextArr: ['Do you remember\nthe Embankment at Chelsea? It can t be ten days ago.']
qText:
Do you remember
the Embankment at Chelsea? It can t be ten days ago.
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr: ['Yes,', 'And you and your sister were head and ears\ndeep in some Quixotic scheme. Ah well!']
qText:
Yes, And you and your sister were head and ears
deep in some Quixotic scheme. Ah well!
speaker: Henry

qTextArr: ['I little thought then, certainly. Did you?']
qText: I little thought then, certainly. Did you?
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr: ['I don t know about that; I shouldn t like to say.']
qText: I don t know about that; I shouldn t like to say.
speaker: Henry

qTextArr: ['Why, was it earlier?', 'Did you think of me this way earlier!\nHow extraordinarily interesting, Henry! Tell me.']
qText:
Why, was it earlier? Did you think of me this way earlier!
How extraordinarily interesting, Henry! Tell me.
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr:
['I didn t think of it,', 'No; when you spoke to me in the
drawing-room, that was practically the first. It was all so different
from what it s supposed to be. On the stage, or in books, a proposal
is--how shall I put it?--a full-blown affair, a kind of bouquet;
it loses its literal meaning. But in life a proposal really is a
proposal--']
qText:
I didn t think of it, No; when you spoke to me in the
drawing-room, that was practically the first. It was all so different
from what it s supposed to be. On the stage, or in books, a proposal
is--how shall I put it?--a full-blown affair, a kind of bouquet;
it loses its literal meaning. But in life a proposal really is a
proposal--
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr: ['By the way--']
qText: By the way--
speaker: Henry

qTextArr: ['--a suggestion, a seed,']
qText: --a suggestion, a seed,
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr: ['I was thinking, if you didn t mind, that we ought to spend this evening\nin a business talk; there will be so much to settle.']
qText:
I was thinking, if you didn t mind, that we ought to spend this evening
in a business talk; there will be so much to settle.
speaker: Henry

qTextArr: ['I think so too.  Tell me, in the first place, how did you get on with Tibby?']
qText: I think so too.  Tell me, in the first place, how did you get on with Tibby?
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr: ['With your brother?']
qText: With your brother?
speaker: Henry

qTextArr: ['Yes, during cigarettes.']
qText: Yes, during cigarettes.
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr: ['Oh, very well.']
qText: Oh, very well.
speaker: Henry

qTextArr: ['I am so glad,', 'What did you talk\nabout? Me, presumably.']
qText:
I am so glad, What did you talk
about? Me, presumably.
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr: ['About Greece too.']
qText: About Greece too.
speaker: Henry

qTextArr: ['Greece was a very good card, Henry. Tibby s only a boy still, and one\nhas to pick and choose subjects a little. Well done.']
qText:
Greece was a very good card, Henry. Tibby s only a boy still, and one
has to pick and choose subjects a little. Well done.
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr: ['I was telling him I have shares in a currant-farm near Calamata.']
qText: I was telling him I have shares in a currant-farm near Calamata.
speaker: Henry

qTextArr: ['What a delightful thing to have shares in! Can t we go there for our\nhoneymoon?']
qText:
What a delightful thing to have shares in! Can t we go there for our
honeymoon?
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr: ['What to do?']
qText: What to do?
speaker: Henry

qTextArr: ['To eat the currants. And isn t there marvellous scenery?']
qText: To eat the currants. And isn t there marvellous scenery?
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr: ['Moderately, but it s not the kind of place one could possibly go to\nwith a lady.']
qText:
Moderately, but it s not the kind of place one could possibly go to
with a lady.
speaker: Henry

qTextArr: ['Why not?']
qText: Why not?
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr: ['No hotels.']
qText: No hotels.
speaker: Henry

qTextArr: ['Some ladies do without hotels. Are you aware that Helen and I have\nwalked alone over the Apennines, with our luggage on our backs?']
qText:
Some ladies do without hotels. Are you aware that Helen and I have
walked alone over the Apennines, with our luggage on our backs?
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr: ['I wasn t aware, and, if I can manage it, you will never do such a thing\nagain.']
qText:
I wasn t aware, and, if I can manage it, you will never do such a thing
again.
speaker: Henry

qTextArr: ['You haven t found time for a talk with Helen\nyet, I suppose?']
qText:
You haven t found time for a talk with Helen
yet, I suppose?
speaker: Margaret

qText: No.
speaker: Henry

qTextArr: ['Do, before you go. I am so anxious you two should be friends.']
qText: Do, before you go. I am so anxious you two should be friends.
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr: ['Your sister and I have always hit it off,', 'But\nwe re drifting away from our business. Let me begin at the beginning.\nYou know that Evie is going to marry Percy Cahill.']
qText:
Your sister and I have always hit it off, But
we re drifting away from our business. Let me begin at the beginning.
You know that Evie is going to marry Percy Cahill.
speaker: Henry

qTextArr: ['Dolly s uncle.']
qText: Dolly s uncle.
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr:
['Exactly. The girl s madly in love with him. A very good sort of fellow,
but he demands--and rightly--a suitable provision with her. And in the
second place you will naturally understand, there is Charles. Before
leaving town, I wrote Charles a very careful letter. You see, he has
an increasing family and increasing expenses, and the I. and W. A. is
nothing particular just now, though capable of development.']
qText:
Exactly. The girl s madly in love with him. A very good sort of fellow,
but he demands--and rightly--a suitable provision with her. And in the
second place you will naturally understand, there is Charles. Before
leaving town, I wrote Charles a very careful letter. You see, he has
an increasing family and increasing expenses, and the I. and W. A. is
nothing particular just now, though capable of development.
speaker: Henry

qTextArr: ['Poor fellow!']
qText: Poor fellow!
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr: ['Charles being the elder son, some day Charles will have Howards End;\nbut I am anxious, in my own happiness, not to be unjust to others.']
qText:
Charles being the elder son, some day Charles will have Howards End;
but I am anxious, in my own happiness, not to be unjust to others.
speaker: Henry

qTextArr: ['Of course not,', 'you mean money.\nHow stupid I am! Of course not!']
qText:
Of course not, you mean money.
How stupid I am! Of course not!
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr: ['Yes, Money, since you put\nit so frankly. I am determined to be just to all--just to you, just to\nthem. I am determined that my children shall have me.']
qText:
Yes, Money, since you put
it so frankly. I am determined to be just to all--just to you, just to
them. I am determined that my children shall have me.
speaker: Henry

qTextArr: ['Be generous to them,', 'Bother justice!']
qText: Be generous to them, Bother justice!
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr: ['I am determined--and have already written to Charles to that effect--']
qText: I am determined--and have already written to Charles to that effect--
speaker: Henry

qTextArr: ['But how much have you got?']
qText: But how much have you got?
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr: ['What?']
qText: What?
speaker: Henry

qTextArr: ['How much have you a year? I ve six hundred.']
qText: How much have you a year? I ve six hundred.
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr: ['My income?']
qText: My income?
speaker: Henry

qTextArr: ['Yes. We must begin with how much you have, before we can settle how\nmuch you can give Charles. Justice, and even generosity, depend on\nthat.']
qText:
Yes. We must begin with how much you have, before we can settle how
much you can give Charles. Justice, and even generosity, depend on
that.
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr: ['I must say you re a downright young woman,', 'What a question to spring on a fellow!']
qText: I must say you re a downright young woman, What a question to spring on a fellow!
speaker: Henry

qTextArr: ['Don t you know your income? Or don t you want to tell it me?']
qText: Don t you know your income? Or don t you want to tell it me?
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr: ['That s all right']
qText: That s all right
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr:
['don t tell me. I don t want to
know. I can do the sum just as well by proportion. Divide your income
into ten parts. How many parts would you give to Evie, how many to
Charles, how many to Paul?']
qText:
don t tell me. I don t want to
know. I can do the sum just as well by proportion. Divide your income
into ten parts. How many parts would you give to Evie, how many to
Charles, how many to Paul?
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr:
['The fact is, my dear, I hadn t any intention of bothering you with
details. I only wanted to let you know that--well, that something must
be done for the others, and you ve understood me perfectly, so let s
pass on to the next point.']
qText:
The fact is, my dear, I hadn t any intention of bothering you with
details. I only wanted to let you know that--well, that something must
be done for the others, and you ve understood me perfectly, so let s
pass on to the next point.
speaker: Henry

qTextArr: ['Yes, we ve settled that,', 'Go ahead; give away all you can, bearing in mind that I ve\na clear six hundred. What a mercy it is to have all this money about\none.']
qText:
Yes, we ve settled that, Go ahead; give away all you can, bearing in mind that I ve
a clear six hundred. What a mercy it is to have all this money about
one.
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr: ['We ve none too much, I assure you; you re marrying a poor man.']
qText: We ve none too much, I assure you; you re marrying a poor man.
speaker: Henry

qTextArr:
['Helen wouldn t agree with me here,', 'Helen daren t slang
the rich, being rich herself, but she would like to. There s an odd
notion, that I haven t yet got hold of, running about at the back of her
brain, that poverty is somehow  real.  She dislikes all organisation,
and probably confuses wealth with the technique of wealth. Sovereigns in
a stocking wouldn t bother her; cheques do. Helen is too relentless. One
can t deal in her high-handed manner with the world.']
qText:
Helen wouldn t agree with me here, Helen daren t slang
the rich, being rich herself, but she would like to. There s an odd
notion, that I haven t yet got hold of, running about at the back of her
brain, that poverty is somehow  real.  She dislikes all organisation,
and probably confuses wealth with the technique of wealth. Sovereigns in
a stocking wouldn t bother her; cheques do. Helen is too relentless. One
can t deal in her high-handed manner with the world.
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr: ['There s this other point, and then I must go back to my hotel and write\nsome letters. What s to be done now about the house in Ducie Street?']
qText:
There s this other point, and then I must go back to my hotel and write
some letters. What s to be done now about the house in Ducie Street?
speaker: Henry

qTextArr: ['Keep it on--at least, it depends. When do you want to marry me?']
qText: Keep it on--at least, it depends. When do you want to marry me?
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr: ['I say!', 'Take care I don t report you to the police.']
qText: I say! Take care I don t report you to the police.
speaker: Henry
refExp: Mr Wilcox turned on them and said

qTextArr: ['Evie will probably be married in September. We could scarcely think of\nanything before then.']
qText:
Evie will probably be married in September. We could scarcely think of
anything before then.
speaker: Henry

qTextArr: ['The earlier the nicer, Henry. Females are not supposed to say such\nthings, but the earlier the nicer.']
qText:
The earlier the nicer, Henry. Females are not supposed to say such
things, but the earlier the nicer.
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr: ['How about September for us too?']
qText: How about September for us too?
speaker: Henry

qTextArr:
['Right. Shall we go into Ducie Street ourselves in September? Or shall
we try to bounce Helen and Tibby into it? That s rather an idea. They
are so unbusinesslike, we could make them do anything by judicious
management. Look here--yes. We ll do that. And we ourselves could live
at Howards End or Shropshire.']
qText:
Right. Shall we go into Ducie Street ourselves in September? Or shall
we try to bounce Helen and Tibby into it? That s rather an idea. They
are so unbusinesslike, we could make them do anything by judicious
management. Look here--yes. We ll do that. And we ourselves could live
at Howards End or Shropshire.
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr:
['Heavens! how you women do fly round! My head s
in a whirl. Point by point, Margaret. Howards End s impossible. I let
it to Hamar Bryce on a three years  agreement last March. Don t you
remember? Oniton. Well, that is much, much too far away to rely on
entirely. You will be able to be down there entertaining a certain
amount, but we must have a house within easy reach of Town. Only Ducie
Street has huge drawbacks. There s a mews behind.']
qText:
Heavens! how you women do fly round! My head s
in a whirl. Point by point, Margaret. Howards End s impossible. I let
it to Hamar Bryce on a three years  agreement last March. Don t you
remember? Oniton. Well, that is much, much too far away to rely on
entirely. You will be able to be down there entertaining a certain
amount, but we must have a house within easy reach of Town. Only Ducie
Street has huge drawbacks. There s a mews behind.
speaker: Henry

qTextArr:
['Yes, in summer especially, the mews is a serious nuisance. The
smoking-room, too, is an abominable little den. The house opposite
has been taken by operatic people. Ducie Street s going down, it s my
private opinion.']
qText:
Yes, in summer especially, the mews is a serious nuisance. The
smoking-room, too, is an abominable little den. The house opposite
has been taken by operatic people. Ducie Street s going down, it s my
private opinion.
speaker: Henry

qTextArr: ['How sad! It s only a few years since they built those pretty houses.']
qText: How sad! It s only a few years since they built those pretty houses.
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr: ['Shows things are moving. Good for trade.']
qText: Shows things are moving. Good for trade.
speaker: Henry

qTextArr:
['I hate this continual flux of London. It is an epitome of us at
our worst--eternal formlessness; all the qualities, good, bad, and
indifferent, streaming away--streaming, streaming for ever. That s why I
dread it so. I mistrust rivers, even in scenery. Now, the sea--']
qText:
I hate this continual flux of London. It is an epitome of us at
our worst--eternal formlessness; all the qualities, good, bad, and
indifferent, streaming away--streaming, streaming for ever. That s why I
dread it so. I mistrust rivers, even in scenery. Now, the sea--
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr: ['High tide, yes.']
qText: High tide, yes.
speaker: Henry

qTextArr: ['And these are the men to whom we give the vote,', 'However, they have their own lives and interests. Let s get on.']
qText: And these are the men to whom we give the vote, However, they have their own lives and interests. Let s get on.
speaker: Henry

qTextArr: ['A nice beginning, if your aunt saw you slip in alone!']
qText: A nice beginning, if your aunt saw you slip in alone!
speaker: Henry

qTextArr: ['But I always do go about alone. Considering I ve walked over the\nApennines, it s common sense. You will make me so angry. I don t the\nleast take it as a compliment.']
qText:
But I always do go about alone. Considering I ve walked over the
Apennines, it s common sense. You will make me so angry. I don t the
least take it as a compliment.
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr: ['It isn t meant as a compliment, my dear. I\njust won t have you going about in the dark. Such people about too! It s\ndangerous.']
qText:
It isn t meant as a compliment, my dear. I
just won t have you going about in the dark. Such people about too! It s
dangerous.
speaker: Henry

qTextArr: ['Can t I look after myself? I do wish--']
qText: Can t I look after myself? I do wish--
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr: ['Come along, Margaret; no wheedling.']
qText: Come along, Margaret; no wheedling.
speaker: Henry

qTextArr: ['Margaret']
qText: Margaret
speaker: Henry
refExp: Mr Wilcox who was in front said

qTextArr: ['You ve waked the baby. I knew you would. (Rum-ti-foo,\nRackety-tackety-Tompkin!) I m not responsible for what Uncle Percy does,\nnor for anybody else or anything, so there!']
qText:
You ve waked the baby. I knew you would. (Rum-ti-foo,
Rackety-tackety-Tompkin!) I m not responsible for what Uncle Percy does,
nor for anybody else or anything, so there!
speaker: Dolly

qTextArr: ['Who asked him while I was away? Who asked my sister down to meet him?\nWho sent them out in the motor day after day?']
qText:
Who asked him while I was away? Who asked my sister down to meet him?
Who sent them out in the motor day after day?
speaker: Charles Wilcox

qTextArr: ['Charles, that reminds me of some poem.']
qText: Charles, that reminds me of some poem.
speaker: Dolly

qTextArr: ['Does it indeed? We shall all be dancing to a very different music\npresently. Miss Schlegel has fairly got us on toast.']
qText:
Does it indeed? We shall all be dancing to a very different music
presently. Miss Schlegel has fairly got us on toast.
speaker: Charles Wilcox

qTextArr: ['I could simply scratch that woman s eyes out, and to say it s my fault\nis most unfair.']
qText:
I could simply scratch that woman s eyes out, and to say it s my fault
is most unfair.
speaker: Dolly

qTextArr: ['It s your fault, and five months ago you admitted it.']
qText: It s your fault, and five months ago you admitted it.
speaker: Charles Wilcox

qTextArr: ['I didn t.']
qText: I didn t.
speaker: Dolly

qTextArr: ['You did.']
qText: You did.
speaker: Charles Wilcox

qTextArr: ['Tootle, tootle, playing on the pootle!']
qText: Tootle, tootle, playing on the pootle!
speaker: Dolly

qTextArr:
['It s all very well to turn the conversation, but father would
never have dreamt of marrying as long as Evie was there to make him
comfortable. But you must needs start match-making. Besides, Cahill s
too old.']
qText:
It s all very well to turn the conversation, but father would
never have dreamt of marrying as long as Evie was there to make him
comfortable. But you must needs start match-making. Besides, Cahill s
too old.
speaker: Charles Wilcox

qTextArr: ['Of course, if you re going to be rude to Uncle Percy.']
qText: Of course, if you re going to be rude to Uncle Percy.
speaker: Dolly

qTextArr: ['Miss Schlegel always meant to get hold of Howards End, and, thanks to\nyou, she s got it.']
qText:
Miss Schlegel always meant to get hold of Howards End, and, thanks to
you, she s got it.
speaker: Charles Wilcox

qTextArr: ['I call the way you twist things round and make them hang together most\nunfair. You couldn t have been nastier if you d caught me flirting.\nCould he, diddums?']
qText:
I call the way you twist things round and make them hang together most
unfair. You couldn t have been nastier if you d caught me flirting.
Could he, diddums?
speaker: Dolly

qTextArr:
['We re in a bad hole, and must make the best of it. I shall answer the
pater s letter civilly. He s evidently anxious to do the decent thing.
But I do not intend to forget these Schlegels in a hurry. As long
as they re on their best behaviour--Dolly, are you listening?--we ll
behave, too. But if I find them giving themselves airs or monopolising
my father, or at all ill-treating him, or worrying him with their
artistic beastliness, I intend to put my foot down, yes, firmly. Taking
my mother s place! Heaven knows what poor old Paul will say when the
news reaches him.']
qText:
We re in a bad hole, and must make the best of it. I shall answer the
pater s letter civilly. He s evidently anxious to do the decent thing.
But I do not intend to forget these Schlegels in a hurry. As long
as they re on their best behaviour--Dolly, are you listening?--we ll
behave, too. But if I find them giving themselves airs or monopolising
my father, or at all ill-treating him, or worrying him with their
artistic beastliness, I intend to put my foot down, yes, firmly. Taking
my mother s place! Heaven knows what poor old Paul will say when the
news reaches him.
speaker: Charles Wilcox

qTextArr: ['My motto is Concentrate. I ve no intention of frittering away\nmy strength on that sort of thing.']
qText:
My motto is Concentrate. I ve no intention of frittering away
my strength on that sort of thing.
speaker: Henry

qTextArr: ['It isn t frittering away the\nstrength,', 'It s enlarging the space in which you may\nbe strong.']
qText:
It isn t frittering away the
strength, It s enlarging the space in which you may
be strong.
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr: ['You re a clever little woman, but my motto s\nConcentrate.']
qText:
You re a clever little woman, but my motto s
Concentrate.
speaker: Henry

qTextArr: ['Here we all are!']
qText: Here we all are!
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr: ['Here we are. Good-morning, Helen.']
qText: Here we are. Good-morning, Helen.
speaker: Henry

qTextArr: ['Good-morning, Mr. Wilcox.']
qText: Good-morning, Mr. Wilcox.
speaker: Helen

qTextArr: ['Henry, she has had such a nice letter from the queer, cross boy. Do\nyou remember him? He had a sad moustache, but the back of his head was\nyoung.']
qText:
Henry, she has had such a nice letter from the queer, cross boy. Do
you remember him? He had a sad moustache, but the back of his head was
young.
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr: ['I have had a letter too. Not a nice one--I want to talk it over with\nyou']
qText:
I have had a letter too. Not a nice one--I want to talk it over with
you
speaker: Henry

qTextArr: ['Thanks to your hint, he s clearing out of the Porphyrion.']
qText: Thanks to your hint, he s clearing out of the Porphyrion.
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr: ['Not a bad business that Porphyrion,']
qText: Not a bad business that Porphyrion,
speaker: Henry

qTextArr: ['Not a BAD--', 'Surely, on Chelsea\nEmbankment--']
qText:
Not a BAD-- Surely, on Chelsea
Embankment--
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr: ['Here s our hostess. Good-morning, Mrs. Munt. Fine rhododendrons.\nGood-morning, Frau Liesecke; we manage to grow flowers in England, don t\nwe?']
qText:
Here s our hostess. Good-morning, Mrs. Munt. Fine rhododendrons.
Good-morning, Frau Liesecke; we manage to grow flowers in England, don t
we?
speaker: Henry

qTextArr: ['Not a BAD business?']
qText: Not a BAD business?
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr:
['No. My letter s about Howards End. Bryce has been ordered abroad, and
wants to sublet it--I am far from sure that I shall give him permission.
There was no clause in the agreement. In my opinion, subletting is a
mistake. If he can find me another tenant, whom I consider suitable,
I may cancel the agreement. Morning, Schlegel. Don t you think that s
better than subletting?']
qText:
No. My letter s about Howards End. Bryce has been ordered abroad, and
wants to sublet it--I am far from sure that I shall give him permission.
There was no clause in the agreement. In my opinion, subletting is a
mistake. If he can find me another tenant, whom I consider suitable,
I may cancel the agreement. Morning, Schlegel. Don t you think that s
better than subletting?
speaker: Henry

qTextArr: ['When there is a sublet I find that damage--']
qText: When there is a sublet I find that damage--
speaker: Henry

qTextArr: ['Do excuse me, but about the Porphyrion. I don t feel easy--might I just\nbother you, Henry?']
qText:
Do excuse me, but about the Porphyrion. I don t feel easy--might I just
bother you, Henry?
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr: ['You said on Chelsea Embankment, surely, that it was a bad concern, so\nwe advised this clerk to clear out. He writes this morning that he s\ntaken our advice, and now you say it s not a bad concern.']
qText:
You said on Chelsea Embankment, surely, that it was a bad concern, so
we advised this clerk to clear out. He writes this morning that he s
taken our advice, and now you say it s not a bad concern.
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr: ['A clerk who clears out of any concern, good or bad, without securing a\nberth somewhere else first, is a fool, and I ve no pity for him.']
qText:
A clerk who clears out of any concern, good or bad, without securing a
berth somewhere else first, is a fool, and I ve no pity for him.
speaker: Henry

qTextArr: ['He has not done that. He s going into a bank in Camden Town, he says.\nThe salary s much lower, but he hopes to manage--a branch of Dempster s\nBank. Is that all right?']
qText:
He has not done that. He s going into a bank in Camden Town, he says.
The salary s much lower, but he hopes to manage--a branch of Dempster s
Bank. Is that all right?
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr: ['Dempster! Why goodness me, yes.']
qText: Dempster! Why goodness me, yes.
speaker: Henry

qTextArr: ['More right than the Porphyrion?']
qText: More right than the Porphyrion?
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr: ['Yes, yes, yes; safe as houses--safer.']
qText: Yes, yes, yes; safe as houses--safer.
speaker: Henry

qTextArr: ['Very many thanks. I m sorry--if you sublet--?']
qText: Very many thanks. I m sorry--if you sublet--?
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr:
['If he sublets, I shan t have the same control. In theory there should
be no more damage done at Howards End; in practice there will be. Things
may be done for which no money can compensate. For instance, I shouldn t
want that fine wych-elm spoilt. It hangs--Margaret, we must go and see
the old place some time. It s pretty in its way. We ll motor down and
have lunch with Charles.']
qText:
If he sublets, I shan t have the same control. In theory there should
be no more damage done at Howards End; in practice there will be. Things
may be done for which no money can compensate. For instance, I shouldn t
want that fine wych-elm spoilt. It hangs--Margaret, we must go and see
the old place some time. It s pretty in its way. We ll motor down and
have lunch with Charles.
speaker: Henry

qTextArr: ['I should enjoy that,']
qText: I should enjoy that,
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr: ['What about next Wednesday?']
qText: What about next Wednesday?
speaker: Henry

qTextArr: ['Wednesday? No, I couldn t well do that. Aunt Juley expects us to stop\nhere another week at least.']
qText:
Wednesday? No, I couldn t well do that. Aunt Juley expects us to stop
here another week at least.
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr: ['But you can give that up now.']
qText: But you can give that up now.
speaker: Henry

qText: Er--no,
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr: ['Oh, that ll be all right. I ll speak to her.']
qText: Oh, that ll be all right. I ll speak to her.
speaker: Henry

qTextArr:
['This visit is a high solemnity. My aunt counts on it year after
year. She turns the house upside down for us; she invites our special
friends--she scarcely knows Frieda, and we can t leave her on her hands.
I missed one day, and she would be so hurt if I didn t stay the full
ten.']
qText:
This visit is a high solemnity. My aunt counts on it year after
year. She turns the house upside down for us; she invites our special
friends--she scarcely knows Frieda, and we can t leave her on her hands.
I missed one day, and she would be so hurt if I didn t stay the full
ten.
speaker: Margaret
menEnts: [[['Aunt Juley'], ['Aunt Juley'], ['Margaret', 'Tibby', 'Helen'], ['Aunt Juley'], ['Aunt Juley'], ['Frieda'], ['Margaret', 'Henry'], ['Frieda'], ['Aunt Juley'], ['Aunt Juley']]]

qTextArr: ['But I ll say a word to her. Don t you bother.']
qText: But I ll say a word to her. Don t you bother.
speaker: Henry

qTextArr: ['Henry, I won t go. Don t bully me.']
qText: Henry, I won t go. Don t bully me.
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr: ['You want to see the house, though?']
qText: You want to see the house, though?
speaker: Henry

qTextArr: ['Very much--I ve heard so much about it, one way or the other. Aren t\nthere pigs  teeth in the wych-elm?']
qText:
Very much--I ve heard so much about it, one way or the other. Aren t
there pigs  teeth in the wych-elm?
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr: ['PIGS TEETH?']
qText: PIGS TEETH?
speaker: Henry

qTextArr: ['And you chew the bark for toothache.']
qText: And you chew the bark for toothache.
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr: ['What a rum notion! Of course not!']
qText: What a rum notion! Of course not!
speaker: Henry

qTextArr: ['Perhaps I have confused it with some other tree. There are still a\ngreat number of sacred trees in England, it seems.']
qText:
Perhaps I have confused it with some other tree. There are still a
great number of sacred trees in England, it seems.
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr: ['Oh. Mr. Wilcox, about the Porphyrion--']
qText: Oh. Mr. Wilcox, about the Porphyrion--
speaker: Helen

qTextArr: ['It s all right,', 'Dempster s Bank s\nbetter.']
qText:
It s all right, Dempster s Bank s
better.
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr: ['But I think you told us the Porphyrion was bad, and would smash before\nChristmas.']
qText:
But I think you told us the Porphyrion was bad, and would smash before
Christmas.
speaker: Helen

qTextArr: ['Did I? It was still outside the Tariff Ring, and had to take rotten\npolicies. Lately it came in--safe as houses now.']
qText:
Did I? It was still outside the Tariff Ring, and had to take rotten
policies. Lately it came in--safe as houses now.
speaker: Henry

qTextArr: ['In other words, Mr. Bast need never have left it.']
qText: In other words, Mr. Bast need never have left it.
speaker: Helen

qTextArr: ['No, the fellow needn t.']
qText: No, the fellow needn t.
speaker: Henry

qTextArr: ['--and needn t have started life elsewhere at a greatly reduced salary.']
qText: --and needn t have started life elsewhere at a greatly reduced salary.
speaker: Helen

qTextArr: ['He only says  reduced,']
qText: He only says  reduced,
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr: ['With a man so poor, every reduction must be great. I consider it a\ndeplorable misfortune.']
qText:
With a man so poor, every reduction must be great. I consider it a
deplorable misfortune.
speaker: Helen

qTextArr: ['What? What s that? Do you mean\nthat I m responsible?']
qText:
What? What s that? Do you mean
that I m responsible?
speaker: Henry

qTextArr: ['You re ridiculous, Helen.']
qText: You re ridiculous, Helen.
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr: ['You seem to think--']
qText: You seem to think--
speaker: Henry

qTextArr:
['Let me explain the point
to you. It is like this. You seem to assume, when a business concern is
conducting a delicate negotiation, it ought to keep the public informed
stage by stage. The Porphyrion, according to you, was bound to say,  I
am trying all I can to get into the Tariff Ring. I am not sure that
I shall succeed, but it is the only thing that will save me from
insolvency, and I am trying.  My dear Helen--']
qText:
Let me explain the point
to you. It is like this. You seem to assume, when a business concern is
conducting a delicate negotiation, it ought to keep the public informed
stage by stage. The Porphyrion, according to you, was bound to say,  I
am trying all I can to get into the Tariff Ring. I am not sure that
I shall succeed, but it is the only thing that will save me from
insolvency, and I am trying.  My dear Helen--
speaker: Henry

qTextArr: ['Is that your point? A man who had little money has less--that s mine.']
qText: Is that your point? A man who had little money has less--that s mine.
speaker: Helen

qTextArr: ['I am grieved for your clerk. But it is all in the day s work. It s part\nof the battle of life.']
qText:
I am grieved for your clerk. But it is all in the day s work. It s part
of the battle of life.
speaker: Henry

qTextArr: ['A man who had little money--', 'has less, owing to\nus. Under these circumstances I consider  the battle of life  a happy\nexpression.']
qText:
A man who had little money-- has less, owing to
us. Under these circumstances I consider  the battle of life  a happy
expression.
speaker: Helen

qTextArr: ['Oh come, come!', 'you re not to blame. No one s\nto blame.']
qText:
Oh come, come! you re not to blame. No one s
to blame.
speaker: Henry

qTextArr: ['Is no one to blame for anything?']
qText: Is no one to blame for anything?
speaker: Helen

qTextArr: ['I wouldn t say that, but you re taking it far too seriously. Who is\nthis fellow?']
qText:
I wouldn t say that, but you re taking it far too seriously. Who is
this fellow?
speaker: Henry

qTextArr:
['We have told you about the fellow twice already,', 'You
have even met the fellow. He is very poor and his wife is an
extravagant imbecile. He is capable of better things. We--we, the upper
classes--thought we would help him from the height of our superior
knowledge--and here s the result!']
qText:
We have told you about the fellow twice already, You
have even met the fellow. He is very poor and his wife is an
extravagant imbecile. He is capable of better things. We--we, the upper
classes--thought we would help him from the height of our superior
knowledge--and here s the result!
speaker: Helen

qTextArr: ['Now, a word of advice.']
qText: Now, a word of advice.
speaker: Henry

qTextArr: ['I require no more advice.']
qText: I require no more advice.
speaker: Helen

qTextArr:
['A word of advice. Don t take up that sentimental attitude over the
poor. See that she doesn t, Margaret. The poor are poor, and one s sorry
for them, but there it is. As civilisation moves forward, the shoe is
bound to pinch in places, and it s absurd to pretend that any one is
responsible personally. Neither you, nor I, nor my informant, nor the
man who informed him, nor the directors of the Porphyrion, are to blame
for this clerk s loss of salary. It s just the shoe pinching--no one can
help it; and it might easily have been worse.']
qText:
A word of advice. Don t take up that sentimental attitude over the
poor. See that she doesn t, Margaret. The poor are poor, and one s sorry
for them, but there it is. As civilisation moves forward, the shoe is
bound to pinch in places, and it s absurd to pretend that any one is
responsible personally. Neither you, nor I, nor my informant, nor the
man who informed him, nor the directors of the Porphyrion, are to blame
for this clerk s loss of salary. It s just the shoe pinching--no one can
help it; and it might easily have been worse.
speaker: Henry

qTextArr:
['By all means subscribe to charities--subscribe to them largely--but
don t get carried away by absurd schemes of Social Reform. I see a good
deal behind the scenes, and you can take it from me that there is no
Social Question--except for a few journalists who try to get a living
out of the phrase. There are just rich and poor, as there always have
been and always will be. Point me out a time when men have been equal--']
qText:
By all means subscribe to charities--subscribe to them largely--but
don t get carried away by absurd schemes of Social Reform. I see a good
deal behind the scenes, and you can take it from me that there is no
Social Question--except for a few journalists who try to get a living
out of the phrase. There are just rich and poor, as there always have
been and always will be. Point me out a time when men have been equal--
speaker: Henry

qTextArr: ['I didn t say--']
qText: I didn t say--
speaker: Helen

qTextArr:
['Point me out a time when desire for equality has made them happier. No,
no. You can t. There always have been rich and poor. I m no fatalist.
Heaven forbid! But our civilisation is moulded by great impersonal
forces']
qText:
Point me out a time when desire for equality has made them happier. No,
no. You can t. There always have been rich and poor. I m no fatalist.
Heaven forbid! But our civilisation is moulded by great impersonal
forces
speaker: Henry

qTextArr: ['and there always will be rich and poor. You can t deny it']
qText: and there always will be rich and poor. You can t deny it
speaker: Henry

qTextArr: ['and you can t deny that, in spite\nof all, the tendency of civilisation has on the whole been upward.']
qText:
and you can t deny that, in spite
of all, the tendency of civilisation has on the whole been upward.
speaker: Henry

qTextArr: ['Owing to God, I suppose,']
qText: Owing to God, I suppose,
speaker: Helen

qTextArr: ['You grab the dollars. God does the rest.']
qText: You grab the dollars. God does the rest.
speaker: Helen

qTextArr: ['She rather reminds me of\nDolly.']
qText:
She rather reminds me of
Dolly.
speaker: Henry

qTextArr: ['Don t ever discuss political economy with Henry,', 'It ll only end in a cry.']
qText: Don t ever discuss political economy with Henry, It ll only end in a cry.
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr:
['But he must be one of those men who have reconciled science with
religion,', 'I don t like those men. They are
scientific themselves, and talk of the survival of the fittest, and cut
down the salaries of their clerks, and stunt the independence of all who
may menace their comfort, but yet they believe that somehow good--it
is always that sloppy  somehow  will be the outcome, and that in some
mystical way the Mr. Basts of the future will benefit because the Mr.
Brits of today are in pain.']
qText:
But he must be one of those men who have reconciled science with
religion, I don t like those men. They are
scientific themselves, and talk of the survival of the fittest, and cut
down the salaries of their clerks, and stunt the independence of all who
may menace their comfort, but yet they believe that somehow good--it
is always that sloppy  somehow  will be the outcome, and that in some
mystical way the Mr. Basts of the future will benefit because the Mr.
Brits of today are in pain.
speaker: Helen

qTextArr: ['He is such a man in theory. But oh, Helen, in theory!']
qText: He is such a man in theory. But oh, Helen, in theory!
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr: ['But oh, Meg, what a theory!']
qText: But oh, Meg, what a theory!
speaker: Helen

qTextArr: ['Why should you put things so bitterly, dearie?']
qText: Why should you put things so bitterly, dearie?
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr: ['Because I m an old maid,', 'I can t think\nwhy I go on like this myself.']
qText:
Because I m an old maid, I can t think
why I go on like this myself.
speaker: Helen

qTextArr: ['Margaret!', 'Magsy! It isn t true, surely, what Mr.\nWilcox says, that you want to go away early next week?']
qText:
Margaret! Magsy! It isn t true, surely, what Mr.
Wilcox says, that you want to go away early next week?
speaker: Aunt Juley

qTextArr: ['Not  want,', 'but there is so much to be\nsettled, and I do want to see the Charles s.']
qText:
Not  want, but there is so much to be
settled, and I do want to see the Charles s.
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr: ['But going away without taking the Weymouth trip, or even the Lulworth?', 'Without going once more up Nine Barrows\nDown?']
qText:
But going away without taking the Weymouth trip, or even the Lulworth? Without going once more up Nine Barrows
Down?
speaker: Aunt Juley

qTextArr: ['I m afraid so.']
qText: I m afraid so.
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr: ['Good! I did the breaking of the ice.']
qText: Good! I did the breaking of the ice.
speaker: Henry

qTextArr: ['Yes,', 'there is a mystery.\nI can t help it. It s not my fault. It s the way life has been made.']
qText:
Yes, there is a mystery.
I can t help it. It s not my fault. It s the way life has been made.
speaker: Helen

qTextArr: ['Go on and marry him. I think you re\nsplendid; and if any one can pull it off, you will.']
qText:
Go on and marry him. I think you re
splendid; and if any one can pull it off, you will.
speaker: Helen
refExp: Helen was silent for a minute and then burst into a queer speech

qTextArr:
['Yes, there
is, and I wasn t up to it with Paul. I can do only what s easy. I
can only entice and be enticed. I can t, and won t, attempt difficult
relations. If I marry, it will either be a man who s strong enough to
boss me or whom I m strong enough to boss. So I shan t ever marry, for
there aren t such men. And Heaven help any one whom I do marry, for I
shall certainly run away from him before you can say  Jack Robinson. 
There! Because I m uneducated. But you, you re different; you re a
heroine.']
qText:
Yes, there
is, and I wasn t up to it with Paul. I can do only what s easy. I
can only entice and be enticed. I can t, and won t, attempt difficult
relations. If I marry, it will either be a man who s strong enough to
boss me or whom I m strong enough to boss. So I shan t ever marry, for
there aren t such men. And Heaven help any one whom I do marry, for I
shall certainly run away from him before you can say  Jack Robinson. 
There! Because I m uneducated. But you, you re different; you re a
heroine.
speaker: Helen

qTextArr: ['Oh, Helen! Am I? Will it be as dreadful for poor Henry as all that?']
qText: Oh, Helen! Am I? Will it be as dreadful for poor Henry as all that?
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr:
['You mean to keep proportion, and that s heroic, it s Greek, and I don t
see why it shouldn t succeed with you. Go on and fight with him and help
