him. Don t ask me for help, or even for sympathy. Henceforward I m going
my own way. I mean to be thorough, because thoroughness is easy. I
mean to dislike your husband, and to tell him so. I mean to make no
concessions to Tibby. If Tibby wants to live with me, he must lump me.
I mean to love you more than ever. Yes, I do. You and I have built
up something real, because it is purely spiritual. There s no veil of
mystery over us. Unreality and mystery begin as soon as one touches the
body. The popular view is, as usual, exactly the wrong one. Our bothers
are over tangible things--money, husbands, house-hunting. But Heaven
will work of itself.']
qText:
You mean to keep proportion, and that s heroic, it s Greek, and I don t
see why it shouldn t succeed with you. Go on and fight with him and help
him. Don t ask me for help, or even for sympathy. Henceforward I m going
my own way. I mean to be thorough, because thoroughness is easy. I
mean to dislike your husband, and to tell him so. I mean to make no
concessions to Tibby. If Tibby wants to live with me, he must lump me.
I mean to love you more than ever. Yes, I do. You and I have built
up something real, because it is purely spiritual. There s no veil of
mystery over us. Unreality and mystery begin as soon as one touches the
body. The popular view is, as usual, exactly the wrong one. Our bothers
are over tangible things--money, husbands, house-hunting. But Heaven
will work of itself.
speaker: Helen

qTextArr: ['Perhaps.']
qText: Perhaps.
speaker: Margaret
refExp: Margaret was grateful for this expression of affection and answered

qTextArr: ['Yes, I see, dear; it s\nabout half-way between,']
qText:
Yes, I see, dear; it s
about half-way between,
speaker: Aunt Juley

qTextArr: ['I definitely dislike\nhim, but I ll do what I can,', 'Do what you can with my\nfriends in return.']
qText:
I definitely dislike
him, but I ll do what I can, Do what you can with my
friends in return.
speaker: Helen

qTextArr: ['One minute!']
qText: One minute!
speaker: Henry

qTextArr:
['I hope that my wife--how do you do?--will give you a decent lunch,', 'I left instructions, but we live in a rough-and-ready way.
She expects you back to tea, too, after you have had a look at Howards
End. I wonder what you ll think of the place. I wouldn t touch it with
tongs myself. Do sit down! It s a measly little place.']
qText:
I hope that my wife--how do you do?--will give you a decent lunch, I left instructions, but we live in a rough-and-ready way.
She expects you back to tea, too, after you have had a look at Howards
End. I wonder what you ll think of the place. I wouldn t touch it with
tongs myself. Do sit down! It s a measly little place.
speaker: Charles Wilcox

qTextArr: ['I shall enjoy seeing it,']
qText: I shall enjoy seeing it,
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr:
['You ll see it at its worst, for Bryce decamped abroad last Monday
without even arranging for a charwoman to clear up after him. I never
saw such a disgraceful mess. It s unbelievable. He wasn t in the house a
month.']
qText:
You ll see it at its worst, for Bryce decamped abroad last Monday
without even arranging for a charwoman to clear up after him. I never
saw such a disgraceful mess. It s unbelievable. He wasn t in the house a
month.
speaker: Charles Wilcox

qTextArr: ['I ve more than a little bone to pick with Bryce,']
qText: I ve more than a little bone to pick with Bryce,
speaker: Henry

qTextArr: ['Why did he go so suddenly?']
qText: Why did he go so suddenly?
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr: ['Invalid type; couldn t sleep.']
qText: Invalid type; couldn t sleep.
speaker: Charles Wilcox

qTextArr: ['Poor fellow!']
qText: Poor fellow!
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr: ['Poor fiddlesticks!', 'He had the\nimpudence to put up notice-boards without as much as saying with your\nleave or by your leave. Charles flung them down.']
qText:
Poor fiddlesticks! He had the
impudence to put up notice-boards without as much as saying with your
leave or by your leave. Charles flung them down.
speaker: Henry

qTextArr: ['Yes, I flung them down,']
qText: Yes, I flung them down,
speaker: Charles Wilcox

qTextArr: ['I ve sent a telegram after him, and a pretty sharp one, too. He, and\nhe in person, is responsible for the upkeep of that house for the next\nthree years.']
qText:
I ve sent a telegram after him, and a pretty sharp one, too. He, and
he in person, is responsible for the upkeep of that house for the next
three years.
speaker: Henry

qTextArr: ['The keys are at the farm; we wouldn t have the keys.']
qText: The keys are at the farm; we wouldn t have the keys.
speaker: Charles Wilcox

qTextArr: ['Quite right.']
qText: Quite right.
speaker: Henry

qTextArr: ['Dolly would have taken them, but I was in, fortunately.']
qText: Dolly would have taken them, but I was in, fortunately.
speaker: Charles Wilcox

qTextArr: ['What s Mr. Bryce like?']
qText: What s Mr. Bryce like?
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr: ['Now we ll be\noff,']
qText:
Now we ll be
off,
speaker: Henry

qTextArr: ['They re all right,', 'They ll learn--like the swallows\nand the telegraph-wires.']
qText:
They re all right, They ll learn--like the swallows

qTextArr:
['It gave her quite a turn,', 'None of you girls have any nerves, really. Of
course, a word from me put it all right, but silly old Miss Avery--she
frightened you, didn t she, Margaret? There you stood clutching a bunch
of weeds. She might have said something, instead of coming down the
stairs with that alarming bonnet on. I passed her as I came in. Enough
to make the car shy. I believe Miss Avery goes in for being a character;
some old maids do.', 'It is their last resource.
Heaven knows what she was doing in the place; but that s Bryce s
business, not mine.']
qText:
It gave her quite a turn, None of you girls have any nerves, really. Of
course, a word from me put it all right, but silly old Miss Avery--she
frightened you, didn t she, Margaret? There you stood clutching a bunch
of weeds. She might have said something, instead of coming down the
stairs with that alarming bonnet on. I passed her as I came in. Enough
to make the car shy. I believe Miss Avery goes in for being a character;
some old maids do. It is their last resource.
Heaven knows what she was doing in the place; but that s Bryce s
business, not mine.
speaker: Henry

qTextArr: ['Is Miss Avery uneducated classes?']
qText: Is Miss Avery uneducated classes?
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr:
['She s just one of the crew at the farm. People like that always assume
things. She assumed you d know who she was. She left all the Howards End
keys in the front lobby, and assumed that you d seen them as you came
in, that you d lock up the house when you d done, and would bring them
on down to her. And there was her niece hunting for them down at the
farm. Lack of education makes people very casual. Hilton was full of
women like Miss Avery once.']
qText:
She s just one of the crew at the farm. People like that always assume
things. She assumed you d know who she was. She left all the Howards End
keys in the front lobby, and assumed that you d seen them as you came
in, that you d lock up the house when you d done, and would bring them
on down to her. And there was her niece hunting for them down at the
farm. Lack of education makes people very casual. Hilton was full of
women like Miss Avery once.

qTextArr:
['Then hadn t Mrs. Wilcox a brother--or was it an uncle? Anyhow, he
popped the question, and Miss Avery, she said  No.  Just imagine, if
she d said  Yes,  she would have been Charles s aunt. (Oh, I say,
that s rather good!  Charlie s Aunt ! I must chaff him about that this
evening.) And the man went out and was killed. Yes, I m certain I ve
got it right now. Tom Howard--he was the last of them.']
qText:
Then hadn t Mrs. Wilcox a brother--or was it an uncle? Anyhow, he
popped the question, and Miss Avery, she said  No.  Just imagine, if
she d said  Yes,  she would have been Charles s aunt. (Oh, I say,
that s rather good!  Charlie s Aunt ! I must chaff him about that this
evening.) And the man went out and was killed. Yes, I m certain I ve
got it right now. Tom Howard--he was the last of them.

qTextArr:
['It is so unlucky,', 'that money wasn t put into it about fifty years ago.
Then it had four--five--times the land--thirty acres at least. One
could have made something out of it then--a small park, or at all events
shrubberies, and rebuilt the house farther away from the road. What s
the good of taking it in hand now? Nothing but the meadow left, and even
that was heavily mortgaged when I first had to do with things--yes, and
the house too. Oh, it was no joke.', 'Mismanagement did it--besides, the days for
small farms are over. It doesn t pay--except with intensive cultivation.
Small holdings, back to the land--ah! philanthropic bunkum. Take it as a
rule that nothing pays on a small scale. Most of the land you see', 'belongs
to the people at the Park--they made their pile over copper--good chaps.
Avery s Farm, Sishe s--what they call the Common, where you see that
ruined oak--one after the other fell in, and so did this, as near as
is no matter.', 'When I had more control I did what I could--sold off the two and a half
animals, and the mangy pony, and the superannuated tools; pulled down
the outhouses; drained; thinned out I don t know how many guelder-roses
and elder-trees; and inside the house I turned the old kitchen into a
hall, and made a kitchen behind where the dairy was. Garage and so on
came later. But one could still tell it s been an old farm. And yet
it isn t the place that would fetch one of your artistic crew.']
qText:
It is so unlucky, that money wasn t put into it about fifty years ago.
Then it had four--five--times the land--thirty acres at least. One
could have made something out of it then--a small park, or at all events
shrubberies, and rebuilt the house farther away from the road. What s
the good of taking it in hand now? Nothing but the meadow left, and even
that was heavily mortgaged when I first had to do with things--yes, and
the house too. Oh, it was no joke. Mismanagement did it--besides, the days for
small farms are over. It doesn t pay--except with intensive cultivation.
Small holdings, back to the land--ah! philanthropic bunkum. Take it as a
rule that nothing pays on a small scale. Most of the land you see belongs
to the people at the Park--they made their pile over copper--good chaps.
Avery s Farm, Sishe s--what they call the Common, where you see that
ruined oak--one after the other fell in, and so did this, as near as
is no matter. When I had more control I did what I could--sold off the two and a half
animals, and the mangy pony, and the superannuated tools; pulled down
the outhouses; drained; thinned out I don t know how many guelder-roses
and elder-trees; and inside the house I turned the old kitchen into a
hall, and made a kitchen behind where the dairy was. Garage and so on
came later. But one could still tell it s been an old farm. And yet
it isn t the place that would fetch one of your artistic crew.
speaker: Henry

qText: Extraordinary! Who told you?

qTextArr:
['It is all very well,', 'the pater s saying that he will be just to all, but one
can t be just indefinitely. Money isn t elastic. What s to happen if
Evie has a family? And, come to that, so may the pater. There ll not be
enough to go round, for there s none coming in, either through Dolly or
Percy. It s damnable!']
qText:
It is all very well, the pater s saying that he will be just to all, but one
can t be just indefinitely. Money isn t elastic. What s to happen if
Evie has a family? And, come to that, so may the pater. There ll not be
enough to go round, for there s none coming in, either through Dolly or

a comfort to have arrived!']

a great point of it.']

qTextArr: ['The Basts.']
qText: The Basts.
speaker: Helen

qTextArr: ['Oh, Helen!', 'Whatever have you done now?']
qText: Oh, Helen! Whatever have you done now?
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr:
['He has lost his place. He has been turned out of his bank. Yes, he s
done for. We upper classes have ruined him, and I suppose you ll tell
me it s the battle of life. Starving. His wife is ill. Starving. She
fainted in the train.']
qText:
He has lost his place. He has been turned out of his bank. Yes, he s
done for. We upper classes have ruined him, and I suppose you ll tell
me it s the battle of life. Starving. His wife is ill. Starving. She
fainted in the train.
speaker: Helen

qTextArr: ['Helen, are you mad?']
qText: Helen, are you mad?
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr:
['Perhaps. Yes. If you like, I m mad. But I ve brought them. I ll stand
injustice no longer. I ll show up the wretchedness that lies under this
luxury, this talk of impersonal forces, this cant about God doing what
we re too slack to do ourselves.']
qText:
Perhaps. Yes. If you like, I m mad. But I ve brought them. I ll stand
injustice no longer. I ll show up the wretchedness that lies under this
luxury, this talk of impersonal forces, this cant about God doing what
we re too slack to do ourselves.
speaker: Helen

qTextArr: ['Have you actually brought two starving people from London to\nShropshire, Helen?']
qText:
Have you actually brought two starving people from London to
Shropshire, Helen?
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr: ['There was a restaurant car on the train,']
qText: There was a restaurant car on the train,
speaker: Helen

qTextArr:
['Don t be absurd. They aren t starving, and you know it. Now, begin from
the beginning. I won t have such theatrical nonsense. How dare you! Yes,
how dare you!', 'bursting in to Evie s
wedding in this heartless way. My goodness! but you ve a perverted
notion of philanthropy. Look', 'servants,
people out of the windows. They think it s some vulgar scandal, and
I must explain,  Oh no, it s only my sister screaming, and only two
hangers-on of ours, whom she has brought here for no conceivable
reason.']
qText:
Don t be absurd. They aren t starving, and you know it. Now, begin from
the beginning. I won t have such theatrical nonsense. How dare you! Yes,
how dare you! bursting in to Evie s
wedding in this heartless way. My goodness! but you ve a perverted
notion of philanthropy. Look servants,
people out of the windows. They think it s some vulgar scandal, and
I must explain,  Oh no, it s only my sister screaming, and only two
hangers-on of ours, whom she has brought here for no conceivable
reason.
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr: ['Kindly take back that word  hangers-on,']
qText: Kindly take back that word  hangers-on,
speaker: Helen

qTextArr: ['Very well,', 'I, too, am sorry about them, but it beats me why\nyou ve brought them here, or why you re here yourself.']
qText:
Very well, I, too, am sorry about them, but it beats me why
you ve brought them here, or why you re here yourself.
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr: ['It s our last chance of seeing Mr. Wilcox.']
qText: It s our last chance of seeing Mr. Wilcox.
speaker: Helen

qTextArr: ['He s going to Scotland. I know he is. I insist on seeing him.']
qText: He s going to Scotland. I know he is. I insist on seeing him.
speaker: Helen

qTextArr: ['Yes, to-morrow.']
qText: Yes, to-morrow.
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr: ['I knew it was our last chance.']
qText: I knew it was our last chance.
speaker: Helen

qTextArr: ['How do you do, Mr. Bast?', 'This is an odd business. What view do you take of it?']
qText: How do you do, Mr. Bast? This is an odd business. What view do you take of it?
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr: ['There is Mrs. Bast, too,']
qText: There is Mrs. Bast, too,
speaker: Helen

qTextArr: ['You have fainted,', 'Perhaps the air will do you good.']
qText: You have fainted, Perhaps the air will do you good.
speaker: Helen

qTextArr: ['I m sure I don t want to intrude,', 'But you have been so kind to me in the past\nin warning me about the Porphyrion that I wondered--why, I wondered\nwhether--']
qText:
I m sure I don t want to intrude, But you have been so kind to me in the past
in warning me about the Porphyrion that I wondered--why, I wondered
whether--
speaker: Leonard

qTextArr: ['Whether we could get him back into the Porphyrion again,', 'Meg, this has been a cheerful business. A bright evening s work\nthat was on Chelsea Embankment.']
qText:
Whether we could get him back into the Porphyrion again, Meg, this has been a cheerful business. A bright evening s work
that was on Chelsea Embankment.
speaker: Helen

qTextArr: ['I don t understand. You left the Porphyrion because we suggested it was\na bad concern, didn t you?']
qText:
I don t understand. You left the Porphyrion because we suggested it was
a bad concern, didn t you?
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr: ['That s right.']
qText: That s right.
speaker: Leonard

qTextArr: ['And went into a bank instead?']
qText: And went into a bank instead?
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr: ['I told you all that,', 'and they reduced their staff after\nhe had been in a month, and now he s penniless, and I consider that we\nand our informant are directly to blame.']
qText:
I told you all that, and they reduced their staff after
he had been in a month, and now he s penniless, and I consider that we
and our informant are directly to blame.
speaker: Helen

qTextArr: ['I hate all this,']
qText: I hate all this,
speaker: Leonard

qTextArr:
['I hope you do, Mr. Bast. But it s no good mincing matters. You have
done yourself no good by coming here. If you intend to confront Mr.
Wilcox, and to call him to account for a chance remark, you will make a
very great mistake.']
qText:
I hope you do, Mr. Bast. But it s no good mincing matters. You have
done yourself no good by coming here. If you intend to confront Mr.
Wilcox, and to call him to account for a chance remark, you will make a
very great mistake.
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr: ['I brought them. I did it all,']
qText: I brought them. I did it all,
speaker: Helen

qTextArr:
['I can only advise you to go at once. My sister has put you in a false
position, and it is kindest to tell you so. It s too late to get to
town, but you ll find a comfortable hotel in Oniton, where Mrs. Bast can
rest, and I hope you ll be my guests there.']
qText:
I can only advise you to go at once. My sister has put you in a false
position, and it is kindest to tell you so. It s too late to get to
town, but you ll find a comfortable hotel in Oniton, where Mrs. Bast can
rest, and I hope you ll be my guests there.
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr: ['That isn t what I want, Miss Schlegel,', 'You re very\nkind, and no doubt it s a false position, but you make me miserable. I\nseem no good at all.']
qText:
That isn t what I want, Miss Schlegel, You re very
kind, and no doubt it s a false position, but you make me miserable. I
seem no good at all.
speaker: Leonard

qTextArr: ['It s work he wants,', 'Can t you see?']
qText: It s work he wants, Can t you see?
speaker: Helen

qTextArr: ['Jacky, let s go. We re more bother than we re worth.\nWe re costing these ladies pounds and pounds already to get work for us,\nand they never will. There s nothing we re good enough to do.']
qText:
Jacky, let s go. We re more bother than we re worth.
We re costing these ladies pounds and pounds already to get work for us,
and they never will. There s nothing we re good enough to do.
speaker: Leonard

qTextArr: ['We would like to find you work,', 'We want to--I, like my sister. You re only down in your luck. Go to the\nhotel, have a good night s rest, and some day you shall pay me back the\nbill, if you prefer it.']
qText:
We would like to find you work, We want to--I, like my sister. You re only down in your luck. Go to the
hotel, have a good night s rest, and some day you shall pay me back the
bill, if you prefer it.
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr:
['You don t know what you re talking about,', 'I shall never get
work now. If rich people fail at one profession, they can try another.
Not I. I had my groove, and I ve got out of it. I could do one
particular branch of insurance in one particular office well enough to
command a salary, but that s all. Poetry s nothing, Miss Schlegel. One s
thoughts about this and that are nothing. Your money, too, is nothing,
if you ll understand me. I mean if a man over twenty once loses his own
particular job, it s all over with him. I have seen it happen to others.
Their friends gave them money for a little, but in the end they fall
over the edge. It s no good. It s the whole world pulling. There always
will be rich and poor.']
qText:
You don t know what you re talking about, I shall never get
work now. If rich people fail at one profession, they can try another.
Not I. I had my groove, and I ve got out of it. I could do one
particular branch of insurance in one particular office well enough to
command a salary, but that s all. Poetry s nothing, Miss Schlegel. One s
thoughts about this and that are nothing. Your money, too, is nothing,
if you ll understand me. I mean if a man over twenty once loses his own
particular job, it s all over with him. I have seen it happen to others.
Their friends gave them money for a little, but in the end they fall
over the edge. It s no good. It s the whole world pulling. There always
will be rich and poor.
speaker: Leonard

qTextArr:
['Won t you have something to eat?', 'I don t
know what to do. It isn t my house, and though Mr. Wilcox would have
been glad to see you at any other time--as I say, I don t know what
to do, but I undertake to do what I can for you. Helen, offer them
something. Do try a sandwich, Mrs. Bast.']
qText:
Won t you have something to eat? I don t
know what to do. It isn t my house, and though Mr. Wilcox would have
been glad to see you at any other time--as I say, I don t know what
to do, but I undertake to do what I can for you. Helen, offer them
something. Do try a sandwich, Mrs. Bast.
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr: ['Helen, I like Mr. Bast. I agree that he s worth helping. I\nagree that we are directly responsible.']
qText:
Helen, I like Mr. Bast. I agree that he s worth helping. I
agree that we are directly responsible.
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr: ['No, indirectly. Via Mr. Wilcox.']
qText: No, indirectly. Via Mr. Wilcox.
speaker: Helen

qTextArr:
['Let me tell you once for all that if you take up that attitude, I ll
do nothing. No doubt you re right logically, and are entitled to say
a great many scathing things about Henry. Only, I won t have it. So
choose.']
qText:
Let me tell you once for all that if you take up that attitude, I ll
do nothing. No doubt you re right logically, and are entitled to say
a great many scathing things about Henry. Only, I won t have it. So
choose.
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr:
['If you promise to take them quietly to the George I will speak to Henry
about them--in my own way, mind; there is to be none of this absurd
screaming about justice. I have no use for justice. If it was only a
question of money, we could do it ourselves. But he wants work, and that
we can t give him, but possibly Henry can.']
qText:
If you promise to take them quietly to the George I will speak to Henry
about them--in my own way, mind; there is to be none of this absurd
screaming about justice. I have no use for justice. If it was only a
question of money, we could do it ourselves. But he wants work, and that
we can t give him, but possibly Henry can.
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr: ['It s his duty to,']
qText: It s his duty to,
speaker: Helen

qTextArr:
['Nor am I concerned with duty. I m concerned with the characters of
various people whom we know, and how, things being as they are, things
may be made a little better. Mr. Wilcox hates being asked favours; all
business men do. But I am going to ask him, at the risk of a rebuff,
because I want to make things a little better.']
qText:
Nor am I concerned with duty. I m concerned with the characters of
various people whom we know, and how, things being as they are, things
may be made a little better. Mr. Wilcox hates being asked favours; all
business men do. But I am going to ask him, at the risk of a rebuff,
because I want to make things a little better.
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr: ['Very well. I promise. You take it very calmly.']
qText: Very well. I promise. You take it very calmly.
speaker: Helen

qTextArr:
['Take them off to the George, then, and I ll try. Poor creatures! but
they look tired.', 'I haven t nearly done with
you, though, Helen. You have been most self-indulgent. I can t get over
it. You have less restraint rather than more as you grow older. Think it
over and alter yourself, or we shan t have happy lives.']
qText:
Take them off to the George, then, and I ll try. Poor creatures! but
they look tired. I haven t nearly done with
you, though, Helen. You have been most self-indulgent. I can t get over
it. You have less restraint rather than more as you grow older. Think it
over and alter yourself, or we shan t have happy lives.
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr: ['Was it townees?']
qText: Was it townees?
speaker: Henry

qTextArr: ['You ll never believe me,', 'It s\nall right now, but it was my sister.']
qText:
You ll never believe me, It s
all right now, but it was my sister.
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr: ['Helen here?', 'But she refused the\ninvitation. I thought hated weddings.']
qText:
Helen here? But she refused the
invitation. I thought hated weddings.
speaker: Henry

qTextArr: ['Don t get up. She has not come to the wedding. I ve bundled her off to\nthe George.']
qText:
Don t get up. She has not come to the wedding. I ve bundled her off to
the George.
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr: ['No; she has two of her proteges with her and must keep with them.']
qText: No; she has two of her proteges with her and must keep with them.
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr: ['Let  em all come.']
qText: Let  em all come.
speaker: Henry

qTextArr: ['My dear Henry, did you see them?']
qText: My dear Henry, did you see them?
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr: ['I did catch sight of a brown bunch of a woman, certainly.']
qText: I did catch sight of a brown bunch of a woman, certainly.
speaker: Henry

qTextArr: ['The brown bunch was Helen, but did you catch sight of a sea-green and\nsalmon bunch?']
qText:
The brown bunch was Helen, but did you catch sight of a sea-green and
salmon bunch?
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr: ['What! are they out bean-feasting?']
qText: What! are they out bean-feasting?
speaker: Henry

qTextArr: ['No; business. They wanted to see me, and later on I want to talk to you\nabout them.']
qText:
No; business. They wanted to see me, and later on I want to talk to you
about them.
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr: ['Why later\non? Tell me now. No time like the present.']
qText:
Why later
on? Tell me now. No time like the present.
speaker: Henry
refExp: Henry took the hint at once and said

qTextArr: ['Shall I?']
qText: Shall I?
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr: ['If it isn t a long story.']
qText: If it isn t a long story.
speaker: Henry

qTextArr: ['Oh, not five minutes; but there s a sting at the end of it, for I want\nyou to find the man some work in your office.']
qText:
Oh, not five minutes; but there s a sting at the end of it, for I want
you to find the man some work in your office.
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr: ['What are his qualifications?']
qText: What are his qualifications?
speaker: Henry

qTextArr: ['I don t know. He s a clerk.']
qText: I don t know. He s a clerk.
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr: ['How old?']
qText: How old?
speaker: Henry

qTextArr: ['Twenty-five, perhaps.']
qText: Twenty-five, perhaps.
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr: ['What s his name?']
qText: What s his name?
speaker: Henry

qTextArr: ['Bast,']
qText: Bast,
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr: ['Where was he before?']
qText: Where was he before?
speaker: Henry

qTextArr: ['Dempster s Bank.']
qText: Dempster s Bank.
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr: ['Why did he leave?']
qText: Why did he leave?
speaker: Henry

qTextArr: ['They reduced their staff.']
qText: They reduced their staff.
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr: ['All right; I ll see him.']
qText: All right; I ll see him.
speaker: Henry

qTextArr: ['The woman who can t influence\nher husband to vote the way she wants ought to be ashamed of herself.']
qText:
The woman who can t influence
her husband to vote the way she wants ought to be ashamed of herself.
speaker: Mrs. Plynlimmon
refExp: Mrs Plynlimmon when condemning suffragettes had said

qTextArr: ['I should be glad if you took him,', 'but I don t know whether\nhe s qualified.']
qText:
I should be glad if you took him, but I don t know whether
he s qualified.
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr: ['I ll do what I can. But, Margaret, this mustn t be taken as a\nprecedent.']
qText:
I ll do what I can. But, Margaret, this mustn t be taken as a
precedent.
speaker: Henry

qTextArr: ['No, of course--of course--']
qText: No, of course--of course--
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr: ['I can t fit in your proteges every day. Business would suffer.']
qText: I can t fit in your proteges every day. Business would suffer.
speaker: Henry

qTextArr: ['I can promise you he s the last. He--he s rather a special case.']
qText: I can promise you he s the last. He--he s rather a special case.
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr: ['Proteges always are.']
qText: Proteges always are.
speaker: Henry

qTextArr: ['Your protege has made us late,', 'The Fussells--will just be\nstarting.']
qText:
Your protege has made us late, The Fussells--will just be
starting.
speaker: Henry

qTextArr: ['She s overtired,']
qText: She s overtired,
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr: ['She s something else,', 'This won t do. I can t have her in\nmy garden in this state.']
qText:
She s something else, This won t do. I can t have her in
my garden in this state.
speaker: Henry

qTextArr: ['Is she--']
qText: Is she--
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr: ['Madam, you will be more comfortable at the hotel,']
qText: Madam, you will be more comfortable at the hotel,
speaker: Henry

qTextArr: ['If it isn t Hen!']
qText: If it isn t Hen!
speaker: Jacky

qTextArr: ['Ne crois pas que le mari lui ressemble,', 'Il est\ntout   fait diff rent.']
qText:
Ne crois pas que le mari lui ressemble, Il est
tout   fait diff rent.
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr: ['Henry!']
qText: Henry!
speaker: Jacky

qTextArr: ['I congratulate you on your proteges,']
qText: I congratulate you on your proteges,
speaker: Henry

qTextArr: ['Hen, don t go. You do love me, dear, don t you?']
qText: Hen, don t go. You do love me, dear, don t you?
speaker: Jacky

qTextArr: ['Bless us, what a person!']
qText: Bless us, what a person!
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr: ['You re a nice boy, you are.']
qText: You re a nice boy, you are.
speaker: Jacky

qTextArr: ['There now, I love you.']
qText: There now, I love you.
speaker: Jacky

qTextArr: ['Henry, I am awfully sorry.']
qText: Henry, I am awfully sorry.
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr: ['And pray why?']
qText: And pray why?
speaker: Henry

qTextArr: ['To have brought this down on you.']
qText: To have brought this down on you.
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr: ['Pray don t apologise.']
qText: Pray don t apologise.
speaker: Henry

qTextArr: ['Why does she call you  Hen ?', 'Has she ever\nseen you before?']
qText:
Why does she call you  Hen ? Has she ever
seen you before?
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr: ['Seen Hen before!', 'Who hasn t seen Hen? He s serving you\nlike me, my boys! You wait--Still we love  em.']
qText:
Seen Hen before! Who hasn t seen Hen? He s serving you
like me, my boys! You wait--Still we love  em.
speaker: Jacky

qTextArr: ['Are you now satisfied?']
qText: Are you now satisfied?
speaker: Henry

qTextArr: ['I don t know what it is all about,', 'Let s come in.']
qText: I don t know what it is all about, Let s come in.
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr: ['Don t you indeed?', 'I do. Allow\nme to congratulate you on the success of your plan.']
qText:
Don t you indeed? I do. Allow
me to congratulate you on the success of your plan.
speaker: Henry

qTextArr: ['This is Helen s plan, not mine.']
qText: This is Helen s plan, not mine.
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr:
['I now understand your interest in the Basts. Very well thought out.
I am amused at your caution, Margaret. You are quite right--it was
necessary. I am a man, and have lived a man s past. I have the honour to
release you from your engagement.']
qText:
I now understand your interest in the Basts. Very well thought out.
I am amused at your caution, Margaret. You are quite right--it was
necessary. I am a man, and have lived a man s past. I have the honour to
release you from your engagement.
speaker: Henry

qTextArr: ['So that--']
qText: So that--
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr: ['So what?']
qText: So what?
speaker: Colonel Fussell

qTextArr: ['We were saying--Henry and I were just having the fiercest argument, my\npoint being--']
qText:
We were saying--Henry and I were just having the fiercest argument, my
point being--
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr: ['No, let me do that,']
qText: No, let me do that,
speaker: Henry

qTextArr: ['Thanks so much! You see--he has forgiven me!']
qText: Thanks so much! You see--he has forgiven me!
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr: ['I don t expect there s much to forgive.']
qText: I don t expect there s much to forgive.
speaker: Colonel Fussell

qTextArr: ['So that woman has been your mistress?']
qText: So that woman has been your mistress?
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr: ['You put it with your usual delicacy,']
qText: You put it with your usual delicacy,
speaker: Henry

qTextArr: ['When, please?']
qText: When, please?
speaker: Margaret

qText: Why?
speaker: Henry

qTextArr: ['When, please?']
qText: When, please?
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr: ['Ten years ago.']
qText: Ten years ago.
speaker: Henry

qTextArr:
['Mr. Wilcox is so illogical,', 'If we
told him it was his duty to take you on, he might refuse to do it. The
fact is, he isn t properly educated. I don t want to set you against
him, but you ll find him a trial.']
qText:
Mr. Wilcox is so illogical, If we
told him it was his duty to take you on, he might refuse to do it. The
fact is, he isn t properly educated. I don t want to set you against
him, but you ll find him a trial.
speaker: Helen

qTextArr: ['I can never thank you sufficiently, Miss Schlegel,']
qText: I can never thank you sufficiently, Miss Schlegel,
speaker: Leonard

qTextArr:
['I believe in personal responsibility. Don t you? And in personal
everything. I hate--I suppose I oughtn t to say that--but the Wilcoxes
are on the wrong tack surely. Or perhaps it isn t their fault. Perhaps
the little thing that says  I  is missing out of the middle of their
heads, and then it s a waste of time to blame them. There s a nightmare
of a theory that says a special race is being born which will rule the
rest of us in the future just because it lacks the little thing that
says  I.  Had you heard that?']
qText:
I believe in personal responsibility. Don t you? And in personal
everything. I hate--I suppose I oughtn t to say that--but the Wilcoxes
are on the wrong tack surely. Or perhaps it isn t their fault. Perhaps
the little thing that says  I  is missing out of the middle of their
heads, and then it s a waste of time to blame them. There s a nightmare
of a theory that says a special race is being born which will rule the
rest of us in the future just because it lacks the little thing that
says  I.  Had you heard that?
speaker: Helen

qTextArr: ['I get no time for reading.']
qText: I get no time for reading.
speaker: Leonard

qTextArr:
['Had you thought it, then? That there are two kinds of people--our kind,
who live straight from the middle of their heads, and the other kind
who can t, because their heads have no middle? They can t say  I.  They
AREN T in fact, and so they re supermen. Pierpont Morgan has never said
 I  in his life.']
qText:
Had you thought it, then? That there are two kinds of people--our kind,
who live straight from the middle of their heads, and the other kind
who can t, because their heads have no middle? They can t say  I.  They
AREN T in fact, and so they re supermen. Pierpont Morgan has never said
 I  in his life.
speaker: Helen

qTextArr: ['I never got on to Nietzsche,', 'But I always understood\nthat those supermen were rather what you may call egoists.']
qText:
I never got on to Nietzsche, But I always understood
that those supermen were rather what you may call egoists.
speaker: Leonard

qTextArr:
['Oh no, that s wrong,', 'No superman ever said  I want, 
because  I want  must lead to the question,  Who am I?  and so to Pity
and to Justice. He only says  want.   Want Europe,  if he s Napoleon;
 want wives,  if he s Bluebeard;  want Botticelli,  if he s Pierpont
Morgan. Never the  I ; and if you could pierce through the superman,
you d find panic and emptiness in the middle."']
qText:
Oh no, that s wrong, No superman ever said  I want, 
because  I want  must lead to the question,  Who am I?  and so to Pity
and to Justice. He only says  want.   Want Europe,  if he s Napoleon;
 want wives,  if he s Bluebeard;  want Botticelli,  if he s Pierpont
Morgan. Never the  I ; and if you could pierce through the superman,
you d find panic and emptiness in the middle."
speaker: Helen

qTextArr: ['May I take it, Miss\nSchlegel, that you and I are both the sort that say  I ?']
qText:
May I take it, Miss
Schlegel, that you and I are both the sort that say  I ?
speaker: Leonard

qTextArr: ['Of course.']
qText: Of course.
speaker: Helen

qTextArr: ['And your sister, too?']
qText: And your sister, too?
speaker: Leonard

qTextArr: ['Of course,', 'All presentable people say\n I.']
qText:
Of course, All presentable people say
 I.
speaker: Helen

qTextArr: ['But Mr. Wilcox--he is not perhaps--']
qText: But Mr. Wilcox--he is not perhaps--
speaker: Leonard

qTextArr: ['I don t know that it s any good discussing Mr. Wilcox either.']
qText: I don t know that it s any good discussing Mr. Wilcox either.
speaker: Helen

qTextArr: ['Quite so, quite so,']
qText: Quite so, quite so,
speaker: Leonard

qTextArr: ['Mrs.\nBast--does she ever say  I ?', 'Is she very tired?']
qText:
Mrs.
Bast--does she ever say  I ? Is she very tired?
speaker: Helen

qTextArr: ['It s better she stops in her room,']
qText: It s better she stops in her room,
speaker: Leonard

qTextArr: ['Shall I sit up with her?']
qText: Shall I sit up with her?
speaker: Helen

qTextArr: ['No, thank you; she does not need company.']
qText: No, thank you; she does not need company.
speaker: Leonard

qTextArr: ['Mr. Bast, what kind of woman is your wife?']
qText: Mr. Bast, what kind of woman is your wife?
speaker: Helen

qTextArr: ['You ought to know my ways by now. Does that question offend you?']
qText: You ought to know my ways by now. Does that question offend you?
speaker: Helen

qTextArr: ['No, oh no, Miss Schlegel, no.']
qText: No, oh no, Miss Schlegel, no.
speaker: Leonard

qTextArr: ['Because I love honesty. Don t pretend your marriage has been a happy\none. You and she can have nothing in common.']
qText:
Because I love honesty. Don t pretend your marriage has been a happy
one. You and she can have nothing in common.
speaker: Helen

qTextArr:
['I suppose that s pretty obvious;
but Jacky never meant to do anybody any harm. When things went wrong,
or I heard things, I used to think it was her fault, but, looking back,
it s more mine. I needn t have married her, but as I have I must stick
to her and keep her.']
qText:
I suppose that s pretty obvious;
but Jacky never meant to do anybody any harm. When things went wrong,
or I heard things, I used to think it was her fault, but, looking back,
it s more mine. I needn t have married her, but as I have I must stick
to her and keep her.
speaker: Leonard
refExp: He did not deny it but said

qTextArr: ['How long have you been married?']
qText: How long have you been married?
speaker: Helen

qTextArr: ['Nearly three years.']
qText: Nearly three years.
speaker: Leonard

qTextArr: ['What did your people say?']
qText: What did your people say?
speaker: Helen

qTextArr: ['They will not have anything to do with us. They had a sort of family\ncouncil when they heard I was married, and cut us off altogether.']
qText:
They will not have anything to do with us. They had a sort of family
council when they heard I was married, and cut us off altogether.
speaker: Leonard

qTextArr: ['My good boy, what a mess!', 'Who are your people?']
qText: My good boy, what a mess! Who are your people?
speaker: Helen

qTextArr: ['And your grandparents?']
qText: And your grandparents?
speaker: Helen

qTextArr: ['They\nwere just nothing at all,', 'agricultural labourers and that\nsort.']
qText:
They
were just nothing at all, agricultural labourers and that
sort.
speaker: Leonard

qTextArr: ['So! From which part?']
qText: So! From which part?
speaker: Helen

qTextArr: ['Lincolnshire mostly, but my mother s father--he, oddly enough, came\nfrom these parts round here.']
qText:
Lincolnshire mostly, but my mother s father--he, oddly enough, came
from these parts round here.
speaker: Leonard

qTextArr: ['From this very Shropshire. Yes, that is odd. My mother s people were\nLancashire. But why do your brother and your sisters object to Mrs.\nBast?']
qText:
From this very Shropshire. Yes, that is odd. My mother s people were
Lancashire. But why do your brother and your sisters object to Mrs.
Bast?
speaker: Helen

qTextArr: ['Oh, I don t know.']
qText: Oh, I don t know.
speaker: Leonard

qTextArr: ['Excuse me, you do know. I am not a baby. I can bear anything you tell\nme, and the more you tell the more I shall be able to help. Have they\nheard anything against her?']
qText:
Excuse me, you do know. I am not a baby. I can bear anything you tell
me, and the more you tell the more I shall be able to help. Have they
heard anything against her?
speaker: Helen

qTextArr: ['I think I have guessed now,']
qText: I think I have guessed now,
speaker: Helen

qTextArr: ['I don t think so, Miss Schlegel; I hope not.']
qText: I don t think so, Miss Schlegel; I hope not.
speaker: Leonard

qTextArr:
['We must be honest, even over these things. I have guessed. I am
frightfully, dreadfully sorry, but it does not make the least difference
to me. I shall feel just the same to both of you. I blame, not your wife
for these things, but men.']
qText:
We must be honest, even over these things. I have guessed. I am
frightfully, dreadfully sorry, but it does not make the least difference
to me. I shall feel just the same to both of you. I blame, not your wife
for these things, but men.
speaker: Helen

qTextArr:
['Don t you worry,', 'I can t bear that. We
shall be all right if I get work. If I could only get work--something
regular to do. Then it wouldn t be so bad again. I don t trouble after
books as I used. I can imagine that with regular work we should settle
down again. It stops one thinking.']
qText:
Don t you worry, I can t bear that. We
shall be all right if I get work. If I could only get work--something
regular to do. Then it wouldn t be so bad again. I don t trouble after
books as I used. I can imagine that with regular work we should settle
down again. It stops one thinking.
speaker: Leonard

qTextArr: ['Settle down to what?']
qText: Settle down to what?
speaker: Helen

qTextArr: ['Oh, just settle down.']
qText: Oh, just settle down.
speaker: Leonard

qTextArr: ['And that s to be life!', 'How\ncan you, with all the beautiful things to see and do--with music--with\nwalking at night--']
qText:
And that s to be life! How
can you, with all the beautiful things to see and do--with music--with
walking at night--
speaker: Helen

qTextArr:
['Walking is well enough when a man s in work,', 'Oh, I did
talk a lot of nonsense once, but there s nothing like a bailiff in the
house to drive it out of you. When I saw him fingering my Ruskins and
Stevensons, I seemed to see life straight and real, and it isn t a
pretty sight. My books are back again, thanks to you, but they ll never
be the same to me again, and I shan t ever again think night in the
woods is wonderful.']
qText:
Walking is well enough when a man s in work, Oh, I did
talk a lot of nonsense once, but there s nothing like a bailiff in the
house to drive it out of you. When I saw him fingering my Ruskins and
Stevensons, I seemed to see life straight and real, and it isn t a
pretty sight. My books are back again, thanks to you, but they ll never
be the same to me again, and I shan t ever again think night in the
woods is wonderful.
speaker: Leonard

qTextArr: ['Why not?']
qText: Why not?
speaker: Helen

qTextArr: ['Because I see one must have money.']
qText: Because I see one must have money.
speaker: Leonard

qTextArr: ['Well, you re wrong.']
qText: Well, you re wrong.
speaker: Helen

qTextArr:
['I wish I was wrong, but--the clergyman--he has money of his own, or
else he s paid; the poet or the musician--just the same; the tramp--he s
no different. The tramp goes to the workhouse in the end, and is paid
for with other people s money. Miss Schlegel, the real thing s money, and
all the rest is a dream.']
qText:
I wish I was wrong, but--the clergyman--he has money of his own, or
else he s paid; the poet or the musician--just the same; the tramp--he s
no different. The tramp goes to the workhouse in the end, and is paid
for with other people s money. Miss Schlegel, the real thing s money, and
all the rest is a dream.
speaker: Leonard

qTextArr: ['You re still wrong. You ve forgotten Death.']
qText: You re still wrong. You ve forgotten Death.
speaker: Helen

qTextArr:
['If we lived forever, what you say would be true. But we have to die,
we have to leave life presently. Injustice and greed would be the real
thing if we lived for ever. As it is, we must hold to other things,
because Death is coming. I love Death--not morbidly, but because He
explains. He shows me the emptiness of Money. Death and Money are the
eternal foes. Not Death and Life. Never mind what lies behind Death, Mr.
Bast, but be sure that the poet and the musician and the tramp will be
happier in it than the man who has never learnt to say,  I am I.']
qText:
If we lived forever, what you say would be true. But we have to die,
we have to leave life presently. Injustice and greed would be the real
thing if we lived for ever. As it is, we must hold to other things,
because Death is coming. I love Death--not morbidly, but because He
explains. He shows me the emptiness of Money. Death and Money are the
eternal foes. Not Death and Life. Never mind what lies behind Death, Mr.
Bast, but be sure that the poet and the musician and the tramp will be
happier in it than the man who has never learnt to say,  I am I.
speaker: Helen

qTextArr: ['I wonder.']
qText: I wonder.
speaker: Leonard

qTextArr:
['We are all in a mist--I know, but I can help you this far--men like
the Wilcoxes are deeper in the mist than any. Sane, sound Englishmen!
building up empires, levelling all the world into what they call common
sense. But mention Death to them and they re offended, because Death s
really Imperial, and He cries out against them for ever.']
qText:
We are all in a mist--I know, but I can help you this far--men like
the Wilcoxes are deeper in the mist than any. Sane, sound Englishmen!
building up empires, levelling all the world into what they call common
sense. But mention Death to them and they re offended, because Death s
really Imperial, and He cries out against them for ever.
speaker: Helen

qTextArr: ['I am as afraid of Death as any one.']
qText: I am as afraid of Death as any one.
speaker: Leonard

qTextArr: ['But not of the idea of Death.']
qText: But not of the idea of Death.
speaker: Helen

qTextArr: ['But what is the difference?']
qText: But what is the difference?
speaker: Leonard

qTextArr: ['Infinite difference,']
qText: Infinite difference,
speaker: Helen

qTextArr: ['I must be stupid,']
qText: I must be stupid,
speaker: Leonard

qTextArr: ['Death destroys a\nman: the idea of Death saves him.']
qText:
Death destroys a
man: the idea of Death saves him.
speaker: Helen

qTextArr: ['So never give in,']
qText: So never give in,
speaker: Helen

qTextArr: ['I think that ll about do,']
qText: I think that ll about do,
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr: ['Who s there?']
qText: Who s there?
speaker: Henry

qTextArr: ['I have asked Helen to sleep,', 'She is best here; so don t\nlock the front-door.']
qText:
I have asked Helen to sleep, She is best here; so don t
lock the front-door.
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr: ['I thought some one had got in,']
qText: I thought some one had got in,
speaker: Henry

qTextArr: ['At the same time I told the man that we could do nothing for him. I\ndon t know about later, but now the Basts must clearly go.']
qText:
At the same time I told the man that we could do nothing for him. I
don t know about later, but now the Basts must clearly go.
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr: ['Did you say that your sister is sleeping here, after all?']
qText: Did you say that your sister is sleeping here, after all?
speaker: Henry

qTextArr: ['Probably.']
qText: Probably.
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr: ['Is she to be shown up to your room?']
qText: Is she to be shown up to your room?
speaker: Henry

qTextArr: ['I have naturally nothing to say to her; I am going to bed. Will you\ntell the servants about Helen? Could some one go to carry her bag?']
qText:
I have naturally nothing to say to her; I am going to bed. Will you
tell the servants about Helen? Could some one go to carry her bag?
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr: ['You must make more noise than that if you want them to hear.']
qText: You must make more noise than that if you want them to hear.
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr: ['Far\ntoo much screaming there,']
qText:
Far
too much screaming there,
speaker: Henry

qTextArr: ['Henry dear--']
qText: Henry dear--
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr: ['Henry dear, look at me. No, I won t have you shirking. Look at me.\nThere. That s all.']
qText:
Henry dear, look at me. No, I won t have you shirking. Look at me.
There. That s all.
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr: ['You re referring to last evening,', 'I have released\nyou from your engagement. I could find excuses, but I won t. No, I\nwon t. A thousand times no. I m a bad lot, and must be left at that.']
qText:
You re referring to last evening, I have released
you from your engagement. I could find excuses, but I won t. No, I
won t. A thousand times no. I m a bad lot, and must be left at that.
speaker: Henry

qTextArr: ['Leave it where you will, boy. It s not going to trouble us; I know what\nI m talking about, and it will make no difference.']
qText:
Leave it where you will, boy. It s not going to trouble us; I know what
I m talking about, and it will make no difference.
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr: ['No difference?', 'No difference, when you find that I am\nnot the fellow you thought?']
qText:
No difference? No difference, when you find that I am
not the fellow you thought?
speaker: Henry

qTextArr: ['I am unworthy of you,', 'Had I been worthy, I should not have\nreleased you from your engagement. I know what I am talking about. I\ncan t bear to talk of such things. We had better leave it.']
qText:
I am unworthy of you, Had I been worthy, I should not have
released you from your engagement. I know what I am talking about. I
can t bear to talk of such things. We had better leave it.
speaker: Henry

qTextArr: ['You, with your sheltered life, and refined pursuits, and\nfriends, and books, you and your sister, and women like you--I say, how\ncan you guess the temptations that lie round a man?']
qText:
You, with your sheltered life, and refined pursuits, and
friends, and books, you and your sister, and women like you--I say, how
can you guess the temptations that lie round a man?
speaker: Henry
refExp: He jerked it from her and rising to his feet went on

qTextArr: ['It is difficult for us,', 'but if we are worth marrying,\nwe do guess.']
qText:
It is difficult for us, but if we are worth marrying,
we do guess.
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr: ['Cut off from decent society and family ties, what do you suppose\nhappens to thousands of young fellows overseas? Isolated. No one near. I\nknow by bitter experience, and yet you say it makes  no difference.']
qText:
Cut off from decent society and family ties, what do you suppose
happens to thousands of young fellows overseas? Isolated. No one near. I
know by bitter experience, and yet you say it makes  no difference.
speaker: Henry

qTextArr: ['Not to me.']
qText: Not to me.
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr: ['Did Helen come?']
qText: Did Helen come?
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr: ['But that won t do at all, at all! We don t want her gossiping with Mrs.\nBast.']
qText:
But that won t do at all, at all! We don t want her gossiping with Mrs.
Bast.
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr: ['Good God! no!', 'Let them gossip, my game s up, though I thank you for your\nunselfishness--little as my thanks are worth.']
qText:
Good God! no! Let them gossip, my game s up, though I thank you for your
unselfishness--little as my thanks are worth.
speaker: Henry

qTextArr: ['Didn t she send me a message or anything?']
qText: Didn t she send me a message or anything?
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr: ['I heard of none.']
qText: I heard of none.
speaker: Henry

qTextArr: ['Would you ring the bell, please?']
qText: Would you ring the bell, please?
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr: ['What to do?']
qText: What to do?
speaker: Henry

qTextArr: ['Why, to inquire.']
qText: Why, to inquire.
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr: ['I ll go, thank you,']
qText: I ll go, thank you,
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr:
['It is no good,', 'Those things leak out; you cannot stop a
story once it has started. I have known cases of other men--I despised
them once, I thought that I m different, I shall never be tempted. Oh,
Margaret--', 'We fellows all come to grief once in
our time. Will you believe that? There are moments when the strongest
man--', 'That s true,
isn t it? If you knew all, you would excuse me. I was far from good
influences--far even from England. I was very, very lonely, and longed
for a woman s voice. That s enough. I have told you too much already for
you to forgive me now.']
qText:
It is no good, Those things leak out; you cannot stop a
story once it has started. I have known cases of other men--I despised
them once, I thought that I m different, I shall never be tempted. Oh,
Margaret-- We fellows all come to grief once in
our time. Will you believe that? There are moments when the strongest
man-- That s true,
isn t it? If you knew all, you would excuse me. I was far from good
influences--far even from England. I was very, very lonely, and longed
for a woman s voice. That s enough. I have told you too much already for
you to forgive me now.
speaker: Henry

qTextArr: ['Yes, that s enough, dear.']
qText: Yes, that s enough, dear.
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr: ['I have']
qText: I have
speaker: Henry

qTextArr: ['I have been through hell.']
qText: I have been through hell.
speaker: Henry

qTextArr: ['I have already forgiven you, Henry.']
qText: I have already forgiven you, Henry.
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr: ['Well, let them go--the man and his wife, I mean, for the more we see of\nyour sister the better.']
qText:
Well, let them go--the man and his wife, I mean, for the more we see of
your sister the better.
speaker: Henry

qTextArr: ['But they have gone separately--Helen very early, the Basts just before\nI arrived. They have left no message. They have answered neither of my\nnotes. I don t like to think what it all means.']
qText:
But they have gone separately--Helen very early, the Basts just before
I arrived. They have left no message. They have answered neither of my
notes. I don t like to think what it all means.
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr: ['What did you say in the notes?']
qText: What did you say in the notes?
speaker: Henry

qTextArr: ['I told you last night.']
qText: I told you last night.
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr: ['Oh--ah--yes! Dear, would you like one turn in the garden?']
qText: Oh--ah--yes! Dear, would you like one turn in the garden?
speaker: Henry

qTextArr: ['I am afraid there has been gossiping of some kind at the George. Helen\nwould not have left unless she had heard something. I mismanaged that.\nIt is wretched. I ought to have parted her from that woman at once.']
qText:
I am afraid there has been gossiping of some kind at the George. Helen
would not have left unless she had heard something. I mismanaged that.
It is wretched. I ought to have parted her from that woman at once.
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr: ['Margaret!']
qText: Margaret!
speaker: Henry

qTextArr: ['Yes--yes, Henry?']
qText: Yes--yes, Henry?
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr: ['I am far from a saint--in fact, the reverse--but you have taken me, for\nbetter or worse. Bygones must be bygones. You have promised to forgive\nme. Margaret, a promise is a promise. Never mention that woman again.']
qText:
I am far from a saint--in fact, the reverse--but you have taken me, for
better or worse. Bygones must be bygones. You have promised to forgive
me. Margaret, a promise is a promise. Never mention that woman again.
speaker: Henry

qTextArr: ['Except for some practical reason--never.']
qText: Except for some practical reason--never.
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr: ['Practical! You practical!']
qText: Practical! You practical!
speaker: Henry

qTextArr: ['Yes, I m practical,']
qText: Yes, I m practical,
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr: ['At all events, you mustn t worry,', 'This is a man s business.', 'On no account mention it to anybody.']
qText: At all events, you mustn t worry, This is a man s business. On no account mention it to anybody.
speaker: Henry

qTextArr: ['I have come from Oniton,', 'There has been a great deal of\ntrouble there.']
qText:
I have come from Oniton, There has been a great deal of
trouble there.
speaker: Helen

qTextArr: ['Who s for lunch?']
qText: Who s for lunch?
speaker: Tibby

qTextArr: ['Why such an\nearly start?']
qText:
Why such an
early start?
speaker: Tibby

qTextArr: ['Sunrise or something--when I could get away.']
qText: Sunrise or something--when I could get away.
speaker: Helen

qTextArr: ['So I surmise. Why?']
qText: So I surmise. Why?
speaker: Tibby

qTextArr: ['I don t know what s to be done, Tibby. I am very much upset at a piece\nof news that concerns Meg, and do not want to face her, and I am not\ngoing back to Wickham Place. I stopped here to tell you this.']
qText:
I don t know what s to be done, Tibby. I am very much upset at a piece
of news that concerns Meg, and do not want to face her, and I am not
going back to Wickham Place. I stopped here to tell you this.
speaker: Helen

qTextArr: ['Give Meg my love and say that I want to be alone. I mean to go to\nMunich or else Bonn.']
qText:
Give Meg my love and say that I want to be alone. I mean to go to
Munich or else Bonn.
speaker: Helen

qTextArr: ['Such a message is easily given,']
qText: Such a message is easily given,
speaker: Tibby

qTextArr:
['As regards Wickham Place and my share of the furniture, you and she are
to do exactly as you like. My own feeling is that everything may just as
well be sold. What does one want with dusty economic books, which have
made the world no better, or with mother s hideous chiffoniers? I have
also another commission for you. I want you to deliver a letter.']
qText:
As regards Wickham Place and my share of the furniture, you and she are
to do exactly as you like. My own feeling is that everything may just as
well be sold. What does one want with dusty economic books, which have
made the world no better, or with mother s hideous chiffoniers? I have
also another commission for you. I want you to deliver a letter.
speaker: Helen

qTextArr: ['I haven t written it yet. Why shouldn t I post it, though?']
qText: I haven t written it yet. Why shouldn t I post it, though?
speaker: Helen

qTextArr: ['My head is rather wretched. I hope that none of your\nfriends are likely to come in.']
qText:
My head is rather wretched. I hope that none of your
friends are likely to come in.
speaker: Helen

qTextArr: ['Not there,']
qText: Not there,
speaker: Helen

qTextArr: ['Do you mind Mrs.\nMartlett coming in?', 'or shall I take it from her at the\ndoor?']
qText:
Do you mind Mrs.
Martlett coming in? or shall I take it from her at the
door?
speaker: Tibby

qTextArr: ['Could I bathe my eyes, Tibby?']
qText: Could I bathe my eyes, Tibby?
speaker: Helen

qTextArr:
['Now for the explanation,', 'Why didn t I begin with it? I
have found out something about Mr. Wilcox. He has behaved very wrongly
indeed, and ruined two people s lives. It all came on me very suddenly
last night; I am very much upset, and I do not know what to do. Mrs.
Bast--']
qText:
Now for the explanation, Why didn t I begin with it? I
have found out something about Mr. Wilcox. He has behaved very wrongly
indeed, and ruined two people s lives. It all came on me very suddenly
last night; I am very much upset, and I do not know what to do. Mrs.
Bast--
speaker: Helen

qTextArr: ['Oh, those people!']
qText: Oh, those people!
speaker: Tibby

qTextArr: ['Shall I lock the door again?']
qText: Shall I lock the door again?
speaker: Tibby

qTextArr:
['No thanks, Tibbikins. You re being very good to me. I want to tell you
the story before I go abroad, you must do exactly what you like--treat
it as part of the furniture. Meg cannot have heard it yet, I think. But
I cannot face her and tell her that the man she is going to marry has
misconducted himself. I don t even know whether she ought to be told.
Knowing as she does that I dislike him, she will suspect me, and think
that I want to ruin her match. I simply don t know what to make of such
a thing. I trust your judgment. What would you do?']
qText:
No thanks, Tibbikins. You re being very good to me. I want to tell you
the story before I go abroad, you must do exactly what you like--treat
it as part of the furniture. Meg cannot have heard it yet, I think. But
I cannot face her and tell her that the man she is going to marry has
misconducted himself. I don t even know whether she ought to be told.
Knowing as she does that I dislike him, she will suspect me, and think
that I want to ruin her match. I simply don t know what to make of such
a thing. I trust your judgment. What would you do?
speaker: Helen
menTexts: [['Tibbikins', 'You', 'you', 'you', 'you', 'Meg', 'her', 'her', 'the man she is going to marry', 'she', 'she', 'she', 'him', 'she', 'her', 'you']]

qTextArr: ['I gather he has had a mistress,']
qText: I gather he has had a mistress,
speaker: Tibby

qTextArr:
['And ruined two people s lives. And
goes about saying that personal actions count for nothing, and there
always will be rich and poor. He met her when he was trying to get rich
out in Cyprus--I don t wish to make him worse than he is, and no doubt
she was ready enough to meet him. But there it is. They met. He goes his
way and she goes hers. What do you suppose is the end of such women?']
qText:
And ruined two people s lives. And
goes about saying that personal actions count for nothing, and there
always will be rich and poor. He met her when he was trying to get rich
out in Cyprus--I don t wish to make him worse than he is, and no doubt
she was ready enough to meet him. But there it is. They met. He goes his
way and she goes hers. What do you suppose is the end of such women?
speaker: Helen

qTextArr:
['They end in two ways: Either they sink till the lunatic asylums and the
workhouses are full of them, and cause Mr. Wilcox to write letters to
the papers complaining of our national degeneracy, or else they entrap a
boy into marriage before it is too late. She--I can t blame her.']
qText:
They end in two ways: Either they sink till the lunatic asylums and the
workhouses are full of them, and cause Mr. Wilcox to write letters to
the papers complaining of our national degeneracy, or else they entrap a
boy into marriage before it is too late. She--I can t blame her.
speaker: Helen

qTextArr:
['But this isn t all,', 'I come now to the business that took
us to Oniton. We went all three. Acting on Mr. Wilcox s advice, the man
throws up a secure situation and takes an insecure one, from which he is
dismissed. There are certain excuses, but in the main Mr. Wilcox is to
blame, as Meg herself admitted. It is only common justice that he should
employ the man himself. But he meets the woman, and, like the cur that
he is, he refuses, and tries to get rid of them. He makes Meg write.
Two notes came from her late that evening--one for me, one for Leonard,
dismissing him with barely a reason. I couldn t understand. Then it
comes out that Mrs. Bast had spoken to Mr. Wilcox on the lawn while we
left her to get rooms, and was still speaking about him when Leonard
came back to her. This Leonard knew all along. He thought it natural he
should be ruined twice. Natural! Could you have contained yourself?']
qText:
But this isn t all, I come now to the business that took
us to Oniton. We went all three. Acting on Mr. Wilcox s advice, the man
throws up a secure situation and takes an insecure one, from which he is
dismissed. There are certain excuses, but in the main Mr. Wilcox is to
blame, as Meg herself admitted. It is only common justice that he should
employ the man himself. But he meets the woman, and, like the cur that
he is, he refuses, and tries to get rid of them. He makes Meg write.
Two notes came from her late that evening--one for me, one for Leonard,
dismissing him with barely a reason. I couldn t understand. Then it
comes out that Mrs. Bast had spoken to Mr. Wilcox on the lawn while we
left her to get rooms, and was still speaking about him when Leonard
came back to her. This Leonard knew all along. He thought it natural he
should be ruined twice. Natural! Could you have contained yourself?
speaker: Helen
menTexts: [[], ['We', 'Mr. Wilcox', 'the man', 'he', 'Mr. Wilcox', 'Meg', 'he', 'the man', 'he', 'the woman', 'he', 'he', 'them', 'He', 'Meg', 'Leonard', 'him', 'Mrs. Bast', 'Mr. Wilcox', 'we', 'her', 'him', 'Leonard', 'her', 'Leonard', 'He', 'he', 'you']]

qTextArr: ['It is certainly a very bad business,']
qText: It is certainly a very bad business,
speaker: Tibby

qTextArr:
['I was afraid that I saw it out of
proportion. But you are right outside it, and you must know. In a day or
two--or perhaps a week--take whatever steps you think fit. I leave it in
your hands.']
qText:
I was afraid that I saw it out of
proportion. But you are right outside it, and you must know. In a day or
two--or perhaps a week--take whatever steps you think fit. I leave it in
your hands.
speaker: Helen

qTextArr: ['The facts as they touch Meg are all before you,']
qText: The facts as they touch Meg are all before you,
speaker: Helen

qTextArr: ['You see, Helen--have a cigarette--I don t see what I m to do.']
qText: You see, Helen--have a cigarette--I don t see what I m to do.
speaker: Tibby

qTextArr: ['Then there s nothing to be done. I dare say you are right. Let them\nmarry. There remains the question of compensation.']
qText:
Then there s nothing to be done. I dare say you are right. Let them
marry. There remains the question of compensation.
speaker: Helen

qTextArr: ['Do you want me to adjudicate that too? Had you not better consult an\nexpert?']
qText:
Do you want me to adjudicate that too? Had you not better consult an
expert?
speaker: Tibby

qTextArr:
['This part is in confidence,', 'It has nothing to do with
Meg, and do not mention it to her. The compensation--I do not see who is
to pay it if I don t, and I have already decided on the minimum sum.
As soon as possible I am placing it to your account, and when I am in
Germany you will pay it over for me. I shall never forget your kindness,
Tibbikins, if you do this.']
qText:
This part is in confidence, It has nothing to do with
Meg, and do not mention it to her. The compensation--I do not see who is
to pay it if I don t, and I have already decided on the minimum sum.
As soon as possible I am placing it to your account, and when I am in
Germany you will pay it over for me. I shall never forget your kindness,
Tibbikins, if you do this.
speaker: Helen

qTextArr: ['What is the sum?']
qText: What is the sum?
speaker: Tibby

qTextArr: ['Five thousand.']
qText: Five thousand.
speaker: Helen

qTextArr: ['Good God alive!']
qText: Good God alive!
speaker: Tibby

qTextArr:
['Now, what is the good of driblets? To go through life having done one
thing--to have raised one person from the abyss; not these puny gifts of
shillings and blankets--making the grey more grey. No doubt people will
think me extraordinary.']
qText:
Now, what is the good of driblets? To go through life having done one
thing--to have raised one person from the abyss; not these puny gifts of
shillings and blankets--making the grey more grey. No doubt people will
think me extraordinary.
speaker: Helen

qTextArr: ['I don t care an iota what people think!', 'But it s half what you have.']
qText: I don t care an iota what people think! But it s half what you have.
speaker: Tibby

qTextArr: ['Not nearly half.']
qText: Not nearly half.
speaker: Helen

qTextArr:
['I
have far too much, and we settled at Chelsea last spring that three
hundred a year is necessary to set a man on his feet. What I give will
bring in a hundred and fifty between two. It isn t enough.']
qText:
I
have far too much, and we settled at Chelsea last spring that three
hundred a year is necessary to set a man on his feet. What I give will
bring in a hundred and fifty between two. It isn t enough.
speaker: Helen

qTextArr: ['I didn t expect you to understand me.']
qText: I didn t expect you to understand me.
speaker: Helen

qTextArr: ['I? I understand nobody.']
qText: I? I understand nobody.
speaker: Tibby

qTextArr: ['But you ll do it?']
qText: But you ll do it?
speaker: Helen

qTextArr: ['Apparently.']
qText: Apparently.
speaker: Tibby

qTextArr:
['I leave you two commissions, then. The first concerns Mr. Wilcox, and
you are to use your discretion. The second concerns the money, and is
to be mentioned to no one, and carried out literally. You will send a
hundred pounds on account to-morrow.']
qText:
I leave you two commissions, then. The first concerns Mr. Wilcox, and
you are to use your discretion. The second concerns the money, and is
to be mentioned to no one, and carried out literally. You will send a
hundred pounds on account to-morrow.
speaker: Helen

qTextArr: ['Does that seem to you so odd?']
qText: Does that seem to you so odd?
speaker: Helen
refExp: She stopped like a frightened animal and said

qTextArr: ['Did she\nseem worried at any rumour about Henry?']
qText:
Did she
seem worried at any rumour about Henry?
speaker: Margaret

qText: Yes.
speaker: Tibby

qTextArr: ['I knew it\nwas that!', 'I ll write to her.']
qText:
I knew it
was that! I ll write to her.
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr: ['I didn t want to bother you,', 'Besides, I have only heard\nfor certain this morning.']
qText:
I didn t want to bother you, Besides, I have only heard
for certain this morning.
speaker: Henry

qTextArr: ['Where are we to live?', 'I loved the\nplace extraordinarily. Don t you believe in having a permanent home,\nHenry?']
qText:
Where are we to live? I loved the
place extraordinarily. Don t you believe in having a permanent home,
Henry?
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr: ['This is news. I never heard till this minute that Oniton was damp.']
qText: This is news. I never heard till this minute that Oniton was damp.
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr: ['My dear girl!']
qText: My dear girl!
speaker: Henry

qTextArr:
['have you eyes? have you a skin?
How could it be anything but damp in such a situation? In the first
place, the Grange is on clay, and built where the castle moat must have
been; then there s that detestable little river, steaming all night like
a kettle. Feel the cellar walls; look up under the eaves. Ask Sir James
or any one. Those Shropshire valleys are notorious. The only possible
place for a house in Shropshire is on a hill; but, for my part, I think
the country is too far from London, and the scenery nothing special.']
qText:
have you eyes? have you a skin?
How could it be anything but damp in such a situation? In the first
place, the Grange is on clay, and built where the castle moat must have
been; then there s that detestable little river, steaming all night like
a kettle. Feel the cellar walls; look up under the eaves. Ask Sir James
or any one. Those Shropshire valleys are notorious. The only possible
place for a house in Shropshire is on a hill; but, for my part, I think
the country is too far from London, and the scenery nothing special.
speaker: Henry

qTextArr: ['Why did you go there, then?']
qText: Why did you go there, then?
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr: ['I--because--']
qText: I--because--
speaker: Henry

qTextArr: ['Why have\nwe come to the Tyrol, if it comes to that? One might go on asking such\nquestions indefinitely.']
qText:
Why have
we come to the Tyrol, if it comes to that? One might go on asking such
questions indefinitely.
speaker: Henry

qTextArr: ['The truth is, I took Oniton on account of Evie. Don t let this go any\nfurther.']
qText:
The truth is, I took Oniton on account of Evie. Don t let this go any
further.
speaker: Henry

qTextArr: ['Certainly not.']
qText: Certainly not.
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr:
['I shouldn t like her to know that she nearly let me in for a very bad
bargain. No sooner did I sign the agreement than she got engaged. Poor
little girl! She was so keen on it all, and wouldn t even wait to
make proper inquiries about the shooting. Afraid it would get snapped
up--just like all of your sex. Well, no harm s done. She has had her
country wedding, and I ve got rid of my goose to some fellows who are
starting a preparatory school.']
qText:
I shouldn t like her to know that she nearly let me in for a very bad
bargain. No sooner did I sign the agreement than she got engaged. Poor
little girl! She was so keen on it all, and wouldn t even wait to
make proper inquiries about the shooting. Afraid it would get snapped
up--just like all of your sex. Well, no harm s done. She has had her
country wedding, and I ve got rid of my goose to some fellows who are
starting a preparatory school.
speaker: Henry

qTextArr: ['Where shall we live, then, Henry? I should enjoy living somewhere.']
qText: Where shall we live, then, Henry? I should enjoy living somewhere.
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr: ['I have not yet decided. What about Norfolk?']
qText: I have not yet decided. What about Norfolk?
speaker: Henry

qTextArr: ['It is now what?', 'Nearly October. Let us camp for the\nwinter at Ducie Street, and look out for something in the spring.']
qText:
It is now what? Nearly October. Let us camp for the
winter at Ducie Street, and look out for something in the spring.
speaker: Henry

qTextArr: ['If possible, something permanent. I can t be as young as I was, for\nthese alterations don t suit me.']
qText:
If possible, something permanent. I can t be as young as I was, for
these alterations don t suit me.
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr: ['But, my dear, which would you rather have--alterations or rheumatism?']
qText: But, my dear, which would you rather have--alterations or rheumatism?
speaker: Henry

qTextArr:
['I see your point,', 'If Oniton is really
damp, it is impossible, and must be inhabited by little boys. Only, in
the spring, let us look before we leap. I will take warning by Evie,
and not hurry you. Remember that you have a free hand this time.
These endless moves must be bad for the furniture, and are certainly
expensive.']
qText:
I see your point, If Oniton is really
damp, it is impossible, and must be inhabited by little boys. Only, in
the spring, let us look before we leap. I will take warning by Evie,
and not hurry you. Remember that you have a free hand this time.
These endless moves must be bad for the furniture, and are certainly
expensive.
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr: ['What a practical little woman it is! What s it been reading?\nTheo--theo--how much?']
qText:
What a practical little woman it is! What s it been reading?
Theo--theo--how much?
speaker: Henry

qTextArr: ['Theosophy.']
qText: Theosophy.
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr: ['Have you heard the news?', 'Charles is so ang--I mean he is sure you know about it, or, rather, that\nyou don t know.']
qText:
Have you heard the news? Charles is so ang--I mean he is sure you know about it, or, rather, that
you don t know.
speaker: Dolly

qTextArr: ['Why, Dolly!', 'Here s a surprise!\nHow are the boys and the baby?']
qText:
Why, Dolly! Here s a surprise!
How are the boys and the baby?
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr: ['But lucky you, with four courts of your own at Midhurst.']
qText: But lucky you, with four courts of your own at Midhurst.
speaker: Dolly

qTextArr: ['It will be very jolly,']
qText: It will be very jolly,
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr: ['Are those the plans? Does it matter my seeing them?']
qText: Are those the plans? Does it matter my seeing them?
speaker: Dolly

qTextArr: ['Of course not.']
qText: Of course not.
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr: ['Charles has never seen the plans.']
qText: Charles has never seen the plans.
speaker: Dolly

qTextArr: ['They have only just arrived. Here is the ground floor--no, that s\nrather difficult. Try the elevation. We are to have a good many gables\nand a picturesque sky-line.']
qText:
They have only just arrived. Here is the ground floor--no, that s
rather difficult. Try the elevation. We are to have a good many gables
and a picturesque sky-line.
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr: ['What makes it smell so funny?']
qText: What makes it smell so funny?
speaker: Dolly

qTextArr: ['I suppose the paper.']
qText: I suppose the paper.
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr: ['And WHICH way up is it?']
qText: And WHICH way up is it?
speaker: Dolly

qTextArr: ['Just the ordinary way up. That s the sky-line and the part that smells\nstrongest is the sky.']
qText:
Just the ordinary way up. That s the sky-line and the part that smells
strongest is the sky.
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr: ['Well, ask me another. Margaret--oh--what was I going to say? How s\nHelen?']
qText:
Well, ask me another. Margaret--oh--what was I going to say? How s
Helen?
speaker: Dolly

qTextArr: ['Quite well.']
qText: Quite well.
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr: ['Is she never coming back to England? Every one thinks it s awfully odd\nshe doesn t.']
qText:
Is she never coming back to England? Every one thinks it s awfully odd
she doesn t.
speaker: Dolly

qTextArr: ['So it is,', 'Helen is odd, awfully. She has now\nbeen away eight months.']
qText:
So it is, Helen is odd, awfully. She has now
been away eight months.
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr: ['But hasn t she any address?']
qText: But hasn t she any address?
speaker: Dolly

qTextArr: ['A poste restante somewhere in Bavaria is her address. Do write her a\nline. I will look it up for you.']
qText:
A poste restante somewhere in Bavaria is her address. Do write her a
line. I will look it up for you.
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr: ['No, don t bother. That s eight months she has been away, surely?']
qText: No, don t bother. That s eight months she has been away, surely?
speaker: Dolly

qTextArr: ['Exactly. She left just after Evie s wedding. It would be eight months.']
qText: Exactly. She left just after Evie s wedding. It would be eight months.
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr: ['Just when baby was born, then?']
qText: Just when baby was born, then?
speaker: Dolly

qTextArr: ['Just so.']
qText: Just so.
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr: ['Oh, yes,', 'that is it: Miss Avery has been unpacking your\npacking-cases.']
qText:
Oh, yes, that is it: Miss Avery has been unpacking your
packing-cases.
speaker: Dolly

qTextArr: ['Why has she done that? How unnecessary!']
qText: Why has she done that? How unnecessary!
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr: ['Ask another. I suppose you ordered her to.']
qText: Ask another. I suppose you ordered her to.
speaker: Dolly

qTextArr: ['I gave no such orders. Perhaps she was airing the things. She did\nundertake to light an occasional fire.']
qText:
