I gave no such orders. Perhaps she was airing the things. She did
undertake to light an occasional fire.
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr: ['It was far more than an air,', 'The floor sounds\ncovered with books. Charles sent me to know what is to be done, for he\nfeels certain you don t know.']
qText:
It was far more than an air, The floor sounds
covered with books. Charles sent me to know what is to be done, for he
feels certain you don t know.
speaker: Dolly

qTextArr: ['Books!', 'Dolly, are you\nserious? Has she been touching our books?']
qText:
Books! Dolly, are you
serious? Has she been touching our books?
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr: ['Hasn t she, though! What used to be the hall s full of them. Charles\nthought for certain you knew of it.']
qText:
Hasn t she, though! What used to be the hall s full of them. Charles
thought for certain you knew of it.
speaker: Dolly

qTextArr:
['I am very much obliged to you, Dolly. What can have come over Miss
Avery? I must go down about it at once. Some of the books are my
brother s, and are quite valuable. She had no right to open any of the
cases.']
qText:
I am very much obliged to you, Dolly. What can have come over Miss
Avery? I must go down about it at once. Some of the books are my
brother s, and are quite valuable. She had no right to open any of the
cases.
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr:
['I say she s dotty. She was the one that never got married, you know.
Oh, I say, perhaps, she thinks your books are wedding-presents to
herself. Old maids are taken that way sometimes. Miss Avery hates us all
like poison ever since her frightful dust-up with Evie.']
qText:
I say she s dotty. She was the one that never got married, you know.
Oh, I say, perhaps, she thinks your books are wedding-presents to
herself. Old maids are taken that way sometimes. Miss Avery hates us all
like poison ever since her frightful dust-up with Evie.
speaker: Dolly
menEnts: [[['Miss Avery'], ['Miss Avery'], ['Margaret'], ['Miss Avery'], ['Margaret'], ['Miss Avery'], ['Charles Wilcox', 'Henry', 'Evie', 'Dolly'], ['Miss Avery'], ['Evie']]]

qTextArr: ['I hadn t heard of that,']
qText: I hadn t heard of that,
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr: ['Didn t you know she gave Evie a present last August, and Evie returned\nit, and then--oh, goloshes! You never read such a letter as Miss Avery\nwrote.']
qText:
Didn t you know she gave Evie a present last August, and Evie returned
it, and then--oh, goloshes! You never read such a letter as Miss Avery
wrote.
speaker: Dolly

qTextArr: ['But it was wrong of Evie to return it. It wasn t like her to do such a\nheartless thing.']
qText:
But it was wrong of Evie to return it. It wasn t like her to do such a
heartless thing.
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr: ['But the present was so expensive.']
qText: But the present was so expensive.
speaker: Dolly

qTextArr: ['Why does that make any difference, Dolly?']
qText: Why does that make any difference, Dolly?
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr: ['Still, when it costs over five pounds--I didn t see it, but it was\na lovely enamel pendant from a Bond Street shop. You can t very well\naccept that kind of thing from a farm woman. Now, can you?']
qText:
Still, when it costs over five pounds--I didn t see it, but it was
a lovely enamel pendant from a Bond Street shop. You can t very well
accept that kind of thing from a farm woman. Now, can you?
speaker: Dolly

qTextArr: ['You accepted a present from Miss Avery when you were married.']
qText: You accepted a present from Miss Avery when you were married.
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr:
['Oh, mine was old earthenware stuff--not worth a halfpenny. Evie s was
quite different. You d have to ask any one to the wedding who gave you
a pendant like that. Uncle Percy and Albert and father and Charles all
said it was quite impossible, and when four men agree, what is a girl to
do? Evie didn t want to upset the old thing, so thought a sort of joking
letter best, and returned the pendant straight to the shop to save Miss
Avery trouble.']
qText:
Oh, mine was old earthenware stuff--not worth a halfpenny. Evie s was
quite different. You d have to ask any one to the wedding who gave you
a pendant like that. Uncle Percy and Albert and father and Charles all
said it was quite impossible, and when four men agree, what is a girl to
do? Evie didn t want to upset the old thing, so thought a sort of joking
letter best, and returned the pendant straight to the shop to save Miss
Avery trouble.
speaker: Dolly

qTextArr: ['But Miss Avery said--']
qText: But Miss Avery said--
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr: ['It was a perfectly awful letter. Charles said\nit was the letter of a madman. In the end she had the pendant back again\nfrom the shop and threw it into the duck-pond.']
qText:
It was a perfectly awful letter. Charles said
it was the letter of a madman. In the end she had the pendant back again
from the shop and threw it into the duck-pond.
speaker: Dolly

qTextArr: ['Did she give any reasons?']
qText: Did she give any reasons?
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr: ['We think she meant to be invited to Oniton, and so climb into society.']
qText: We think she meant to be invited to Oniton, and so climb into society.
speaker: Dolly

qTextArr: ['She s rather old for that,', 'May she not have\ngiven the present to Evie in remembrance of her mother?']
qText:
She s rather old for that, May she not have
given the present to Evie in remembrance of her mother?
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr: ['That s a notion. Give every one their due, eh? Well, I suppose I ought\nto be toddling. Come along, Mr. Muff--you want a new coat, but I don t\nknow who ll give it you, I m sure;']
speaker: Dolly

qTextArr: ['Oh yes.']
qText: Oh yes.
speaker: Dolly

qTextArr: ['I wonder, then, why he let me ask her to look after the house.']
qText: I wonder, then, why he let me ask her to look after the house.
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr: ['But she s only a farm woman,']
qText: But she s only a farm woman,
speaker: Dolly

qTextArr: ['I have patience with a man who knows his job,']
qText: I have patience with a man who knows his job,
speaker: Henry

qTextArr: ['Left to itself,', 'this county would vote\nLiberal.']
qText:
Left to itself, this county would vote
Liberal.
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr:
['Yes, Mrs. Wilcox; no, Mrs. Wilcox; oh yes, Mrs.
Wilcox, auntie received your letter quite duly. Auntie has gone up to
your little place at the present moment. Shall I send the servant to
direct you?']
qText:
Yes, Mrs. Wilcox; no, Mrs. Wilcox; oh yes, Mrs.
Wilcox, auntie received your letter quite duly. Auntie has gone up to
your little place at the present moment. Shall I send the servant to
direct you?
speaker: Madge

qTextArr:
['Of course, auntie does not generally look
after your place; she only does it to oblige a neighbour as something
exceptional. It gives her something to do. She spends quite a lot of her
time there. My husband says to me sometimes,']
qText:
Of course, auntie does not generally look
after your place; she only does it to oblige a neighbour as something
exceptional. It gives her something to do. She spends quite a lot of her
time there. My husband says to me sometimes,
speaker: Madge

qTextArr: ['I say,']
qText: I say,
speaker: Madge

qTextArr: ['Yes, Mrs. Wilcox. Mrs. Wilcox,\ncould I prevail upon you to accept a piece of cake? Not if I cut it for\nyou?']
qText:
Yes, Mrs. Wilcox. Mrs. Wilcox,
could I prevail upon you to accept a piece of cake? Not if I cut it for
you?
speaker: Madge

qTextArr: ['I cannot let you go on alone. Now don t. You really mustn t. I\nwill direct you myself if it comes to that. I must get my hat.\nNow']
qText:
I cannot let you go on alone. Now don t. You really mustn t. I
will direct you myself if it comes to that. I must get my hat.
Now
speaker: Madge

qTextArr: ['Mrs. Wilcox, don t you move while I m gone.']
qText: Mrs. Wilcox, don t you move while I m gone.
speaker: Madge

qTextArr: ['Auntie!']
qText: Auntie!
speaker: Madge

qTextArr: ['Are you sure that Miss Avery is up here?']
qText: Are you sure that Miss Avery is up here?
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr: ['Oh, yes, Mrs. Wilcox, quite sure. She is here daily.']
qText: Oh, yes, Mrs. Wilcox, quite sure. She is here daily.
speaker: Madge

qTextArr: ['Well, well!', 'If it isn t Mrs.\nWilcox come at last!']
qText:
Well, well! If it isn t Mrs.
Wilcox come at last!
speaker: Miss Avery

qTextArr: ['Have you got the key, auntie?']
qText: Have you got the key, auntie?
speaker: Madge

qTextArr: ['Madge, go away,']
qText: Madge, go away,
speaker: Miss Avery

qTextArr: ['Auntie, it s Mrs. Wilcox--']
qText: Auntie, it s Mrs. Wilcox--
speaker: Madge

qTextArr: ['Your niece and I have come together.']
qText: Your niece and I have come together.
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr: ['Madge, go away. This is no moment for your hat.']
qText: Madge, go away. This is no moment for your hat.
speaker: Miss Avery

qTextArr: ['Auntie gets more eccentric lately,']
qText: Auntie gets more eccentric lately,
speaker: Madge

qTextArr: ['Miss Avery!', 'I have come about the furniture. Could\nyou kindly let me in?']
qText:
Miss Avery! I have come about the furniture. Could
you kindly let me in?
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr: ['Yes, Mrs. Wilcox,', 'of course.']
qText: Yes, Mrs. Wilcox, of course.
speaker: Miss Avery

qTextArr: ['I hope Miss Avery is not ill,']
qText: I hope Miss Avery is not ill,
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr: ['Well, if you ll excuse me,', 'perhaps I ought to be leaving\nyou now. The servants need seeing to at the farm. Auntie is so odd at\ntimes.']
qText:
Well, if you ll excuse me, perhaps I ought to be leaving
you now. The servants need seeing to at the farm. Auntie is so odd at
times.
speaker: Madge

qTextArr: ['Well, come right in, Mrs. Wilcox!']
qText: Well, come right in, Mrs. Wilcox!
speaker: Miss Avery

qTextArr: ['Thank you so much,']
qText: Thank you so much,
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr: ['Come right into the hall first,']
qText: Come right into the hall first,
speaker: Miss Avery

qTextArr:
['I m afraid this isn t what we meant,', 'Mr. Wilcox and I
never intended the cases to be touched. For instance, these books are my
brother s. We are storing them for him and for my sister, who is abroad.
When you kindly undertook to look after things, we never expected you to
do so much.']
qText:
I m afraid this isn t what we meant, Mr. Wilcox and I
never intended the cases to be touched. For instance, these books are my
brother s. We are storing them for him and for my sister, who is abroad.
When you kindly undertook to look after things, we never expected you to
do so much.
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr: ['The house has been empty long enough,']
qText: The house has been empty long enough,
speaker: Miss Avery

qTextArr: ['I dare say we didn t explain,', 'It has been a mistake, and very likely our mistake.']
qText: I dare say we didn t explain, It has been a mistake, and very likely our mistake.
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr: ['Mrs. Wilcox, it has been mistake upon mistake for fifty years. The\nhouse is Mrs. Wilcox s, and she would not desire it to stand empty any\nlonger.']
qText:
Mrs. Wilcox, it has been mistake upon mistake for fifty years. The
house is Mrs. Wilcox s, and she would not desire it to stand empty any
longer.
speaker: Miss Avery

qTextArr: ['Yes, Mrs. Wilcox s house, the mother of Mr. Charles.']
qText: Yes, Mrs. Wilcox s house, the mother of Mr. Charles.
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr: ['Mistake upon mistake,', 'Mistake upon mistake.']
qText: Mistake upon mistake, Mistake upon mistake.
speaker: Miss Avery

qTextArr: ['Well, I don t know,', 'I really don t know what s to be done.']
qText: Well, I don t know, I really don t know what s to be done.
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr: ['Yes, it should be a merry house enough.']
qText: Yes, it should be a merry house enough.
speaker: Miss Avery

qTextArr: ['I don t know--I dare say. Well, thank you very much, Miss Avery. Yes,\nthat s all right. Delightful.']
qText:
I don t know--I dare say. Well, thank you very much, Miss Avery. Yes,
that s all right. Delightful.
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr: ['There is still the parlour.']
qText: There is still the parlour.
speaker: Miss Avery

qTextArr: ['And the dining-room.']
qText: And the dining-room.
speaker: Miss Avery

qTextArr: ['Then through here--']
qText: Then through here--
speaker: Miss Avery

qTextArr:
['I ve not finished
here yet,', 'There s still a deal to do. The
farm lads will carry your great wardrobes upstairs, for there is no need
to go into expense at Hilton.']
qText:
I ve not finished
here yet, There s still a deal to do. The
farm lads will carry your great wardrobes upstairs, for there is no need
to go into expense at Hilton.
speaker: Miss Avery

qTextArr: ['It is all a mistake,', 'A misunderstanding. Mr. Wilcox and I are not going to live\nat Howards End.']
qText:
It is all a mistake, A misunderstanding. Mr. Wilcox and I are not going to live
at Howards End.
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr: ['Oh, indeed! On account of his hay fever?']
qText: Oh, indeed! On account of his hay fever?
speaker: Miss Avery

qTextArr: ['We have settled to build a new home for ourselves in Sussex, and part\nof this furniture--my part--will go down there presently.']
qText:
We have settled to build a new home for ourselves in Sussex, and part
of this furniture--my part--will go down there presently.
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr: ['You think that you won t come back to live here, Mrs. Wilcox,\nbut you will.']
qText:
You think that you won t come back to live here, Mrs. Wilcox,
but you will.
speaker: Miss Avery

qTextArr:
['That remains to be seen,', 'We have no intention
of doing so for the present. We happen to need a much larger house.
Circumstances oblige us to give big parties. Of course, some day--one
never knows, does one?']
qText:
That remains to be seen, We have no intention
of doing so for the present. We happen to need a much larger house.
Circumstances oblige us to give big parties. Of course, some day--one
never knows, does one?
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr: ['Some day! Tcha! tcha! Don t talk about some day.\nYou are living here now.']
qText:
Some day! Tcha! tcha! Don t talk about some day.
You are living here now.
speaker: Miss Avery

qText: Am I?
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr: ['You are living here, and have been for the last ten minutes, if you ask\nme.']
qText:
You are living here, and have been for the last ten minutes, if you ask
me.
speaker: Miss Avery

qTextArr: ['The nursery,']
qText: The nursery,
speaker: Miss Avery

qTextArr: ['It s a beautiful meadow,']
qText: It s a beautiful meadow,
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr:
['Yes, the maidy s well enough,', 'for those, that is,
who don t suffer from sneezing.', 'I ve
seen Charlie Wilcox go out to my lads in hay time--oh, they ought to do
this--they mustn t do that--he d learn them to be lads. And just then
the tickling took him. He has it from his father, with other things.
There s not one Wilcox that can stand up against a field in June--I
laughed fit to burst while he was courting Ruth.']
qText:
Yes, the maidy s well enough, for those, that is,
who don t suffer from sneezing. I ve
seen Charlie Wilcox go out to my lads in hay time--oh, they ought to do
this--they mustn t do that--he d learn them to be lads. And just then
the tickling took him. He has it from his father, with other things.
There s not one Wilcox that can stand up against a field in June--I
laughed fit to burst while he was courting Ruth.
speaker: Miss Avery

qTextArr: ['My brother gets hay fever too,']
qText: My brother gets hay fever too,
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr: ['This house lies too much on the land for them. Naturally, they were\nglad enough to slip in at first. But Wilcoxes are better than nothing,\nas I see you ve found.']
qText:
This house lies too much on the land for them. Naturally, they were
glad enough to slip in at first. But Wilcoxes are better than nothing,
as I see you ve found.
speaker: Miss Avery

qTextArr: ['They keep a place going, don t they? Yes, it is just that.']
qText: They keep a place going, don t they? Yes, it is just that.
speaker: Miss Avery

qTextArr: ['They keep England going, it is my opinion.']
qText: They keep England going, it is my opinion.
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr:
['Ay, they breed like rabbits.
Well, well, it s a funny world. But He who made it knows what He wants
in it, I suppose. If Mrs. Charlie is expecting her fourth, it isn t for
us to repine.']
qText:
Ay, they breed like rabbits.
Well, well, it s a funny world. But He who made it knows what He wants
in it, I suppose. If Mrs. Charlie is expecting her fourth, it isn t for
us to repine.
speaker: Miss Avery
refExp: Miss Avery upset her by replying

qTextArr: ['They breed and they also work,', 'It certainly is a funny world, but so long as men\nlike my husband and his sons govern it, I think it ll never be a bad\none--never really bad.']
qText:
They breed and they also work, It certainly is a funny world, but so long as men
like my husband and his sons govern it, I think it ll never be a bad
one--never really bad.
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr: ['No, better n nothing,']
qText: No, better n nothing,
speaker: Miss Avery

qTextArr:
['I
never saw much of Ruth after her grandmother died, but we stayed civil.
It was a very civil family. Old Mrs. Howard never spoke against
anybody, nor let any one be turned away without food. Then it was never
 Trespassers will be prosecuted  in their land, but would people please
not come in? Mrs. Howard was never created to run a farm.']
qText:
I
never saw much of Ruth after her grandmother died, but we stayed civil.
It was a very civil family. Old Mrs. Howard never spoke against
anybody, nor let any one be turned away without food. Then it was never
 Trespassers will be prosecuted  in their land, but would people please
not come in? Mrs. Howard was never created to run a farm.
speaker: Miss Avery

qTextArr: ['Had they no men to help them?']
qText: Had they no men to help them?
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr: ['Things went on until there were no men.']
qText: Things went on until there were no men.
speaker: Miss Avery

qTextArr: ['Until Mr. Wilcox came along,']
qText: Until Mr. Wilcox came along,
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr: ['I suppose so; but Ruth should have married a--no disrespect to you to\nsay this, for I take it you were intended to get Wilcox any way, whether\nshe got him first or no.']
qText:
I suppose so; but Ruth should have married a--no disrespect to you to
say this, for I take it you were intended to get Wilcox any way, whether
she got him first or no.
speaker: Miss Avery

qTextArr: ['Whom should she have married?']
qText: Whom should she have married?
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr: ['A soldier!', 'Some real soldier.']
qText: A soldier! Some real soldier.
speaker: Miss Avery

qTextArr:
['But that s all over,', 'A better time is coming now, though
you ve kept me long enough waiting. In a couple of weeks I ll see your
light shining through the hedge of an evening. Have you ordered in
coals?']
qText:
But that s all over, A better time is coming now, though
you ve kept me long enough waiting. In a couple of weeks I ll see your
light shining through the hedge of an evening. Have you ordered in
coals?
speaker: Miss Avery

qTextArr:
['We are not coming,', 'No. Not coming. Never coming. It has all been a
mistake. The furniture must be repacked at once, and I am very sorry,
but I am making other arrangements, and must ask you to give me the
keys.']
qText:
We are not coming, No. Not coming. Never coming. It has all been a
mistake. The furniture must be repacked at once, and I am very sorry,
but I am making other arrangements, and must ask you to give me the
keys.
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr: ['Certainly, Mrs. Wilcox,']
qText: Certainly, Mrs. Wilcox,
speaker: Miss Avery

qTextArr: ['to really\ntake my tiresome chest in hand,']
qText:
to really
take my tiresome chest in hand,
speaker: Aunt Juley
refExp: She had scarcely promised her niece

qTextArr: ['Important--Margaret dear, take the Lulworth when Helen comes.']
qText: Important--Margaret dear, take the Lulworth when Helen comes.
speaker: Aunt Juley

qTextArr: ['Helen won t be able to stop, Aunt Juley. She has telegraphed that she\ncan only get away just to see you. She must go back to Germany as soon\nas you are well.']
qText:
Helen won t be able to stop, Aunt Juley. She has telegraphed that she
can only get away just to see you. She must go back to Germany as soon
as you are well.
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr: ['How very odd of Helen! Mr. Wilcox--']
qText: How very odd of Helen! Mr. Wilcox--
speaker: Aunt Juley

qTextArr: ['Yes, dear?']
qText: Yes, dear?
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr: ['Can he spare you?']
qText: Can he spare you?
speaker: Aunt Juley

qTextArr: ['Margaret--important,', 'I should like you to have some\ncompanion to take walks with. Do try Miss Conder.']
qText:
Margaret--important, I should like you to have some
companion to take walks with. Do try Miss Conder.
speaker: Aunt Juley

qTextArr: ['I have been for a little walk with Miss Conder.']
qText: I have been for a little walk with Miss Conder.
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr: ['But she is not really interesting. If only you had Helen.']
qText: But she is not really interesting. If only you had Helen.
speaker: Aunt Juley

qTextArr: ['I have Tibby, Aunt Juley.']
qText: I have Tibby, Aunt Juley.
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr: ['No, but he has to do his Chinese. Some real companion is what you need.\nReally, Helen is odd.']
qText:
No, but he has to do his Chinese. Some real companion is what you need.
Really, Helen is odd.
speaker: Aunt Juley

qTextArr: ['Helen is odd, very,']
qText: Helen is odd, very,
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr: ['Not content with going abroad, why does she want to go back there at\nonce?']
qText:
Not content with going abroad, why does she want to go back there at
once?
speaker: Aunt Juley

qTextArr: ['No doubt she will change her mind when she sees us. She has not the\nleast balance.']
qText:
No doubt she will change her mind when she sees us. She has not the
least balance.
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr: ['Why don t you tell Mr. Wilcox?']
qText: Why don t you tell Mr. Wilcox?
speaker: Tibby

qTextArr: ['About Helen?']
qText: About Helen?
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr: ['Perhaps he has come across that sort of thing.']
qText: Perhaps he has come across that sort of thing.
speaker: Tibby

qTextArr: ['He would do all he could, but--']
qText: He would do all he could, but--
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr: ['Oh, you know best. But he is practical.']
qText: Oh, you know best. But he is practical.
speaker: Tibby

qTextArr: ['Tibby love, what next?']
qText: Tibby love, what next?
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr: ['It is extraordinary.']
qText: It is extraordinary.
speaker: Tibby

qTextArr: ['Dear, your judgment s often clearer than mine. Have you any notion\nwhat s at the back?']
qText:
Dear, your judgment s often clearer than mine. Have you any notion
what s at the back?
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr: ['None, unless it s something mental.']
qText: None, unless it s something mental.
speaker: Tibby

qTextArr: ['Oh--that!', 'Quite impossible.']
qText: Oh--that! Quite impossible.
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr: ['just like Helen']
qText: just like Helen
speaker: Henry
refExp: he only chaffed Tibby and the Schlegels generally and declared

qTextArr: ['That is what we all say,', 'But why should it be\njust like Helen? Why should she be allowed to be so queer, and to grow\nqueerer?']
qText:
That is what we all say, But why should it be
just like Helen? Why should she be allowed to be so queer, and to grow
queerer?
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr:
['Don t ask me. I m a plain man of business. I live and let live. My
advice to you both is, don t worry. Margaret, you ve got black marks
again under your eyes. You know that s strictly forbidden. First
your aunt--then your sister. No, we aren t going to have it. Are we,
Theobald?']
qText:
Don t ask me. I m a plain man of business. I live and let live. My
advice to you both is, don t worry. Margaret, you ve got black marks
again under your eyes. You know that s strictly forbidden. First
your aunt--then your sister. No, we aren t going to have it. Are we,
Theobald?
speaker: Henry

qTextArr: ['I ll give you some tea, and then you go\nstraight to Ducie Street. I can t have my girl looking as old as her\nhusband.']
qText:
I ll give you some tea, and then you go
straight to Ducie Street. I can t have my girl looking as old as her
husband.
speaker: Henry

qTextArr: ['All the same, you have not quite seen our point,']
qText: All the same, you have not quite seen our point,
speaker: Tibby

qTextArr: ['I don t suppose I ever\nshall.']
qText:
I don t suppose I ever
shall.
speaker: Henry
refExp: Mr Wilcox who was in good spirits retorted

qTextArr: ['Margaret s point is this,', 'Our sister may be mad.']
qText: Margaret s point is this, Our sister may be mad.
speaker: Tibby

qTextArr: ['Come in, Charles,', 'Could you help us at all? We\nare again in trouble.']
qText:
Come in, Charles, Could you help us at all? We
are again in trouble.
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr: ['I m afraid I cannot. What are the facts? We are all mad more or less,\nyou know, in these days.']
qText:
I m afraid I cannot. What are the facts? We are all mad more or less,
you know, in these days.
speaker: Charles Wilcox

qTextArr:
['The facts are as follows,', 'The facts are that she has been in England for three days and
will not see us. She has forbidden the bankers to give us her address.
She refuses to answer questions. Margaret finds her letters colourless.
There are other facts, but these are the most striking.']
qText:
The facts are as follows, The facts are that she has been in England for three days and
will not see us. She has forbidden the bankers to give us her address.
She refuses to answer questions. Margaret finds her letters colourless.
There are other facts, but these are the most striking.
speaker: Tibby

qTextArr: ['She has never behaved like this before, then?']
qText: She has never behaved like this before, then?
speaker: Henry

qTextArr: ['Of course not!']
qText: Of course not!
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr: ['Well, my dear, how am I to know?']
qText: Well, my dear, how am I to know?
speaker: Henry

qTextArr: ['You know quite well that\nHelen never sins against affection,', 'You must have noticed\nthat much in her, surely.']
qText:
You know quite well that
Helen never sins against affection, You must have noticed
that much in her, surely.
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr: ['Oh yes; she and I have always hit it off together.']
qText: Oh yes; she and I have always hit it off together.
speaker: Henry

qTextArr: ['No, Henry--can t you see?--I don t mean that.']
qText: No, Henry--can t you see?--I don t mean that.
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr:
['I was meaning that when she was eccentric in the past, one could trace
it back to the heart in the long-run. She behaved oddly because she
cared for some one, or wanted to help them. There s no possible excuse
for her now. She is grieving us deeply, and that is why I am sure that
she is not well.  Mad  is too terrible a word, but she is not well.
I shall never believe it. I shouldn t discuss my sister with you if I
thought she was well--trouble you about her, I mean.']
qText:
I was meaning that when she was eccentric in the past, one could trace
it back to the heart in the long-run. She behaved oddly because she
cared for some one, or wanted to help them. There s no possible excuse
for her now. She is grieving us deeply, and that is why I am sure that
she is not well.  Mad  is too terrible a word, but she is not well.
I shall never believe it. I shouldn t discuss my sister with you if I
thought she was well--trouble you about her, I mean.
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr: ['You want to get hold of her?', 'That s the problem, isn t it?\nShe has got to see a doctor.']
qText:
You want to get hold of her? That s the problem, isn t it?
She has got to see a doctor.
speaker: Henry

qTextArr: ['For all I know she has seen one already.']
qText: For all I know she has seen one already.
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr: ['Yes, yes; don t interrupt.']
qText: Yes, yes; don t interrupt.
speaker: Henry

qTextArr: ['I ve got it,', 'It s\nperfectly easy. Leave it to me. We ll send her down to Howards End.']
qText:
I ve got it, It s
perfectly easy. Leave it to me. We ll send her down to Howards End.
speaker: Henry

qTextArr: ['How will you do that?']
qText: How will you do that?
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr: ['After her books. Tell her that she must unpack them herself. Then you\ncan meet her there.']
qText:
After her books. Tell her that she must unpack them herself. Then you
can meet her there.
speaker: Henry

qTextArr: ['But, Henry, that s just what she won t let me do. It s part of\nher--whatever it is--never to see me.']
qText:
But, Henry, that s just what she won t let me do. It s part of
her--whatever it is--never to see me.
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr:
['Of course you won t tell her you re going. When she is there, looking
at the cases, you ll just stroll in. If nothing is wrong with her, so
much the better. But there ll be the motor round the corner, and we can
run her to a specialist in no time.']
qText:
Of course you won t tell her you re going. When she is there, looking
at the cases, you ll just stroll in. If nothing is wrong with her, so
much the better. But there ll be the motor round the corner, and we can
run her to a specialist in no time.
speaker: Henry

qTextArr: ['It s quite impossible.']
qText: It s quite impossible.
speaker: Margaret

qText: Why?
speaker: Henry

qTextArr: ['It doesn t seem impossible to me,', 'it is surely a very\ntippy plan.']
qText:
It doesn t seem impossible to me, it is surely a very
tippy plan.
speaker: Tibby

qTextArr: ['It is impossible, because--']
qText: It is impossible, because--
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr: ['It s not\nthe particular language that Helen and I talk, if you see my meaning. It\nwould do splendidly for other people, whom I don t blame.']
qText:
It s not
the particular language that Helen and I talk, if you see my meaning. It
would do splendidly for other people, whom I don t blame.
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr: ['But Helen doesn t talk,', 'That s our whole difficulty. She\nwon t talk your particular language, and on that account you think she s\nill.']
qText:
But Helen doesn t talk, That s our whole difficulty. She
won t talk your particular language, and on that account you think she s
ill.
speaker: Tibby

qTextArr: ['No, Henry; it s sweet of you, but I couldn t.']
qText: No, Henry; it s sweet of you, but I couldn t.
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr: ['I see,', 'you have scruples.']
qText: I see, you have scruples.
speaker: Henry

qTextArr: ['I suppose so.']
qText: I suppose so.
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr:
['And sooner than go against them you would have your sister suffer. You
could have got her down to Swanage by a word, but you had scruples. And
scruples are all very well. I am as scrupulous as any man alive, I hope;
but when it is a case like this, when there is a question of madness--']
qText:
And sooner than go against them you would have your sister suffer. You
could have got her down to Swanage by a word, but you had scruples. And
scruples are all very well. I am as scrupulous as any man alive, I hope;
but when it is a case like this, when there is a question of madness--
speaker: Henry

qTextArr: ['I deny it s madness.']
qText: I deny it s madness.
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr: ['You said just now--']
qText: You said just now--
speaker: Henry

qTextArr: ['It s madness when I say it, but not when you say it.']
qText: It s madness when I say it, but not when you say it.
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr: ['Margaret! Margaret!', 'No\neducation can teach a woman logic. Now, my dear, my time is valuable. Do\nyou want me to help you or not?']
qText:
Margaret! Margaret! No
education can teach a woman logic. Now, my dear, my time is valuable. Do
you want me to help you or not?
speaker: Henry

qTextArr: ['Not in that way.']
qText: Not in that way.
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr: ['Answer my question. Plain question, plain answer. Do--']
qText: Answer my question. Plain question, plain answer. Do--
speaker: Henry

qTextArr: ['Pater, we may as well keep\nHowards End out of it,']
qText:
Pater, we may as well keep
Howards End out of it,
speaker: Charles Wilcox

qTextArr: ['Why, Charles?']
qText: Why, Charles?
speaker: Henry

qTextArr: ['The whole house is at sixes and sevens,', 'We don t\nwant any more mess.']
qText:
The whole house is at sixes and sevens, We don t
want any more mess.
speaker: Charles Wilcox

qTextArr: ['Who s  we ?', 'My boy, pray who s  we ?']
qText: Who s  we ? My boy, pray who s  we ?
speaker: Henry

qTextArr: ['I am sure I beg your pardon,', 'I appear always to be\nintruding.']
qText:
I am sure I beg your pardon, I appear always to be
intruding.
speaker: Charles Wilcox

qTextArr: ['I can t have this sort\nof behaviour, my boy. Margaret s too sweet-natured to mind, but I mind\nfor her.']
qText:
I can t have this sort
of behaviour, my boy. Margaret s too sweet-natured to mind, but I mind
for her.
speaker: Henry
refExp: Mr Wilcox said to his son

qTextArr: ['Is anything wrong with you, Charles, this afternoon?']
qText: Is anything wrong with you, Charles, this afternoon?
speaker: Henry

qTextArr: ['No, pater; but you may be taking on a bigger business than you reckon.']
qText: No, pater; but you may be taking on a bigger business than you reckon.
speaker: Charles Wilcox

qText: How?
speaker: Henry

qTextArr: ['Don t ask me.']
qText: Don t ask me.
speaker: Charles Wilcox

qTextArr: ['She was bound to drive,', 'There will be her books.']
qText: She was bound to drive, There will be her books.
speaker: Henry

qTextArr: ['I cannot make it out,']
qText: I cannot make it out,
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr: ['Finish your coffee, dear. We must be off.']
qText: Finish your coffee, dear. We must be off.
speaker: Henry

qTextArr: ['Yes, Margaret, you know you must take plenty,']
qText: Yes, Margaret, you know you must take plenty,
speaker: Dolly

qTextArr: ['You re not fit for it,', 'Let me go alone. I know\nexactly what to do.']
qText:
You re not fit for it, Let me go alone. I know
exactly what to do.
speaker: Henry

qTextArr:
['Oh yes, I am fit,', 'Only most
frightfully worried. I cannot feel that Helen is really alive. Her
letters and telegrams seem to have come from some one else. Her voice
isn t in them. I don t believe your driver really saw her at the
station. I wish I d never mentioned it. I know that Charles is vexed.
Yes, he is--', 'There, Dolly will
forgive me. There. Now we ll be off.']
qText:
Oh yes, I am fit, Only most
frightfully worried. I cannot feel that Helen is really alive. Her
letters and telegrams seem to have come from some one else. Her voice
isn t in them. I don t believe your driver really saw her at the
station. I wish I d never mentioned it. I know that Charles is vexed.
Yes, he is-- There, Dolly will
forgive me. There. Now we ll be off.
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr: ['Don t you want to tidy yourself?']
qText: Don t you want to tidy yourself?
speaker: Henry

qTextArr: ['Have I time?']
qText: Have I time?
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr: ['Yes, plenty.']
qText: Yes, plenty.
speaker: Henry

qTextArr: ['Dolly, I m going without her.']
qText: Dolly, I m going without her.
speaker: Henry

qTextArr: ['Tell her I thought it best.']
qText: Tell her I thought it best.
speaker: Henry

qTextArr: ['Yes, Mr. Wilcox, I see.']
qText: Yes, Mr. Wilcox, I see.
speaker: Dolly

qTextArr: ['Say anything you like. All right.']
qText: Say anything you like. All right.
speaker: Henry

qTextArr: ['I deserve it; I am punished for\nlowering my colours.']
qText:
I deserve it; I am punished for
lowering my colours.
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr: ['I still consider you are not fit for it,']
qText: I still consider you are not fit for it,
speaker: Henry

qTextArr: ['Perhaps I was not at lunch. But the whole thing is spread clearly\nbefore me now.']
qText:
Perhaps I was not at lunch. But the whole thing is spread clearly
before me now.
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr: ['I was meaning to act for the best.']
qText: I was meaning to act for the best.
speaker: Henry

qTextArr: ['Just lend me your scarf, will you. This wind takes one s hair so.']
qText: Just lend me your scarf, will you. This wind takes one s hair so.
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr: ['Certainly, dear girl. Are you all right now?']
qText: Certainly, dear girl. Are you all right now?
speaker: Henry

qTextArr: ['Look! My hands have stopped trembling.']
qText: Look! My hands have stopped trembling.
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr:
['And have quite forgiven me? Then listen. Her cab should already have
arrived at Howards End. (We re a little late, but no matter.) Our first
move will be to send it down to wait at the farm, as, if possible, one
doesn t want a scene before servants. A certain gentleman']
qText:
And have quite forgiven me? Then listen. Her cab should already have
arrived at Howards End. (We re a little late, but no matter.) Our first
move will be to send it down to wait at the farm, as, if possible, one
doesn t want a scene before servants. A certain gentleman
speaker: Henry

qTextArr: ['won t drive in, but will wait a little short of the\nfront gate, behind the laurels. Have you still the keys of the house?']
qText:
won t drive in, but will wait a little short of the
front gate, behind the laurels. Have you still the keys of the house?
speaker: Henry

qText: Yes.
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr: ['Well, they aren t wanted. Do you remember how the house stands?']
qText: Well, they aren t wanted. Do you remember how the house stands?
speaker: Henry

qText: Yes.
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr: ['If we don t find her in the porch, we can stroll round into the garden.\nOur object--']
qText:
If we don t find her in the porch, we can stroll round into the garden.
Our object--
speaker: Henry

qTextArr:
['I was just saying to my wife, Mansbridge, that our main object is not
to frighten Miss Schlegel. The house, as you know, is my property, so it
should seem quite natural for us to be there. The trouble is evidently
nervous--wouldn t you say so, Margaret?']
qText:
I was just saying to my wife, Mansbridge, that our main object is not
to frighten Miss Schlegel. The house, as you know, is my property, so it
should seem quite natural for us to be there. The trouble is evidently
nervous--wouldn t you say so, Margaret?
speaker: Henry

qTextArr: ['Nothing,']
qText: Nothing,
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr: ['Though she did resent my husband s immorality.']
qText: Though she did resent my husband s immorality.
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr: ['She always was highly strung,', 'A tendency to spiritualism and those\nthings, though nothing serious. Musical, literary, artistic, but I\nshould say normal--a very charming girl.']
qText:
She always was highly strung, A tendency to spiritualism and those
things, though nothing serious. Musical, literary, artistic, but I
should say normal--a very charming girl.
speaker: Henry

qTextArr: ['Is the truant all right?']
qText: Is the truant all right?
speaker: Henry

qTextArr: ['Oh, my darling--']
qText: Oh, my darling--
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr: ['Yes,\nall right,']
qText:
Yes,
all right,
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr: ['Margaret, you look upset!']
qText: Margaret, you look upset!
speaker: Henry

qTextArr: ['You\nmight have given me a knock with the gate,']
qText:
You
might have given me a knock with the gate,
speaker: Henry

qTextArr: ['Go\naway.']
qText:
Go
away.
speaker: Margaret
refExp: She or someone for her said

qTextArr: ['Margaret, you look upset again.\nMy dear, give me the keys. What are you doing with Helen?']
qText:
Margaret, you look upset again.
My dear, give me the keys. What are you doing with Helen?
speaker: Henry

qTextArr: ['Oh, dearest, do go away, and I will manage it all.']
qText: Oh, dearest, do go away, and I will manage it all.
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr: ['Manage what?']
qText: Manage what?
speaker: Henry

qTextArr: ['Stop that at least,']
qText: Stop that at least,
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr: ['Come, this is an odd beginning,']
qText: Come, this is an odd beginning,
speaker: Henry

qTextArr: ['I cannot help it,', 'Do wait. It s not my fault. Please\nall four of you go away now.']
qText:
I cannot help it, Do wait. It s not my fault. Please
all four of you go away now.
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr: ['We are relying on you to help us, Mrs. Wilcox,', 'Could you go in and persuade your sister to come out?']
qText: We are relying on you to help us, Mrs. Wilcox, Could you go in and persuade your sister to come out?
speaker: Mansbridge

qTextArr: ['On what grounds?']
qText: On what grounds?
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr: ['I beg your pardon, but it is nothing of the sort. You are not qualified\nto attend my sister, Mr. Mansbridge. If we require your services, we\nwill let you know.']
qText:
I beg your pardon, but it is nothing of the sort. You are not qualified
to attend my sister, Mr. Mansbridge. If we require your services, we
will let you know.
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr: ['I can diagnose the case more bluntly if you wish,']
qText: I can diagnose the case more bluntly if you wish,
speaker: Mansbridge

qTextArr: ['You could, but you have not. You are, therefore, not qualified to\nattend my sister.']
qText:
You could, but you have not. You are, therefore, not qualified to
attend my sister.
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr: ['Come, come, Margaret!', 'This is a\nterrible business, an appalling business. It s doctor s orders. Open the\ndoor.']
qText:
Come, come, Margaret! This is a
terrible business, an appalling business. It s doctor s orders. Open the
door.
speaker: Henry

qTextArr: ['Forgive me, but I will not.']
qText: Forgive me, but I will not.
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr: ['I don t agree.']
qText: I don t agree.
speaker: Henry

qTextArr: ['This business is as broad as it s long,', 'We\nhad better all work together. You need us, Mrs. Wilcox, and we need\nyou.']
qText:
This business is as broad as it s long, We
had better all work together. You need us, Mrs. Wilcox, and we need
you.
speaker: Mansbridge

qTextArr: ['Quite so,']
qText: Quite so,
speaker: Henry

qTextArr: ['I do not need you in the least,']
qText: I do not need you in the least,
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr: ['No more does my sister, who is still many weeks from her confinement.']
qText: No more does my sister, who is still many weeks from her confinement.
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr: ['Margaret, Margaret!']
qText: Margaret, Margaret!
speaker: Henry

qTextArr: ['Well, Henry, send your doctor away. What possible use is he now?']
qText: Well, Henry, send your doctor away. What possible use is he now?
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr:
['It all turns on affection now,', 'Affection. Don t you
see?', 'Surely you see. I like Helen very much, you not so much.
Mr. Mansbridge doesn t know her. That s all. And affection, when
reciprocated, gives rights. Put that down in your note-book, Mr.
Mansbridge. It s a useful formula.', 'You don t know what you want yourselves,', 'For one sensible remark I will let you in. But you cannot make
it. You would trouble my sister for no reason. I will not permit it.
I ll stand here all the day sooner.']
qText:
It all turns on affection now, Affection. Don t you
see? Surely you see. I like Helen very much, you not so much.
Mr. Mansbridge doesn t know her. That s all. And affection, when
reciprocated, gives rights. Put that down in your note-book, Mr.
Mansbridge. It s a useful formula. You don t know what you want yourselves, For one sensible remark I will let you in. But you cannot make
it. You would trouble my sister for no reason. I will not permit it.
I ll stand here all the day sooner.
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr: ['Mansbridge,', 'perhaps not now.']
qText: Mansbridge, perhaps not now.
speaker: Henry

qTextArr: ['Now, Henry, you,', 'Go away now, dear. I shall want your advice later, no\ndoubt. Forgive me if I have been cross. But, seriously, you must go.']
qText:
Now, Henry, you, Go away now, dear. I shall want your advice later, no
doubt. Forgive me if I have been cross. But, seriously, you must go.
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr: ['I shall soon find you down at Dolly s,']
qText: I shall soon find you down at Dolly s,
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr: ['Oh, my darling!', 'My darling, forgive me.']
qText: Oh, my darling! My darling, forgive me.
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr: ['Convenient! You did not tell me that the books were unpacked. I have\nfound nearly everything that I want.']
qText:
Convenient! You did not tell me that the books were unpacked. I have
found nearly everything that I want.
speaker: Helen
refExp: Helen in a dignified voice that came strangely from her said

qTextArr: ['I told you nothing that was true.']
qText: I told you nothing that was true.
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr: ['It has been a great surprise, certainly. Has Aunt Juley been ill?']
qText: It has been a great surprise, certainly. Has Aunt Juley been ill?
speaker: Helen

qTextArr: ['Helen, you wouldn t think I d invent that?']
qText: Helen, you wouldn t think I d invent that?
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr: ['I suppose not,', 'But one loses faith in everything after this.']
qText: I suppose not, But one loses faith in everything after this.
speaker: Helen

qTextArr: ['We thought it was illness, but even then--I haven t behaved worthily.']
qText: We thought it was illness, but even then--I haven t behaved worthily.
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr: ['I ought not to have consulted any one. What would our father have\nthought of me?']
qText:
I ought not to have consulted any one. What would our father have
thought of me?
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr:
['Yes, I am annoyed,', 'My wishes should have been
respected. I would have gone through this meeting if it was necessary,
but after Aunt Juley recovered, it was not necessary. Planning my life,
as I now have to do.']
qText:
Yes, I am annoyed, My wishes should have been
respected. I would have gone through this meeting if it was necessary,
but after Aunt Juley recovered, it was not necessary. Planning my life,
as I now have to do.
speaker: Helen

qTextArr: ['Come away from those books,', 'Helen, do talk to me.']
qText: Come away from those books, Helen, do talk to me.
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr: ['I was just saying that I have stopped living haphazard. One can t go\nthrough a great deal of --']
qText:
I was just saying that I have stopped living haphazard. One can t go
through a great deal of --
speaker: Helen

qTextArr:
['without planning one s
actions in advance. I am going to have a child in June, and in the first
place conversations, discussions, excitement, are not good for me. I
will go through them if necessary, but only then. In the second place I
have no right to trouble people. I cannot fit in with England as I know
it. I have done something that the English never pardon. It would not be
right for them to pardon it. So I must live where I am not known.']
qText:
without planning one s
actions in advance. I am going to have a child in June, and in the first
place conversations, discussions, excitement, are not good for me. I
will go through them if necessary, but only then. In the second place I
have no right to trouble people. I cannot fit in with England as I know
it. I have done something that the English never pardon. It would not be
right for them to pardon it. So I must live where I am not known.
speaker: Helen

qTextArr: ['But why didn t you tell me, dearest?']
qText: But why didn t you tell me, dearest?
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr: ['Yes,', 'I might have, but decided to wait.']
qText: Yes, I might have, but decided to wait.
speaker: Helen

qTextArr: ['I believe you would never have told me.']
qText: I believe you would never have told me.
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr: ['Oh yes, I should. We have taken a flat in Munich.']
qText: Oh yes, I should. We have taken a flat in Munich.
speaker: Helen

qTextArr: ['By  we  I mean myself and Monica. But for her, I am and have been and\nalways wish to be alone.']
qText:
By  we  I mean myself and Monica. But for her, I am and have been and
always wish to be alone.
speaker: Helen

qTextArr: ['I have not heard of Monica.']
qText: I have not heard of Monica.
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr: ['You wouldn t have. She s an Italian--by birth at least. She makes her\nliving by journalism. I met her originally on Garda. Monica is much the\nbest person to see me through.']
qText:
You wouldn t have. She s an Italian--by birth at least. She makes her
living by journalism. I met her originally on Garda. Monica is much the
best person to see me through.
speaker: Helen

qTextArr: ['You are very fond of her, then.']
qText: You are very fond of her, then.
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr: ['She has been extraordinarily sensible with me.']
qText: She has been extraordinarily sensible with me.
speaker: Helen

qTextArr:
['You must not think that we shall never meet,', 'I shall always have a room for you when you can be
spared, and the longer you can be with me the better. But you haven t
understood yet, Meg, and of course it is very difficult for you. This is
a shock to you. It isn t to me, who have been thinking over our futures
for many months, and they won t be changed by a slight contretemps, such
as this. I cannot live in England.']
qText:
You must not think that we shall never meet, I shall always have a room for you when you can be
spared, and the longer you can be with me the better. But you haven t
understood yet, Meg, and of course it is very difficult for you. This is
a shock to you. It isn t to me, who have been thinking over our futures
for many months, and they won t be changed by a slight contretemps, such
as this. I cannot live in England.
speaker: Helen

qTextArr: ['Helen, you ve not forgiven me for my treachery. You COULDN T talk like\nthis to me if you had.']
qText:
Helen, you ve not forgiven me for my treachery. You COULDN T talk like
this to me if you had.
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr: ['Oh, Meg dear, why do we talk at all?']
qText: Oh, Meg dear, why do we talk at all?
speaker: Helen

qTextArr: ['Tell me, how is it that\nall the books are down here?']
qText:
Tell me, how is it that
all the books are down here?
speaker: Helen

qTextArr: ['Series of mistakes.']
qText: Series of mistakes.
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr: ['And a great deal of furniture has been unpacked.']
qText: And a great deal of furniture has been unpacked.
speaker: Helen

qText: All.
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr: ['Who lives here, then?']
qText: Who lives here, then?
speaker: Helen

qTextArr: ['No one.']
qText: No one.
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr: ['I suppose you are letting it, though.']
qText: I suppose you are letting it, though.
speaker: Helen

qTextArr: ['The house is dead,', 'Why worry on about\nit?']
qText:
The house is dead, Why worry on about
it?
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr:
['But I am interested. You talk as if I had lost all my interest in life.
I am still Helen, I hope. Now this hasn t the feel of a dead house.
The hall seems more alive even than in the old days, when it held the
Wilcoxes  own things.']
qText:
But I am interested. You talk as if I had lost all my interest in life.
I am still Helen, I hope. Now this hasn t the feel of a dead house.
The hall seems more alive even than in the old days, when it held the
Wilcoxes  own things.
speaker: Helen

qTextArr: ['Interested, are you? Very well, I must tell you, I suppose. My husband\nlent it on condition we--but by a mistake all our things were unpacked,\nand Miss Avery, instead of--']
qText:
Interested, are you? Very well, I must tell you, I suppose. My husband
lent it on condition we--but by a mistake all our things were unpacked,
and Miss Avery, instead of--
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr: ['Look here, I can t go on\nlike this. I warn you I won t. Helen, why should you be so miserably\nunkind to me, simply because you hate Henry?']
qText:
Look here, I can t go on
like this. I warn you I won t. Helen, why should you be so miserably
unkind to me, simply because you hate Henry?
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr:
['I don t hate him now,', 'I have stopped being a schoolgirl,
and, Meg, once again, I m not being unkind. But as for fitting in with
your English life--no, put it out of your head at once. Imagine a visit
from me at Ducie Street! It s unthinkable.', 'Tell me about yourself,']
qText:
I don t hate him now, I have stopped being a schoolgirl,
and, Meg, once again, I m not being unkind. But as for fitting in with
your English life--no, put it out of your head at once. Imagine a visit
from me at Ducie Street! It s unthinkable. Tell me about yourself,
speaker: Helen

qTextArr: ['There s nothing to tell.']
qText: There s nothing to tell.
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr: ['But your marriage has been happy, Meg?']
qText: But your marriage has been happy, Meg?
speaker: Helen

qTextArr: ['Yes, but I don t feel inclined to talk.']
qText: Yes, but I don t feel inclined to talk.
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr: ['You feel as I do.']
qText: You feel as I do.
speaker: Helen

qTextArr: ['Not that, but I can t.']
qText: Not that, but I can t.
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr: ['No more can I. It is a nuisance, but no good trying.']
qText: No more can I. It is a nuisance, but no good trying.
speaker: Helen

qTextArr: ['Look here, Meg, is the coast clear?']
qText: Look here, Meg, is the coast clear?
speaker: Helen

qTextArr: ['You mean that you want to go away from me?']
qText: You mean that you want to go away from me?
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr: ['I suppose so--dear old lady! it isn t any use. I knew we should have\nnothing to say. Give my love to Aunt Juley and Tibby, and take more\nyourself than I can say. Promise to come and see me in Munich later.']
qText:
I suppose so--dear old lady! it isn t any use. I knew we should have
nothing to say. Give my love to Aunt Juley and Tibby, and take more
yourself than I can say. Promise to come and see me in Munich later.
speaker: Helen

qTextArr: ['Certainly, dearest.']
qText: Certainly, dearest.
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr: ['For that is all we can do.']
qText: For that is all we can do.
speaker: Helen

qTextArr: ['I am glad to have seen you and the things.']
qText: I am glad to have seen you and the things.
speaker: Helen

qTextArr: ['The car has gone, and here s\nyour cab.']
qText:
The car has gone, and here s
your cab.
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr: ['Please, lady, a message,']
qText: Please, lady, a message,
speaker: The Driver
refExp: The driver who was leaning on the gate called out

qTextArr: ['How did this come?']
qText: How did this come?
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr: ['Henry would have done what he could,']
qText: Henry would have done what he could,
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr: ['This IS Mr. Wilcox s house?']
qText: This IS Mr. Wilcox s house?
speaker: Helen

qTextArr: ['Surely you remember Howards End?']
qText: Surely you remember Howards End?
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr: ['Remember? I who remember everything! But it looks to be ours now.']
qText: Remember? I who remember everything! But it looks to be ours now.
speaker: Helen

qTextArr: ['Miss Avery was extraordinary,', 'She loved\nMrs. Wilcox, and would rather furnish her home with our things than\nthink of it empty. In consequence here are all the library books.']
qText:
Miss Avery was extraordinary, She loved
Mrs. Wilcox, and would rather furnish her home with our things than
think of it empty. In consequence here are all the library books.
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr: ['Not all the books. She hasn t unpacked the Art books, in which she may\nshow her sense. And we never used to have the sword here.']
qText:
Not all the books. She hasn t unpacked the Art books, in which she may
show her sense. And we never used to have the sword here.
speaker: Helen

qTextArr: ['The sword looks well, though.']
qText: The sword looks well, though.
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr: ['Magnificent.']
qText: Magnificent.
speaker: Helen

qTextArr: ['Yes, doesn t it?']
qText: Yes, doesn t it?
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr: ['Where s the piano, Meg?']
qText: Where s the piano, Meg?
speaker: Helen

qTextArr: ['I warehoused that in London. Why?']
qText: I warehoused that in London. Why?
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr: ['Nothing.']
qText: Nothing.
speaker: Helen

qTextArr: ['Curious, too, that the carpet fits.']
qText: Curious, too, that the carpet fits.
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr: ['The carpet s a mistake,', 'I know that we had it in\nLondon, but this floor ought to be bare. It is far too beautiful.']
qText:
The carpet s a mistake, I know that we had it in
London, but this floor ought to be bare. It is far too beautiful.
speaker: Helen

qTextArr: ['You still have a mania for under-furnishing. Would you care to come\ninto the dining-room before you start? There s no carpet there.']
qText:
You still have a mania for under-furnishing. Would you care to come
into the dining-room before you start? There s no carpet there.
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr: ['Oh, WHAT a place for mother s chiffonier!']
qText: Oh, WHAT a place for mother s chiffonier!
speaker: Helen

qTextArr: ['Look at the chairs, though.']
qText: Look at the chairs, though.
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr: ['Oh, look at them! Wickham Place faced north, didn t it?']
qText: Oh, look at them! Wickham Place faced north, didn t it?
speaker: Helen

qTextArr: ['North-west.']
qText: North-west.
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr: ['Anyhow, it is thirty years since any of those chairs have felt the sun.\nFeel. Their dear little backs are quite warm.']
qText:
Anyhow, it is thirty years since any of those chairs have felt the sun.
Feel. Their dear little backs are quite warm.
speaker: Helen

qTextArr: ['But why has Miss Avery made them set to partners? I shall just--']
qText: But why has Miss Avery made them set to partners? I shall just--
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr: ['Over here, Meg. Put it so that any one sitting will see the lawn.']
qText: Over here, Meg. Put it so that any one sitting will see the lawn.
speaker: Helen

qTextArr: ['Ye--es. The window s too high.']
qText: Ye--es. The window s too high.
speaker: Helen

qTextArr: ['Try a drawing-room chair.']
qText: Try a drawing-room chair.
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr: ['No, I don t like the drawing-room so much. The beam has been\nmatch-boarded. It would have been so beautiful otherwise.']
qText:
No, I don t like the drawing-room so much. The beam has been
match-boarded. It would have been so beautiful otherwise.
speaker: Helen

qTextArr: ['Helen, what a memory you have for some things! You re perfectly right.\nIt s a room that men have spoilt through trying to make it nice for\nwomen. Men don t know what we want--']
qText:
Helen, what a memory you have for some things! You re perfectly right.
It s a room that men have spoilt through trying to make it nice for
women. Men don t know what we want--
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr: ['And never will.']
qText: And never will.
speaker: Helen

qTextArr: ['I don t agree. In two thousand years they ll know. Look where Tibby\nspilt the soup.']
qText:
I don t agree. In two thousand years they ll know. Look where Tibby
spilt the soup.
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr: ['Coffee. It was coffee surely.']
qText: Coffee. It was coffee surely.
speaker: Helen

qTextArr: ['Impossible. Tibby was far too young to be given\ncoffee at that time.']
qText:
Impossible. Tibby was far too young to be given
coffee at that time.
speaker: Helen

qTextArr: ['Was father alive?']
qText: Was father alive?
speaker: Margaret

qText: Yes.
speaker: Helen

qTextArr:
['Then you re right and it must have been soup. I was thinking of much
later--that unsuccessful visit of Aunt Juley s, when she didn t realise
that Tibby had grown up. It was coffee then, for he threw it down on
purpose. There was some rhyme,  Tea, coffee--coffee tea,  that she said
to him every morning at breakfast. Wait a minute--how did it go?']
qText:
Then you re right and it must have been soup. I was thinking of much
later--that unsuccessful visit of Aunt Juley s, when she didn t realise
that Tibby had grown up. It was coffee then, for he threw it down on
purpose. There was some rhyme,  Tea, coffee--coffee tea,  that she said
to him every morning at breakfast. Wait a minute--how did it go?
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr: ['I know--no, I don t. What a detestable boy Tibby was!']
qText: I know--no, I don t. What a detestable boy Tibby was!
speaker: Helen

qTextArr: ['But the rhyme was simply awful. No decent person could put up with it.']
qText: But the rhyme was simply awful. No decent person could put up with it.
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr: ['Ah, that greengage-tree,', 'Why do I connect it with dumb-bells? And there come\nthe chickens. The grass wants cutting. I love yellow-hammers.']
qText:
Ah, that greengage-tree, Why do I connect it with dumb-bells? And there come
the chickens. The grass wants cutting. I love yellow-hammers.
speaker: Helen

qTextArr: ['I have got it,', 'That every morning for three weeks. No wonder Tibby was wild.']
qText: I have got it, That every morning for three weeks. No wonder Tibby was wild.
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr: ['Tibby is moderately a dear now,']
qText: Tibby is moderately a dear now,
speaker: Helen

qTextArr: ['There! I knew you d say that in the end. Of course he s a dear.']
qText: There! I knew you d say that in the end. Of course he s a dear.
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr: ['Listen! what s that?']
qText: Listen! what s that?
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr: ['Perhaps the Wilcoxes are beginning the siege.']
qText: Perhaps the Wilcoxes are beginning the siege.
speaker: Helen

qTextArr: ['What nonsense--listen!']
qText: What nonsense--listen!
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr: ['It\nis always Meg.']
qText:
It
is always Meg.
speaker: Helen

qTextArr: ['Little boy, what do you want?']
qText: Little boy, what do you want?
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr: ['Please, I am the milk.']
qText: Please, I am the milk.
speaker: Tom

qTextArr: ['Did Miss Avery send you?']
qText: Did Miss Avery send you?
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr: ['Yes, please.']
qText: Yes, please.
speaker: Tom

qTextArr: ['Then take it back and say we require no milk.']
qText: Then take it back and say we require no milk.
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr: ['No, it s not the siege, but possibly an attempt to provision us\nagainst one.']
qText:
No, it s not the siege, but possibly an attempt to provision us
against one.
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr: ['But I like milk,', 'Why send it away?']
qText: But I like milk, Why send it away?
speaker: Helen

qTextArr: ['Do you? Oh, very well. But we ve nothing to put it in, and he wants the\ncan.']
qText:
Do you? Oh, very well. But we ve nothing to put it in, and he wants the
can.
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr: ['Please, I m to call in the morning for the can,']
qText: Please, I m to call in the morning for the can,
speaker: Tom

qTextArr: ['The house will be locked up then.']
qText: The house will be locked up then.
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr: ['In the morning would I bring eggs too?']
qText: In the morning would I bring eggs too?
speaker: Tom

qTextArr: ['Are you the boy whom I saw playing in the stacks last week?']
qText: Are you the boy whom I saw playing in the stacks last week?
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr: ['Well, run away and do it again.']
qText: Well, run away and do it again.
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr: ['Nice little boy,', 'I say, what s your name? Mine s\nHelen.']
qText:
Nice little boy, I say, what s your name? Mine s
Helen.
speaker: Helen

qText: Tom.
speaker: Tom

qTextArr: ['Tom, this one here is Margaret. And at home we ve another called Tibby.']
qText: Tom, this one here is Margaret. And at home we ve another called Tibby.
speaker: Helen

qTextArr: ['Mine are lop-eareds,']
qText: Mine are lop-eareds,
speaker: Tom

qTextArr: ['You re a very good and rather a clever little boy. Mind you come\nagain.--Isn t he charming?']
qText:
You re a very good and rather a clever little boy. Mind you come
again.--Isn t he charming?
speaker: Helen

qTextArr: ['Undoubtedly,', 'He is probably the son of Madge, and\nMadge is dreadful. But this place has wonderful powers.']
qText:
Undoubtedly, He is probably the son of Madge, and
Madge is dreadful. But this place has wonderful powers.
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr: ['What do you mean?']
qText: What do you mean?
speaker: Helen

qTextArr: ['I don t know.']
qText: I don t know.
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr: ['Because I probably agree with you.']
qText: Because I probably agree with you.
speaker: Helen

qTextArr: ['It kills what is dreadful and makes what is beautiful live.']
qText: It kills what is dreadful and makes what is beautiful live.
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr: ['I do agree,', 'But you said that the\nhouse was dead not half an hour ago.']
qText:
I do agree, But you said that the
house was dead not half an hour ago.
speaker: Helen

qTextArr: ['Meaning that I was dead. I felt it.']
qText: Meaning that I was dead. I felt it.
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr:
['Yes, the house has a surer life than we, even if it was empty, and, as
it is, I can t get over that for thirty years the sun has never shone
full on our furniture. After all, Wickham Place was a grave. Meg, I ve a
startling idea.']
qText:
Yes, the house has a surer life than we, even if it was empty, and, as
it is, I can t get over that for thirty years the sun has never shone
full on our furniture. After all, Wickham Place was a grave. Meg, I ve a
startling idea.
speaker: Helen

qTextArr: ['What is it?']
qText: What is it?
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr: ['Drink some milk to steady you.']
qText: Drink some milk to steady you.
speaker: Helen

qTextArr: ['No, I won t tell you yet,', 'because you may laugh or be\nangry. Let s go upstairs first and give the rooms an airing.']
qText:
No, I won t tell you yet, because you may laugh or be
angry. Let s go upstairs first and give the rooms an airing.
speaker: Helen

qTextArr: ['Then one would see really.']
qText: Then one would see really.
speaker: Helen

qTextArr: ['About my\nidea. Couldn t you and I camp out in this house for the night?']
qText:
About my
idea. Couldn t you and I camp out in this house for the night?
speaker: Helen

qTextArr: ['I don t think we could well do that,']
qText: I don t think we could well do that,
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr: ['Here are beds, tables, towels--']
qText: Here are beds, tables, towels--
speaker: Helen

qTextArr: ['I know; but the house isn t supposed to be slept in, and Henry s\nsuggestion was--']
qText:
I know; but the house isn t supposed to be slept in, and Henry s
suggestion was--
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr: ['I require no suggestions. I shall not alter anything in my plans. But\nit would give me so much pleasure to have one night here with you. It\nwill be something to look back on. Oh, Meg lovey, do let s!']
qText:
I require no suggestions. I shall not alter anything in my plans. But
it would give me so much pleasure to have one night here with you. It
will be something to look back on. Oh, Meg lovey, do let s!
speaker: Helen

qTextArr: ['But, Helen, my pet,', 'we can t without getting Henry s\nleave. Of course, he would give it, but you said yourself that you\ncouldn t visit at Ducie Street now, and this is equally intimate.']
qText:
But, Helen, my pet, we can t without getting Henry s
leave. Of course, he would give it, but you said yourself that you
couldn t visit at Ducie Street now, and this is equally intimate.
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr: ['Ducie Street is his house. This is ours. Our furniture, our sort of\npeople coming to the door. Do let us camp out, just one night, and Tom\nshall feed us on eggs and milk. Why not? It s a moon.']
qText:
Ducie Street is his house. This is ours. Our furniture, our sort of
people coming to the door. Do let us camp out, just one night, and Tom
shall feed us on eggs and milk. Why not? It s a moon.
speaker: Helen

qTextArr:
['I feel Charles wouldn t like it,', 'Even our furniture annoyed him, and I was going to clear it out when
Aunt Juley s illness prevented me. I sympathise with Charles. He feels
it s his mother s house. He loves it in rather an untaking way. Henry I
could answer for--not Charles.']
qText:
I feel Charles wouldn t like it, Even our furniture annoyed him, and I was going to clear it out when
Aunt Juley s illness prevented me. I sympathise with Charles. He feels
it s his mother s house. He loves it in rather an untaking way. Henry I
could answer for--not Charles.
speaker: Margaret
menEnts: [[['Charles Wilcox']], [['Charles Wilcox'], ['Aunt Juley'], ['Charles Wilcox'], ['Charles Wilcox'], ['Mrs. Wilcox'], ['Charles Wilcox'], ['Henry'], ['Charles Wilcox']]]

qTextArr: ['I know he won t like it,', 'But I am going to pass out of\ntheir lives. What difference will it make in the long run if they say,\n And she even spent the night at Howards End ?']
qText:
I know he won t like it, But I am going to pass out of
their lives. What difference will it make in the long run if they say,
 And she even spent the night at Howards End ?
speaker: Helen

qTextArr: ['How do you know you ll pass out of their lives? We have thought that\ntwice before.']
qText:
How do you know you ll pass out of their lives? We have thought that
twice before.
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr: ['Because my plans--']
qText: Because my plans--
speaker: Helen

qTextArr: ['--which you change in a moment.']
qText: --which you change in a moment.
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr:
['Then because my life is great and theirs are little,', 'I know of things they can t know of, and so do you. We
know that there s poetry. We know that there s death. They can only take
them on hearsay. We know this is our house, because it feels ours. Oh,
they may take the title-deeds and the door-keys, but for this one night
we are at home.']
qText:
Then because my life is great and theirs are little, I know of things they can t know of, and so do you. We
know that there s poetry. We know that there s death. They can only take
them on hearsay. We know this is our house, because it feels ours. Oh,
they may take the title-deeds and the door-keys, but for this one night
we are at home.
speaker: Helen

qTextArr: ['It would be lovely to have you once more alone,', 'It may\nbe a chance in a thousand.']
qText:
It would be lovely to have you once more alone, It may
be a chance in a thousand.
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr: ['Yes, and we could talk.']
qText: Yes, and we could talk.
speaker: Helen

qTextArr: ['It won t be a\nvery glorious story. But under that wych-elm--honestly, I see little\nhappiness ahead. Cannot I have this one night with you?']
qText:
It won t be a
very glorious story. But under that wych-elm--honestly, I see little
happiness ahead. Cannot I have this one night with you?
speaker: Helen

qTextArr: ['I needn t say how much it would mean to me.']
qText: I needn t say how much it would mean to me.
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr: ['Then let us.']
qText: Then let us.
speaker: Helen

qTextArr: ['It is no good hesitating. Shall I drive down to Hilton now and get\nleave?']
qText:
It is no good hesitating. Shall I drive down to Hilton now and get
leave?
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr: ['Oh, we don t want leave.']
qText: Oh, we don t want leave.
speaker: Helen

qTextArr: ['Charles may say no,']
qText: Charles may say no,
speaker: Helen

qTextArr: ['We shan t consult him.']
qText: We shan t consult him.
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr: ['Go if you like; I should have stopped without leave.']
qText: Go if you like; I should have stopped without leave.
speaker: Helen

qTextArr: ['Expect me back before dark. I am looking forward to it so much. It is\nlike you to have thought of such a beautiful thing.']
qText:
Expect me back before dark. I am looking forward to it so much. It is
like you to have thought of such a beautiful thing.
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr: ['Not a thing, only an ending,']
qText: Not a thing, only an ending,
speaker: Helen

qTextArr: ['But the diddums can t listen; he isn t nine months old,']
qText: But the diddums can t listen; he isn t nine months old,
speaker: Dolly

qTextArr: ['That s not what I was saying,']
qText: That s not what I was saying,
speaker: Henry

qTextArr: ['Is it what we feared?']
qText: Is it what we feared?
speaker: Henry

qTextArr: ['It is.']
qText: It is.
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr:
['Dear girl,', 'there is a troublesome business ahead of us,
and nothing but the most absolute honesty and plain speech will see
us through.', 'I am obliged to question you on
subjects we d both prefer to leave untouched. As you know, I am not one
of your Bernard Shaws who consider nothing sacred. To speak as I must
will pain me, but there are occasions--We are husband and wife, not
children. I am a man of the world, and you are a most exceptional
woman.']
qText:
Dear girl, there is a troublesome business ahead of us,
and nothing but the most absolute honesty and plain speech will see
us through. I am obliged to question you on
subjects we d both prefer to leave untouched. As you know, I am not one
of your Bernard Shaws who consider nothing sacred. To speak as I must
will pain me, but there are occasions--We are husband and wife, not
children. I am a man of the world, and you are a most exceptional
woman.
speaker: Henry

qTextArr: ['I see that you feel as I felt when--My poor little wife! Oh, be brave!\nJust one or two questions, and I have done with you. Was your sister\nwearing a wedding-ring?']
qText:
I see that you feel as I felt when--My poor little wife! Oh, be brave!
Just one or two questions, and I have done with you. Was your sister
wearing a wedding-ring?
speaker: Henry

qText: No.
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr: ['Henry, I really came to ask a favour about Howards End.']
qText: Henry, I really came to ask a favour about Howards End.
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr: ['One point at a time. I am now obliged to ask for the name of her\nseducer.']
qText:
One point at a time. I am now obliged to ask for the name of her
seducer.
speaker: Henry

qTextArr: ['Take your time,', 'Remember that this is far worse\nfor me than for you.']
qText:
Take your time, Remember that this is far worse
for me than for you.
speaker: Henry

qTextArr: ['Seducer? No; I do not know her seducer s name.']
qText: Seducer? No; I do not know her seducer s name.
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr: ['Would she not tell you?']
qText: Would she not tell you?
speaker: Henry

qTextArr: ['I never even asked her who seduced her,']
qText: I never even asked her who seduced her,
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr: ['That is singular.']
qText: That is singular.
speaker: Henry

qTextArr:
['Natural perhaps, dear
girl, that you shouldn t ask. But until his name is known, nothing can
be done. Sit down. How terrible it is to see you so upset! I knew you
weren t fit for it. I wish I hadn t taken you.']
qText:
Natural perhaps, dear
girl, that you shouldn t ask. But until his name is known, nothing can
be done. Sit down. How terrible it is to see you so upset! I knew you
weren t fit for it. I wish I hadn t taken you.
speaker: Henry

qTextArr: ['I like to stand, if you don t mind, for it gives me\na pleasant view of the Six Hills.']
qText:
I like to stand, if you don t mind, for it gives me
a pleasant view of the Six Hills.
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr: ['As you like.']
qText: As you like.
speaker: Henry

qTextArr: ['Have you anything else to ask me, Henry?']
qText: Have you anything else to ask me, Henry?
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr:
['Next you must tell me whether you have gathered anything. I have often
noticed your insight, dear. I only wish my own was as good. You may have
guessed something, even though your sister said nothing. The slightest
hint would help us.']
qText:
Next you must tell me whether you have gathered anything. I have often
noticed your insight, dear. I only wish my own was as good. You may have
guessed something, even though your sister said nothing. The slightest
hint would help us.
speaker: Henry

qTextArr: ['Who is  we ?']
qText: Who is  we ?
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr: ['I thought it best to ring up Charles.']
qText: I thought it best to ring up Charles.
speaker: Henry

qTextArr: ['That was unnecessary,', 'This news will\ngive Charles disproportionate pain.']
qText:
That was unnecessary, This news will
give Charles disproportionate pain.
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr: ['He has at once gone to call on your brother.']
qText: He has at once gone to call on your brother.
speaker: Henry

qTextArr: ['That too was unnecessary.']
qText: That too was unnecessary.
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr: ['Let me explain, dear, how the matter stands. You don t think that I and\nmy son are other than gentlemen? It is in Helen s interests that we are\nacting. It is still not too late to save her name.']
qText:
Let me explain, dear, how the matter stands. You don t think that I and
my son are other than gentlemen? It is in Helen s interests that we are
acting. It is still not too late to save her name.
speaker: Henry

qTextArr: ['Are we to make her seducer\nmarry her?']
qText:
Are we to make her seducer
marry her?
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr: ['If possible, yes.']
qText: If possible, yes.
speaker: Henry

qTextArr: ['But, Henry, suppose he turned out to be married already? One has heard\nof such cases.']
qText:
But, Henry, suppose he turned out to be married already? One has heard
of such cases.
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr: ['In that case he must pay heavily for his misconduct, and be thrashed\nwithin an inch of his life.']
qText:
In that case he must pay heavily for his misconduct, and be thrashed
within an inch of his life.
speaker: Henry

qTextArr: ['May I ask you\nmy question now?']
qText:
May I ask you
my question now?
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr: ['Certainly, my dear.']
qText: Certainly, my dear.
speaker: Henry

qTextArr: ['To-morrow Helen goes to Munich--']
qText: To-morrow Helen goes to Munich--
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr: ['Well, possibly she is right.']
qText: Well, possibly she is right.
speaker: Henry

qTextArr: ['Henry, let a lady finish. To-morrow she goes; to-night, with your\npermission, she would like to sleep at Howards End.']
qText:
Henry, let a lady finish. To-morrow she goes; to-night, with your
permission, she would like to sleep at Howards End.
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr: ['Why Howards End?', 'Would she not be more comfortable,\nas I suggested, at the hotel?']
qText:
Why Howards End? Would she not be more comfortable,
as I suggested, at the hotel?
speaker: Henry

qTextArr: ['It is an odd request, but you\nknow what Helen is and what women in her state are.']
qText:
It is an odd request, but you
know what Helen is and what women in her state are.
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr:
['She has the idea that one night in your house would
give her pleasure and do her good. I think she s right. Being one of
those imaginative girls, the presence of all our books and furniture
soothes her. This is a fact. It is the end of her girlhood. Her last
words to me were,  A beautiful ending.']
qText:
She has the idea that one night in your house would
give her pleasure and do her good. I think she s right. Being one of
those imaginative girls, the presence of all our books and furniture
soothes her. This is a fact. It is the end of her girlhood. Her last
words to me were,  A beautiful ending.
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr: ['She values the old furniture for sentimental reasons, in fact.']
qText: She values the old furniture for sentimental reasons, in fact.
speaker: Henry

qTextArr: ['Exactly. You have quite understood. It is her last hope of being with\nit.']
qText:
Exactly. You have quite understood. It is her last hope of being with
it.
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr:
['I don t agree there, my dear! Helen will have her share of the goods
wherever she goes--possibly more than her share, for you are so fond
of her that you d give her anything of yours that she fancies, wouldn t
you? and I d raise no objection. I could understand it if it was her old
home, because a home, or a house,']
qText:
