I don t agree there, my dear! Helen will have her share of the goods
wherever she goes--possibly more than her share, for you are so fond
of her that you d give her anything of yours that she fancies, wouldn t
you? and I d raise no objection. I could understand it if it was her old
home, because a home, or a house,
speaker: Henry

qTextArr:
['because a house in which one has once
lived becomes in a sort of way sacred, I don t know why. Associations
and so on. Now Helen has no associations with Howards End, though I
and Charles and Evie have. I do not see why she wants to stay the night
there. She will only catch cold.']
qText:
because a house in which one has once
lived becomes in a sort of way sacred, I don t know why. Associations
and so on. Now Helen has no associations with Howards End, though I
and Charles and Evie have. I do not see why she wants to stay the night
there. She will only catch cold.
speaker: Henry

qTextArr: ['Leave it that you don t see,', 'Call it fancy. But\nrealise that fancy is a scientific fact. Helen is fanciful, and wants\nto.']
qText:
Leave it that you don t see, Call it fancy. But
realise that fancy is a scientific fact. Helen is fanciful, and wants
to.
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr: ['If she wants to sleep one night she may want to sleep two. We shall\nnever get her out of the house, perhaps.']
qText:
If she wants to sleep one night she may want to sleep two. We shall
never get her out of the house, perhaps.
speaker: Henry

qTextArr: ['Well?', 'And suppose we\ndon t get her out of the house? Would it matter? She would do no one any\nharm.']
qText:
Well? And suppose we
don t get her out of the house? Would it matter? She would do no one any
harm.
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr: ['No, Henry,', 'I didn t mean that. We will\nonly trouble Howards End for this one night. I take her to London\nto-morrow--']
qText:
No, Henry, I didn t mean that. We will
only trouble Howards End for this one night. I take her to London
to-morrow--
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr: ['Do you intend to sleep in a damp house, too?']
qText: Do you intend to sleep in a damp house, too?
speaker: Henry

qTextArr: ['She cannot be left alone.']
qText: She cannot be left alone.
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr: ['That s quite impossible! Madness. You must be here to meet Charles.']
qText: That s quite impossible! Madness. You must be here to meet Charles.
speaker: Henry

qTextArr: ['I have already told you that your message to Charles was unnecessary,\nand I have no desire to meet him.']
qText:
I have already told you that your message to Charles was unnecessary,
and I have no desire to meet him.
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr: ['Margaret--my Margaret.']
qText: Margaret--my Margaret.
speaker: Henry

qTextArr: ['What has this business to do with Charles? If it concerns me little, it\nconcerns you less, and Charles not at all.']
qText:
What has this business to do with Charles? If it concerns me little, it
concerns you less, and Charles not at all.
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr: ['As the future owner of Howards End,', 'I should say that it did concern Charles.']
qText: As the future owner of Howards End, I should say that it did concern Charles.
speaker: Henry

qTextArr: ['In what way? Will Helen s condition depreciate the property?']
qText: In what way? Will Helen s condition depreciate the property?
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr: ['My dear, you are forgetting yourself.']
qText: My dear, you are forgetting yourself.
speaker: Henry

qTextArr: ['I think you yourself recommended plain speaking.']
qText: I think you yourself recommended plain speaking.
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr:
['Helen commands my sympathy,', 'As your husband, I shall do
all for her that I can, and I have no doubt that she will prove more
sinned against than sinning. But I cannot treat her as if nothing has
happened. I should be false to my position in society if I did.']
qText:
Helen commands my sympathy, As your husband, I shall do
all for her that I can, and I have no doubt that she will prove more
sinned against than sinning. But I cannot treat her as if nothing has
happened. I should be false to my position in society if I did.
speaker: Henry

qTextArr:
['No, let us go back to Helen s
request,', 'It is unreasonable, but the request of an unhappy
girl. Tomorrow she will go to Germany, and trouble society no longer.
To-night she asks to sleep in your empty house--a house which you do not
care about, and which you have not occupied for over a year. May she?
Will you give my sister leave? Will you forgive her as you hope to be
forgiven, and as you have actually been forgiven? Forgive her for one
night only. That will be enough.']
qText:
No, let us go back to Helen s
request, It is unreasonable, but the request of an unhappy
girl. Tomorrow she will go to Germany, and trouble society no longer.
To-night she asks to sleep in your empty house--a house which you do not
care about, and which you have not occupied for over a year. May she?
Will you give my sister leave? Will you forgive her as you hope to be
forgiven, and as you have actually been forgiven? Forgive her for one
night only. That will be enough.
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr: ['As I have actually been forgiven--?']
qText: As I have actually been forgiven--?
speaker: Henry

qTextArr: ['Never mind for the moment what I mean by that,', 'Answer\nmy question.']
qText:
Never mind for the moment what I mean by that, Answer
my question.
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr:
['I seem rather
unaccommodating, but I have some experience of life, and know how one
thing leads to another. I am afraid that your sister had better sleep
at the hotel. I have my children and the memory of my dear wife to
consider. I am sorry, but see that she leaves my house at once.']
qText:
I seem rather
unaccommodating, but I have some experience of life, and know how one
thing leads to another. I am afraid that your sister had better sleep
at the hotel. I have my children and the memory of my dear wife to
consider. I am sorry, but see that she leaves my house at once.
speaker: Henry

qTextArr: ['You have mentioned Mrs. Wilcox.']
qText: You have mentioned Mrs. Wilcox.
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr: ['I beg your pardon?']
qText: I beg your pardon?
speaker: Henry

qTextArr: ['A rare occurrence. In reply, may I mention Mrs. Bast?']
qText: A rare occurrence. In reply, may I mention Mrs. Bast?
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr: ['You have not been yourself all day,']
qText: You have not been yourself all day,
speaker: Henry

qTextArr:
['Not any more of this!', 'You shall see the connection if it
kills you, Henry! You have had a mistress--I forgave you. My sister
has a lover--you drive her from the house. Do you see the connection?
Stupid, hypocritical, cruel--oh, contemptible!--a man who insults his
wife when she s alive and cants with her memory when she s dead. A man
who ruins a woman for his pleasure, and casts her off to ruin other men.
And gives bad financial advice, and then says he is not responsible.
These men are you. You can t recognise them, because you cannot connect.
I ve had enough of your unneeded kindness. I ve spoilt you long enough.
All your life you have been spoiled. Mrs. Wilcox spoiled you. No one has
ever told what you are--muddled, criminally muddled. Men like you use
repentance as a blind, so don t repent. Only say to yourself,  What
Helen has done, I ve done.']
qText:
Not any more of this! You shall see the connection if it
kills you, Henry! You have had a mistress--I forgave you. My sister
has a lover--you drive her from the house. Do you see the connection?
Stupid, hypocritical, cruel--oh, contemptible!--a man who insults his
wife when she s alive and cants with her memory when she s dead. A man
who ruins a woman for his pleasure, and casts her off to ruin other men.
And gives bad financial advice, and then says he is not responsible.
These men are you. You can t recognise them, because you cannot connect.
I ve had enough of your unneeded kindness. I ve spoilt you long enough.
All your life you have been spoiled. Mrs. Wilcox spoiled you. No one has
ever told what you are--muddled, criminally muddled. Men like you use
repentance as a blind, so don t repent. Only say to yourself,  What
Helen has done, I ve done.
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr: ['The two cases are different,']
qText: The two cases are different,
speaker: Henry

qTextArr:
['In what way different? You have betrayed Mrs. Wilcox, Helen only
herself. You remain in society, Helen can t. You have had only pleasure,
she may die. You have the insolence to talk to me of differences,
Henry?']
qText:
In what way different? You have betrayed Mrs. Wilcox, Helen only
herself. You remain in society, Helen can t. You have had only pleasure,
she may die. You have the insolence to talk to me of differences,
Henry?
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr:
['I perceive you are attempting blackmail. It is scarcely a pretty weapon
for a wife to use against her husband. My rule through life has been
never to pay the least attention to threats, and I can only repeat
what I said before: I do not give you and your sister leave to sleep at
Howards End.']
qText:
I perceive you are attempting blackmail. It is scarcely a pretty weapon
for a wife to use against her husband. My rule through life has been
never to pay the least attention to threats, and I can only repeat
what I said before: I do not give you and your sister leave to sleep at
Howards End.
speaker: Henry

qTextArr: ['I\nsuppose you realise that you are your sister s protector?']
qText:
I
suppose you realise that you are your sister s protector?
speaker: Charles Wilcox

qTextArr: ['In what sense?']
qText: In what sense?
speaker: Tibby

qTextArr: ['If a man played about with my sister, I d send a bullet through him,\nbut perhaps you don t mind.']
qText:
If a man played about with my sister, I d send a bullet through him,
but perhaps you don t mind.
speaker: Charles Wilcox

qTextArr: ['I mind very much,']
qText: I mind very much,
speaker: Tibby

qTextArr: ['Who d ye suspect, then? Speak out man. One always suspects some one.']
qText: Who d ye suspect, then? Speak out man. One always suspects some one.
speaker: Charles Wilcox

qTextArr: ['No one. I don t think so.']
qText: No one. I don t think so.
speaker: Tibby

qTextArr: ['You are hiding something,']
qText: You are hiding something,
speaker: Charles Wilcox

qTextArr: ['When you saw her last, did she mention any one s\nname? Yes or no!']
qText:
When you saw her last, did she mention any one s
name? Yes or no!
speaker: Charles Wilcox

qTextArr: ['In my rooms she mentioned some friends, called the Basts.']
qText: In my rooms she mentioned some friends, called the Basts.
speaker: Tibby

qTextArr: ['Who are the Basts?']
qText: Who are the Basts?
speaker: Charles Wilcox

qTextArr: ['People--friends of hers at Evie s wedding.']
qText: People--friends of hers at Evie s wedding.
speaker: Tibby

qTextArr: ['I don t remember. But, by great Scott, I do! My aunt told me about some\nrag-tag. Was she full of them when you saw her? Is there a man? Did she\nspeak of the man? Or--look here--have you had any dealings with him?']
qText:
I don t remember. But, by great Scott, I do! My aunt told me about some
rag-tag. Was she full of them when you saw her? Is there a man? Did she
speak of the man? Or--look here--have you had any dealings with him?
speaker: Charles Wilcox

qTextArr: ['I see--you are in his confidence. They met at your rooms. Oh, what a\nfamily, what a family! God help the poor pater--']
qText:
I see--you are in his confidence. They met at your rooms. Oh, what a
family, what a family! God help the poor pater--
speaker: Charles Wilcox

qTextArr:
['One isolates,', 'I isolated Mr. Wilcox from the other
forces that were pulling Leonard downhill. Consequently, I was full of
pity, and almost of revenge. For weeks I had blamed Mr. Wilcox only, and
so, when your letters came--']
qText:
One isolates, I isolated Mr. Wilcox from the other
forces that were pulling Leonard downhill. Consequently, I was full of
pity, and almost of revenge. For weeks I had blamed Mr. Wilcox only, and
so, when your letters came--
speaker: Helen

qTextArr: ['I need never have written them,', 'They never shielded\nHenry. How hopeless it is to tidy away the past, even for others!']
qText:
I need never have written them, They never shielded
Henry. How hopeless it is to tidy away the past, even for others!
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr: ['I did not know that it was your own idea to dismiss the Basts.']
qText: I did not know that it was your own idea to dismiss the Basts.
speaker: Helen

qTextArr: ['Looking back, that was wrong of me.']
qText: Looking back, that was wrong of me.
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr:
['Looking back, darling, I know that it was right. It is right to save
the man whom one loves. I am less enthusiastic about justice now. But we
both thought you wrote at his dictation. It seemed the last touch of his
callousness. Being very much wrought up by this time--and Mrs. Bast
was upstairs. I had not seen her, and had talked for a long time to
Leonard--I had snubbed him for no reason, and that should have warned me
I was in danger. So when the notes came I wanted us to go to you for an
explanation. He said that he guessed the explanation--he knew of it, and
you mustn t know. I pressed him to tell me. He said no one must know; it
was something to do with his wife. Right up to the end we were Mr. Bast
and Miss Schlegel. I was going to tell him that he must be frank with me
when I saw his eyes, and guessed that Mr. Wilcox had ruined him in two
ways, not one. I drew him to me. I made him tell me. I felt very lonely
myself. He is not to blame. He would have gone on worshipping me. I want
never to see him again, though it sounds appalling. I wanted to give him
money and feel finished. Oh, Meg, the little that is known about these
things!']
qText:
Looking back, darling, I know that it was right. It is right to save
the man whom one loves. I am less enthusiastic about justice now. But we
both thought you wrote at his dictation. It seemed the last touch of his
callousness. Being very much wrought up by this time--and Mrs. Bast
was upstairs. I had not seen her, and had talked for a long time to
Leonard--I had snubbed him for no reason, and that should have warned me
I was in danger. So when the notes came I wanted us to go to you for an
explanation. He said that he guessed the explanation--he knew of it, and
you mustn t know. I pressed him to tell me. He said no one must know; it
was something to do with his wife. Right up to the end we were Mr. Bast
and Miss Schlegel. I was going to tell him that he must be frank with me
when I saw his eyes, and guessed that Mr. Wilcox had ruined him in two
ways, not one. I drew him to me. I made him tell me. I felt very lonely
myself. He is not to blame. He would have gone on worshipping me. I want
never to see him again, though it sounds appalling. I wanted to give him
money and feel finished. Oh, Meg, the little that is known about these
things!
speaker: Helen

qTextArr: ['The little, too, that is known about growth! Both times it was\nloneliness, and the night, and panic afterwards. Did Leonard grow out of\nPaul?']
qText:
The little, too, that is known about growth! Both times it was
loneliness, and the night, and panic afterwards. Did Leonard grow out of
Paul?
speaker: Helen

qTextArr: ['Leonard is a better growth\nthan madness,', 'I was afraid that you would react against Paul\nuntil you went over the verge.']
qText:
Leonard is a better growth
than madness, I was afraid that you would react against Paul
until you went over the verge.
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr:
['I did react until I found poor Leonard. I am steady now. I shan t ever
like your Henry, dearest Meg, or even speak kindly about him, but all
that blinding hate is over. I shall never rave against Wilcoxes any
more. I understand how you married him, and you will now be very happy.']
qText:
I did react until I found poor Leonard. I am steady now. I shan t ever
like your Henry, dearest Meg, or even speak kindly about him, but all
that blinding hate is over. I shall never rave against Wilcoxes any
more. I understand how you married him, and you will now be very happy.
speaker: Helen

qTextArr: ['Yes,', 'I do at last\nunderstand.']
qText:
Yes, I do at last
understand.
speaker: Helen

qTextArr: ['Except Mrs. Wilcox, dearest, no one understands our little movements.']
qText: Except Mrs. Wilcox, dearest, no one understands our little movements.
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr: ['Because in death--I agree.']
qText: Because in death--I agree.
speaker: Helen

qTextArr:
['Not quite. I feel that you and I and Henry are only fragments of that
woman s mind. She knows everything. She is everything. She is the house,
and the tree that leans over it. People have their own deaths as well
as their own lives, and even if there is nothing beyond death, we shall
differ in our nothingness. I cannot believe that knowledge such as hers
will perish with knowledge such as mine. She knew about realities. She
knew when people were in love, though she was not in the room. I don t
doubt that she knew when Henry deceived her.']
qText:
Not quite. I feel that you and I and Henry are only fragments of that
woman s mind. She knows everything. She is everything. She is the house,
and the tree that leans over it. People have their own deaths as well
as their own lives, and even if there is nothing beyond death, we shall
differ in our nothingness. I cannot believe that knowledge such as hers
will perish with knowledge such as mine. She knew about realities. She
knew when people were in love, though she was not in the room. I don t
doubt that she knew when Henry deceived her.
speaker: Margaret

qText: Oh, good-night, Miss Avery.

qText: Why should Miss Avery work for us?
speaker: Helen

qTextArr: ['Why, indeed?']
qText: Why, indeed?
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr: ['This is not quite our house yet,', 'When Miss Avery called,\nI felt we are only a couple of tourists.']
qText:
This is not quite our house yet, When Miss Avery called,

qText: But affectionate tourists.

qText: But tourists who pretend each hotel is their home.

qTextArr:
['I can t pretend very long,', 'Sitting under this tree one
forgets, but I know that to-morrow I shall see the moon rise out of
Germany. Not all your goodness can alter the facts of the case. Unless
you will come with me.']
qText:
I can t pretend very long, Sitting under this tree one
forgets, but I know that to-morrow I shall see the moon rise out of
Germany. Not all your goodness can alter the facts of the case. Unless
you will come with me.
speaker: Helen

qTextArr: ['Are you serious in asking me, Helen? Should I get on with your Monica?']
qText: Are you serious in asking me, Helen? Should I get on with your Monica?
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr: ['You would not, but I am serious in asking you.']
qText: You would not, but I am serious in asking you.
speaker: Helen

qTextArr: ['Still, no more plans now. And no more reminiscences.']
qText: Still, no more plans now. And no more reminiscences.
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr: ['Sleep now,']
qText: Sleep now,
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr: ['Brute--you brute, I couldn t have--']
qText: Brute--you brute, I couldn t have--

Oh what SHALL I do, whatever

She minds that! What would she say if

qText: Excuse me, sir, but is your boss married?

qText: She s out,

qText: I don t know. Hilton. Howards End. Who is it?

qTextArr:
['Why horrible? It s ordinary
light from the moon.', 'But it moves.', 'So does the moon.', 'But it is a
clenched fist.', 'Why not?', 'But it is going to touch me.', 'Let it.', 'Is there life in the
moon?', 'Of course.', 'But I thought it was uninhabited.', 'Not by Time,
Death, Judgment, and the smaller snakes.']
qText:
Why horrible? It s ordinary
light from the moon. But it moves. So does the moon. But it is a
clenched fist. Why not? But it is going to touch me. Let it. Is there life in the
moon? Of course. But I thought it was uninhabited. Not by Time,
Death, Judgment, and the smaller snakes.
speaker: Leonard

qTextArr: ['Smaller snakes!', 'What a notion!']
qText: Smaller snakes! What a notion!
speaker: Leonard

qTextArr: ['I say, Jacky, I m going out for a bit.']
qText: I say, Jacky, I m going out for a bit.

qText: Hullo, Len! What ho, Len!

qTextArr: ['What ho, Jacky! see you again later.']
qText: What ho, Jacky! see you again later.

qTextArr: ['Oh, is he there? I am not surprised. I now thrash him within an inch of\nhis life.']

Oh, is he there? I am not surprised. I now thrash him within an inch of

qText: Bring me a stick.

qText:
Get some water, He s shamming. Of course I only used the blade. Here, carry him out

qText: That s enough,
speaker: Charles Wilcox

qTextArr: ['Yes, murder s enough,']
qText: Yes, murder s enough,

qTextArr: ['I don t know where she is, pater', 'Dolly kept back dinner\nnearly an hour for her.']
qText:
I don t know where she is, pater Dolly kept back dinner

qTextArr: ['Tell me when she comes in.']
qText: Tell me when she comes in.
speaker: Henry

qTextArr: ['I ll sit up for her as late as you like, but she can hardly be coming.\nIsn t she stopping with her sister at the hotel?']
qText:
I ll sit up for her as late as you like, but she can hardly be coming.
Isn t she stopping with her sister at the hotel?

qTextArr: ['Perhaps,', 'perhaps.']
qText: Perhaps, perhaps.
speaker: Henry

qTextArr: ['Can I do anything for you, sir?']
qText: Can I do anything for you, sir?
speaker: Charles Wilcox

qTextArr: ['Not to-night, my boy.']
qText: Not to-night, my boy.
speaker: Henry

qTextArr: ['I can t sleep,', 'I\nhad better have a talk with you and get it over.']
qText:
I can t sleep, I

qTextArr:
['She will feel differently in the morning,', 'But I cannot let this kind of
thing continue without comment. I am morally certain that she is with
her sister at Howards End. The house is mine--and, Charles, it will be
yours--and when I say that no one is to live there, I mean that no one
is to live there. I won t have it.', 'To my mind this question is connected with something far greater, the
rights of property itself.']
qText:
She will feel differently in the morning, But I cannot let this kind of
thing continue without comment. I am morally certain that she is with
her sister at Howards End. The house is mine--and, Charles, it will be
yours--and when I say that no one is to live there, I mean that no one
is to live there. I won t have it. To my mind this question is connected with something far greater, the
rights of property itself.
speaker: Henry

qTextArr: ['Undoubtedly,']
qText: Undoubtedly,
speaker: Charles Wilcox

qTextArr:
['I don t want you to conclude that my wife and I had
anything of the nature of a quarrel. She was only overwrought, as who
would not be? I shall do what I can for Helen, but on the understanding
that they clear out of the house at once. Do you see? That is a sine qua
non.']
qText:
I don t want you to conclude that my wife and I had
anything of the nature of a quarrel. She was only overwrought, as who
would not be? I shall do what I can for Helen, but on the understanding
that they clear out of the house at once. Do you see? That is a sine qua
non.
speaker: Henry

qTextArr: ['Then at eight to-morrow I may go up in the car?']
qText: Then at eight to-morrow I may go up in the car?
speaker: Charles Wilcox

qTextArr: ['Eight or earlier. Say that you are acting as my representative, and, of\ncourse, use no violence, Charles.']
qText:
Eight or earlier. Say that you are acting as my representative, and, of
course, use no violence, Charles.
speaker: Henry

qTextArr: ['It has been pretty horrible,', 'They were there,\nand they had the man up there with them too.']
qText:
It has been pretty horrible, They were there,
and they had the man up there with them too.
speaker: Charles Wilcox

qTextArr: ['What--what man?']
qText: What--what man?
speaker: Henry

qTextArr: ['I told you last night. His name was Bast.']
qText: I told you last night. His name was Bast.
speaker: Charles Wilcox

qTextArr: ['My God! is it possible?', 'In your mother s house!\nCharles, in your mother s house!']
qText:
My God! is it possible? In your mother s house!
Charles, in your mother s house!
speaker: Henry

qTextArr:
['I know, pater. That was what I felt. As a matter of fact, there is
no need to trouble about the man. He was in the last stages of heart
disease, and just before I could show him what I thought of him he went
off. The police are seeing about it at this moment.']
qText:
I know, pater. That was what I felt. As a matter of fact, there is
no need to trouble about the man. He was in the last stages of heart
disease, and just before I could show him what I thought of him he went
off. The police are seeing about it at this moment.
speaker: Charles Wilcox

qTextArr:
['I got up there--oh, it couldn t have been more than half-past seven.
The Avery woman was lighting a fire for them. They were still upstairs.
I waited in the drawing-room. We were all moderately civil and
collected, though I had my suspicions. I gave them your message, and
Mrs. Wilcox said,']
qText:
I got up there--oh, it couldn t have been more than half-past seven.
The Avery woman was lighting a fire for them. They were still upstairs.
I waited in the drawing-room. We were all moderately civil and
collected, though I had my suspicions. I gave them your message, and
Mrs. Wilcox said,
speaker: Charles Wilcox

qTextArr: ['in that way of hers.']
qText: in that way of hers.
speaker: Charles Wilcox

qTextArr: ['Nothing else?']
qText: Nothing else?
speaker: Henry

qTextArr: ['I promised to tell you,  with her love,  that she was going to Germany\nwith her sister this evening. That was all we had time for.']
qText:
I promised to tell you,  with her love,  that she was going to Germany
with her sister this evening. That was all we had time for.
speaker: Charles Wilcox

qTextArr:
['Because by then I suppose the man got tired of hiding, for suddenly
Mrs. Wilcox screamed out his name. I recognised it, and I went for him
in the hall. Was I right, pater? I thought things were going a little
too far.']
qText:
Because by then I suppose the man got tired of hiding, for suddenly
Mrs. Wilcox screamed out his name. I recognised it, and I went for him
in the hall. Was I right, pater? I thought things were going a little
too far.
speaker: Charles Wilcox

qTextArr: ['Right, my dear boy? I don t know. But you would have been no son of\nmine if you hadn t. Then did he just--just--crumple up as you said?']
qText:
Right, my dear boy? I don t know. But you would have been no son of
mine if you hadn t. Then did he just--just--crumple up as you said?
speaker: Henry

qTextArr: ['He caught hold of the bookcase, which came down over him. So I merely\nput the sword down and carried him into the garden. We all thought he\nwas shamming. However, he s dead right enough. Awful business!']
qText:
He caught hold of the bookcase, which came down over him. So I merely
put the sword down and carried him into the garden. We all thought he
was shamming. However, he s dead right enough. Awful business!
speaker: Charles Wilcox

qTextArr: ['Sword?', 'What sword? Whose\nsword?']
qText:
Sword? What sword? Whose
sword?
speaker: Henry

qTextArr: ['A sword of theirs.']
qText: A sword of theirs.
speaker: Charles Wilcox

qTextArr: ['What were you doing with it?']
qText: What were you doing with it?
speaker: Henry

qTextArr: ['Well, didn t you see, pater, I had to snatch up the first thing handy.\nI hadn t a riding-whip or stick. I caught him once or twice over the\nshoulders with the flat of their old German sword.']
qText:
Well, didn t you see, pater, I had to snatch up the first thing handy.
I hadn t a riding-whip or stick. I caught him once or twice over the
shoulders with the flat of their old German sword.
speaker: Charles Wilcox

qTextArr: ['Then what?']
qText: Then what?
speaker: Henry

qTextArr: ['He pulled over the bookcase, as I said, and fell,']
qText: He pulled over the bookcase, as I said, and fell,
speaker: Charles Wilcox

qTextArr: ['But the real cause was heart disease? Of that you re sure?']
qText: But the real cause was heart disease? Of that you re sure?
speaker: Henry

qTextArr: ['That or a fit. However, we shall hear more than enough at the inquest\non such unsavoury topics.']
qText:
That or a fit. However, we shall hear more than enough at the inquest
on such unsavoury topics.
speaker: Charles Wilcox

qTextArr: ['I think I ll go round to the police-station,']
qText: I think I ll go round to the police-station,
speaker: Henry

qTextArr: ['What for?']
qText: What for?
speaker: Dolly

qTextArr: ['Very well, sir. Which car will you have?']
qText: Very well, sir. Which car will you have?
speaker: Charles Wilcox

qTextArr: ['I think I ll walk.']
qText: I think I ll walk.
speaker: Henry

qTextArr: ['It s a good half-mile,', 'The\nsun s very hot for April. Shan t I take you up, and then, perhaps, a\nlittle spin round by Tewin?']
qText:
It s a good half-mile, The
sun s very hot for April. Shan t I take you up, and then, perhaps, a
little spin round by Tewin?
speaker: Charles Wilcox

qTextArr: ['You go on as if I didn t know my own mind,', 'You young fellows  one idea is to get into\na motor. I tell you, I want to walk; I m very fond of walking.']
qText:
You go on as if I didn t know my own mind, You young fellows  one idea is to get into
a motor. I tell you, I want to walk; I m very fond of walking.
speaker: Henry

qTextArr: ['Oh, all right; I m about the house if you want me for anything. I\nthought of not going up to the office to-day, if that is your wish.']
qText:
Oh, all right; I m about the house if you want me for anything. I
thought of not going up to the office to-day, if that is your wish.
speaker: Charles Wilcox

qTextArr: ['It is, indeed, my boy,']
qText: It is, indeed, my boy,
speaker: Henry

qTextArr: ['I expected that,', 'I shall naturally be the most\nimportant witness there.']
qText:
I expected that, I shall naturally be the most
important witness there.
speaker: Charles Wilcox

qTextArr: ['No one ever told\nthe lad he ll have a child']
qText:
No one ever told
the lad he ll have a child
speaker: Miss Avery

qTextArr: ['No\ndoubt Mr. Wilcox may have induced death,', 'but if it wasn t\none thing it would have been another as you know.']
qText:
No
doubt Mr. Wilcox may have induced death, but if it wasn t
one thing it would have been another as you know.
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr: ['Is it the keys that Mr. Wilcox wants?']
qText: Is it the keys that Mr. Wilcox wants?
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr: ['He didn t say, madam.']
qText: He didn t say, madam.
speaker: Crane

qTextArr: ['You haven t any note for me?']
qText: You haven t any note for me?
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr: ['He didn t say, madam.']
qText: He didn t say, madam.
speaker: Crane

qTextArr: ['I prefer to\ndiscuss things with you outside.']
qText:
I prefer to
discuss things with you outside.
speaker: Henry

qTextArr: ['It will be more appropriate in the road, I am afraid,', 'Did you get my message?']
qText: It will be more appropriate in the road, I am afraid, Did you get my message?
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr: ['What about?']
qText: What about?
speaker: Henry

qTextArr: ['I am going to Germany with my sister. I must tell you now that I shall\nmake it my permanent home. Our talk last night was more important than\nyou have realised. I am unable to forgive you and am leaving you.']
qText:
I am going to Germany with my sister. I must tell you now that I shall
make it my permanent home. Our talk last night was more important than
you have realised. I am unable to forgive you and am leaving you.
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr: ['I am extremely tired,', 'I have been\nwalking about all the morning, and wish to sit down.']
qText:
I am extremely tired, I have been
walking about all the morning, and wish to sit down.
speaker: Henry

qTextArr: ['Certainly, if you will consent to sit on the grass.']
qText: Certainly, if you will consent to sit on the grass.
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr: ['Here are your keys,']
qText: Here are your keys,
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr: ['I have something to tell you,']
qText: I have something to tell you,
speaker: Henry

qTextArr: ['I don t want to hear it,', 'My sister is going to be\nill. My life is going to be with her now. We must manage to build up\nsomething, she and I and her child.']
qText:
I don t want to hear it, My sister is going to be
ill. My life is going to be with her now. We must manage to build up
something, she and I and her child.
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr: ['Where are you going?']
qText: Where are you going?
speaker: Henry

qTextArr: ['Munich. We start after the inquest, if she is not too ill.']
qText: Munich. We start after the inquest, if she is not too ill.
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr: ['After the inquest?']
qText: After the inquest?
speaker: Henry

qText: Yes.
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr: ['Have you realised what the verdict at the inquest will be?']
qText: Have you realised what the verdict at the inquest will be?
speaker: Henry

qTextArr: ['Yes, heart disease.']
qText: Yes, heart disease.
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr: ['No, my dear; manslaughter.']
qText: No, my dear; manslaughter.
speaker: Henry

qTextArr: ['Manslaughter,', 'Charles may go to prison. I dare\nnot tell him. I don t know what to do--what to do. I m broken--I m\nended.']
qText:
Manslaughter, Charles may go to prison. I dare
not tell him. I don t know what to do--what to do. I m broken--I m
ended.
speaker: Henry

qTextArr: ['I haven t any idea,', 'Do you suppose baby may, Meg?']
qText: I haven t any idea, Do you suppose baby may, Meg?
speaker: Helen

qTextArr: ['What was that?']
qText: What was that?
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr: ['Tom wants to know whether baby is old enough to play with hay?']
qText: Tom wants to know whether baby is old enough to play with hay?
speaker: Helen

qTextArr: ['I haven t the least notion,']
qText: I haven t the least notion,
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr:
['Now, Tom, baby is not to stand; he is not to lie on his face; he is not
to lie so that his head wags; he is not to be teased or tickled; and he
is not to be cut into two or more pieces by the cutter. Will you be as
careful as all that?']
qText:
Now, Tom, baby is not to stand; he is not to lie on his face; he is not
to lie so that his head wags; he is not to be teased or tickled; and he
is not to be cut into two or more pieces by the cutter. Will you be as
careful as all that?
speaker: Helen

qTextArr: ['That child is a wonderful nursemaid,']
qText: That child is a wonderful nursemaid,
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr: ['He is fond of baby. That s why he does it!', 'They re going to be lifelong friends.']
qText: He is fond of baby. That s why he does it! They re going to be lifelong friends.
speaker: Helen

qTextArr: ['Starting at the ages of six and one?']
qText: Starting at the ages of six and one?
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr: ['Of course. It will be a great thing for Tom.']
qText: Of course. It will be a great thing for Tom.
speaker: Helen

qTextArr: ['It may be a greater thing for baby.']
qText: It may be a greater thing for baby.
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr: ['What a time they all are!', 'What can they be doing inside?', 'I wish Henry was out to enjoy this,', 'This lovely weather\nand to be shut up in the house! It s very hard.']
qText:
What a time they all are! What can they be doing inside? I wish Henry was out to enjoy this, This lovely weather
and to be shut up in the house! It s very hard.
speaker: Helen

qTextArr: ['It has to be,', 'The hay fever is his chief objection\nagainst living here, but he thinks it worth while.']
qText:
It has to be, The hay fever is his chief objection
against living here, but he thinks it worth while.
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr: ['Meg, is or isn t he ill? I can t make out.']
qText: Meg, is or isn t he ill? I can t make out.
speaker: Helen

qTextArr: ['Not ill. Eternally tired. He has worked very hard all his life, and\nnoticed nothing. Those are the people who collapse when they do notice a\nthing.']
qText:
Not ill. Eternally tired. He has worked very hard all his life, and
noticed nothing. Those are the people who collapse when they do notice a
thing.
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr: ['I suppose he worries dreadfully about his part of the tangle.']
qText: I suppose he worries dreadfully about his part of the tangle.
speaker: Helen

qTextArr: ['Dreadfully. That is why I wish Dolly had not come, too, to-day. Still,\nhe wanted them all to come. It has to be.']
qText:
Dreadfully. That is why I wish Dolly had not come, too, to-day. Still,
he wanted them all to come. It has to be.
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr: ['Why does he want them?']
qText: Why does he want them?
speaker: Helen

qTextArr: ['Meg, may I tell you something? I like Henry.']
qText: Meg, may I tell you something? I like Henry.
speaker: Helen

qTextArr: ['You d be odd if you didn t,']
qText: You d be odd if you didn t,
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr: ['I usen t to.']
qText: I usen t to.
speaker: Helen

qTextArr: ['Usen t!']
qText: Usen t!
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr: ['I like Henry because he does worry.']
qText: I like Henry because he does worry.
speaker: Helen

qTextArr: ['And he likes you because you don t.']
qText: And he likes you because you don t.
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr: ['About love,']
qText: About love,
speaker: Helen

qTextArr:
['I mean a woman s love for a man. I supposed I should hang my life on
to that once, and was driven up and down and about as if something was
worrying through me. But everything is peaceful now; I seem cured. That
Herr Forstmeister, whom Frieda keeps writing about, must be a noble
character, but he doesn t see that I shall never marry him or anyone. It
isn t shame or mistrust of myself. I simply couldn t. I m ended. I used
to be so dreamy about a man s love as a girl, and think that for good
or evil love must be the great thing. But it hasn t been; it has been
itself a dream. Do you agree?']
qText:
I mean a woman s love for a man. I supposed I should hang my life on
to that once, and was driven up and down and about as if something was
worrying through me. But everything is peaceful now; I seem cured. That
Herr Forstmeister, whom Frieda keeps writing about, must be a noble
character, but he doesn t see that I shall never marry him or anyone. It
isn t shame or mistrust of myself. I simply couldn t. I m ended. I used
to be so dreamy about a man s love as a girl, and think that for good
or evil love must be the great thing. But it hasn t been; it has been
itself a dream. Do you agree?
speaker: Helen

qTextArr: ['I do not agree. I do not.']
qText: I do not agree. I do not.
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr:
['I ought to remember Leonard as my lover,', 'I tempted him, and killed him, and it is surely the
least I can do. I would like to throw out all my heart to Leonard on
such an afternoon as this. But I cannot. It is no good pretending. I
am forgetting him.', 'How nothing seems to
match--how, my darling, my precious--']
qText:
I ought to remember Leonard as my lover, I tempted him, and killed him, and it is surely the
least I can do. I would like to throw out all my heart to Leonard on
such an afternoon as this. But I cannot. It is no good pretending. I
am forgetting him. How nothing seems to
match--how, my darling, my precious--
speaker: Helen

qTextArr: ['Tommy!']
qText: Tommy!
speaker: Helen

qTextArr: ['Yes, please?']
qText: Yes, please?
speaker: Tom

qTextArr:
['Baby s not to try and stand.--There s something wanting in me. I see
you loving Henry, and understanding him better daily, and I know
that death wouldn t part you in the least. But I--Is it some awful,
appalling, criminal defect?']
qText:
Baby s not to try and stand.--There s something wanting in me. I see
you loving Henry, and understanding him better daily, and I know
that death wouldn t part you in the least. But I--Is it some awful,
appalling, criminal defect?
speaker: Helen

qTextArr:
['It is only that people are far more
different than is pretended. All over the world men and women are
worrying because they cannot develop as they are supposed to develop.
Here and there they have the matter out, and it comforts them. Don t
fret yourself, Helen. Develop what you have; love your child. I do not
love children. I am thankful to have none. I can play with their beauty
and charm, but that is all--nothing real, not one scrap of what there
ought to be. And others--others go farther still, and move outside
humanity altogether. A place, as well as a person, may catch the glow.
Don t you see that all this leads to comfort in the end? It is part of
the battle against sameness. Differences, eternal differences, planted
by God in a single family, so that there may always be colour; sorrow
perhaps, but colour in the daily grey. Then I can t have you worrying
about Leonard. Don t drag in the personal when it will not come. Forget
him.']
qText:
It is only that people are far more
different than is pretended. All over the world men and women are
worrying because they cannot develop as they are supposed to develop.
Here and there they have the matter out, and it comforts them. Don t
fret yourself, Helen. Develop what you have; love your child. I do not
love children. I am thankful to have none. I can play with their beauty
and charm, but that is all--nothing real, not one scrap of what there
ought to be. And others--others go farther still, and move outside
humanity altogether. A place, as well as a person, may catch the glow.
Don t you see that all this leads to comfort in the end? It is part of
the battle against sameness. Differences, eternal differences, planted
by God in a single family, so that there may always be colour; sorrow
perhaps, but colour in the daily grey. Then I can t have you worrying
about Leonard. Don t drag in the personal when it will not come. Forget
him.
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr: ['Yes, yes, but what has Leonard got out of life?']
qText: Yes, yes, but what has Leonard got out of life?
speaker: Helen

qTextArr: ['Perhaps an adventure.']
qText: Perhaps an adventure.
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr: ['Is that enough?']
qText: Is that enough?
speaker: Helen

qTextArr: ['Not for us. But for him.']
qText: Not for us. But for him.
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr: ['Is it sweetening yet?']
qText: Is it sweetening yet?
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr: ['No, only withered.']
qText: No, only withered.
speaker: Helen

qTextArr: ['It will sweeten to-morrow.']
qText: It will sweeten to-morrow.
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr: ['Oh, Meg, you are a person,', 'Think of the\nracket and torture this time last year. But now I couldn t stop unhappy\nif I tried. What a change--and all through you!']
qText:
Oh, Meg, you are a person, Think of the
racket and torture this time last year. But now I couldn t stop unhappy
if I tried. What a change--and all through you!
speaker: Helen

qTextArr: ['Oh, we merely settled down. You and Henry learnt to understand one\nanother and to forgive, all through the autumn and the winter.']
qText:
Oh, we merely settled down. You and Henry learnt to understand one
another and to forgive, all through the autumn and the winter.
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr: ['Yes, but who settled us down?']
qText: Yes, but who settled us down?
speaker: Helen

qTextArr:
['You!', 'You did it all, sweetest, though you re too stupid
to see. Living here was your plan--I wanted you; he wanted you; and
everyone said it was impossible, but you knew. Just think of our lives
without you, Meg--I and baby with Monica, revolting by theory, he handed
about from Dolly to Evie. But you picked up the pieces, and made us a
home. Can t it strike you--even for a moment--that your life has been
heroic? Can t you remember the two months after Charles s arrest, when
you began to act, and did all?']
qText:
You! You did it all, sweetest, though you re too stupid
to see. Living here was your plan--I wanted you; he wanted you; and
everyone said it was impossible, but you knew. Just think of our lives
without you, Meg--I and baby with Monica, revolting by theory, he handed
about from Dolly to Evie. But you picked up the pieces, and made us a
home. Can t it strike you--even for a moment--that your life has been
heroic? Can t you remember the two months after Charles s arrest, when
you began to act, and did all?
speaker: Helen

qTextArr:
['You were both ill at the time,', 'I did the obvious
things. I had two invalids to nurse. Here was a house, ready furnished
and empty. It was obvious. I didn t know myself it would turn into a
permanent home. No doubt I have done a little towards straightening the
tangle, but things that I can t phrase have helped me.']
qText:
You were both ill at the time, I did the obvious
things. I had two invalids to nurse. Here was a house, ready furnished
and empty. It was obvious. I didn t know myself it would turn into a
permanent home. No doubt I have done a little towards straightening the
tangle, but things that I can t phrase have helped me.
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr: ['I hope it will be permanent,']
qText: I hope it will be permanent,
speaker: Helen

qTextArr: ['I think so. There are moments when I feel Howards End peculiarly our\nown.']
qText:
I think so. There are moments when I feel Howards End peculiarly our
own.
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr: ['All the same, London s creeping.']
qText: All the same, London s creeping.
speaker: Helen

qTextArr: ['You see that in Surrey and even Hampshire now,', 'I can\nsee it from the Purbeck Downs. And London is only part of something\nelse, I m afraid. Life s going to be melted down, all over the world.']
qText:
You see that in Surrey and even Hampshire now, I can
see it from the Purbeck Downs. And London is only part of something
else, I m afraid. Life s going to be melted down, all over the world.
speaker: Helen

qTextArr:
['Because a thing is going strong now, it need not go strong for ever,', 'This craze for motion has only set in during the last hundred
years. It may be followed by a civilisation that won t be a movement,
because it will rest on the earth. All the signs are against it now, but
I can t help hoping, and very early in the morning in the garden I feel
that our house is the future as well as the past.']
qText:
Because a thing is going strong now, it need not go strong for ever, This craze for motion has only set in during the last hundred
years. It may be followed by a civilisation that won t be a movement,
because it will rest on the earth. All the signs are against it now, but
I can t help hoping, and very early in the morning in the garden I feel
that our house is the future as well as the past.
speaker: Helen

qTextArr: ['Oh, take care--!']
qText: Oh, take care--!
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr: ['The conclave s breaking at last. I ll go.']
qText: The conclave s breaking at last. I ll go.
speaker: Helen

qTextArr: ['My father has asked for you,']
qText: My father has asked for you,
speaker: Paul

qTextArr: ['We have been talking business,', 'but I dare say you knew\nall about it beforehand.']
qText:
We have been talking business, but I dare say you knew
all about it beforehand.
speaker: Paul

qTextArr: ['Yes, I did.']
qText: Yes, I did.
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr: ['Is this going to suit everyone?', 'Because I\ndon t want you all coming here later on and complaining that I have been\nunfair.']
qText:
Is this going to suit everyone? Because I
don t want you all coming here later on and complaining that I have been
unfair.
speaker: Henry

qTextArr: ['It s apparently got to suit us,']
qText: It s apparently got to suit us,
speaker: Paul

qTextArr: ['I beg your pardon, my boy. You have only to speak, and I will leave the\nhouse to you instead.']
qText:
I beg your pardon, my boy. You have only to speak, and I will leave the
house to you instead.
speaker: Henry

qTextArr: ['As I ve\ngiven up the outdoor life that suited me, and I have come home to look\nafter the business, it s no good my settling down here,', 'It s not really the country, and it s not the town.']
qText:
As I ve
given up the outdoor life that suited me, and I have come home to look
after the business, it s no good my settling down here, It s not really the country, and it s not the town.
speaker: Paul

qTextArr: ['Very well. Does my arrangement suit you, Evie?']
qText: Very well. Does my arrangement suit you, Evie?
speaker: Henry

qTextArr: ['Of course, father.']
qText: Of course, father.
speaker: Evie

qTextArr: ['And you, Dolly?']
qText: And you, Dolly?
speaker: Henry

qTextArr:
['Perfectly splendidly,', 'I thought Charles wanted
it for the boys, but last time I saw him he said no, because we cannot
possibly live in this part of England again. Charles says we ought
to change our name, but I cannot think what to, for Wilcox just suits
Charles and me, and I can t think of any other name.']
qText:
Perfectly splendidly, I thought Charles wanted
it for the boys, but last time I saw him he said no, because we cannot
possibly live in this part of England again. Charles says we ought
to change our name, but I cannot think what to, for Wilcox just suits
Charles and me, and I can t think of any other name.
speaker: Dolly
menEnts: [[], [['Charles Wilcox'], ['Charles Wilcox'], ['Charles Wilcox'], ['Charles Wilcox', 'Dolly'], ['Charles Wilcox'], ['Charles Wilcox', 'Dolly'], ['Charles', 'Dolly'], ['Charles Wilcox']]]

qTextArr:
['Then I leave Howards End to my wife absolutely,', 'And let
everyone understand that; and after I am dead let there be no jealousy
and no surprise.', 'In consequence, I leave my wife no money,', 'That is her own
wish. All that she would have had will be divided among you. I am also
giving you a great deal in my lifetime, so that you may be independent
of me. That is her wish, too. She also is giving away a great deal of
money. She intends to diminish her income by half during the next ten
years; she intends when she dies to leave the house to her nephew, down
in the field. Is all that clear? Does everyone understand?']
qText:
Then I leave Howards End to my wife absolutely, And let
everyone understand that; and after I am dead let there be no jealousy
and no surprise. In consequence, I leave my wife no money, That is her own
wish. All that she would have had will be divided among you. I am also
giving you a great deal in my lifetime, so that you may be independent
of me. That is her wish, too. She also is giving away a great deal of
money. She intends to diminish her income by half during the next ten
years; she intends when she dies to leave the house to her nephew, down
in the field. Is all that clear? Does everyone understand?
speaker: Henry

qTextArr: ['Down in the field? Oh, come! I think we might have had the whole\nestablishment, piccaninnies included.']
qText:
Down in the field? Oh, come! I think we might have had the whole
establishment, piccaninnies included.
speaker: Paul

qTextArr: ['Don t, Paul. You promised you d take care.']
qText: Don t, Paul. You promised you d take care.
speaker: Evie

qTextArr: ['Good-bye, old girl,', 'don t you worry\nabout me.']
qText:
Good-bye, old girl, don t you worry
about me.
speaker: Henry

qTextArr: ['Good-bye, dad.']
qText: Good-bye, dad.
speaker: Evie

qTextArr: ['Good-bye, Mr. Wilcox. It does seem curious that Mrs. Wilcox\nshould have left Margaret Howards End, and yet she get it, after all.']
qText:
Good-bye, Mr. Wilcox. It does seem curious that Mrs. Wilcox
should have left Margaret Howards End, and yet she get it, after all.
speaker: Dolly

qTextArr: ['Goodbye,']
qText: Goodbye,
speaker: Evie

qTextArr: ['Good-bye.']
qText: Good-bye.
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr: ['Good-bye, Dolly.']
qText: Good-bye, Dolly.
speaker: Henry

qTextArr: ['So long, father.']
qText: So long, father.
speaker: Paul

qTextArr: ['Good-bye, my boy; always take care of yourself.']
qText: Good-bye, my boy; always take care of yourself.
speaker: Henry

qTextArr: ['Good-bye, Mrs. Wilcox.']
qText: Good-bye, Mrs. Wilcox.
speaker: Paul

qTextArr: ['Good-bye.']
qText: Good-bye.
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr: ['Could you tell me,\nHenry, what was that about Mrs. Wilcox having left me Howards End?']
qText:
Could you tell me,
Henry, what was that about Mrs. Wilcox having left me Howards End?
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr:
['Yes, she did. But that is a very old story.
When she was ill and you were so kind to her she wanted to make you some
return, and, not being herself at the time, scribbled  Howards End  on
a piece of paper. I went into it thoroughly, and, as it was clearly
fanciful, I set it aside, little knowing what my Margaret would be to me
in the future.']
qText:
Yes, she did. But that is a very old story.
When she was ill and you were so kind to her she wanted to make you some
return, and, not being herself at the time, scribbled  Howards End  on
a piece of paper. I went into it thoroughly, and, as it was clearly
fanciful, I set it aside, little knowing what my Margaret would be to me
in the future.
speaker: Henry

qTextArr: ['I didn t do wrong, did I?']
qText: I didn t do wrong, did I?
speaker: Henry

qTextArr: ['You didn t, darling. Nothing has been done wrong.']
qText: You didn t, darling. Nothing has been done wrong.
speaker: Margaret

qTextArr: ['Here they are at last!']
qText: Here they are at last!
speaker: Henry

qTextArr: ['The field s cut!', 'the big meadow! We ve seen to\nthe very end, and it ll be such a crop of hay as never!']
qText:
The field s cut! the big meadow! We ve seen to
the very end, and it ll be such a crop of hay as never!
speaker: Helen
